text:
(Horizons). 1981, 1983, 1984. Music, Ramon P. Santos. Commissioned by the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) and League of Filipino Composers (“Abot-tanaw I” and “II”), and National Music Competition for Young Artists or NAMCYA (“Abot-tanaw III”). First performed by Lester Demetillo on 17 Oct 1983 at the CCP (“Abot-tanaw I”), Carmencita Lozada on 25 Jan 1984 in Reutlingen, West Germany (“Abot-tanaw II”), and Aima Labra in the 1985 NAMCYA contest (“Abot-tanaw III”) and in a solo recital on 2 Sep 2011 at the University of the Philippines Abelardo Hall Auditorium.

 

Abot-tanaw consists of three large works for three solo instruments: guitar, violin, and piano, respectively. Although written separately, they all explore new performance techniques for and exploit the whole gamut of technical and timbral possibilities of each instrument to evoke widely divergent sound colors. Old Philippine and Asian art forms influence the sound structures in different ways, capturing facets of the improvisatory nuances of Philippine indigenous music within set melodic and rhythmic formulae. Written by Corazon C. Dioquino

text:
1978. Music, Jose Maceda. Lyrics based on the poem “Sa Dilim” by Rogelio Mangahas. First performed in Sep 1978 at the Cultural Center of the Philippines by music students and employees from the University of the Philippines.

 

The “Ading” is a song genre performed by women of the Kalinga people of the northern Philippines.

The work is an example of composer Jose Maceda’s attempt to apply his concept of a “Village Thinking” pervasive in Southeast Asia as a source of an alternative music that reflects a healthy relationship of equilibrium linking man to nature. Ading blurs the line that separates the two participating groups—performers and members of the audience—that populate the musical event and provides them both with opportunities for active music making. It involves 100 instrumentalists, 100 singers, and asks for a 600 to 1,000 member audience. All the instruments are native to the Philippines and easy to process: 20 tagpis (whistle flute), 20 batiwtiw (one-string zither), 20 tagutok (scraper or bull-roarer), 20 balingbing (buzzer), all made of bamboo; wooden kalutang (percussion sticks) and 20 pairs of batongbuhay (polished stones). They may be replaced by other instruments available at the site of the music making. The vocalists are likewise divided into five sub-groups, each composed of 20 singers. Each subgroup is given a fragment of the traditional Kalinga “Ading” melody, sung to the text of Mangahas’s “Sa Dilim” (In the Darkness) to perform at a given time and each member of the subgroup may perform it at his or her own pace. The text of the poem reads:

naliligaw ang dilat

sa gubat ng karimlan,

ngunit hindi ang bulag

na doo’y ating gabay.

 

(lost in the jungle

is the wide-eyed,

but not the blind,

who, there, is our guide.)

From the beginning of the 30-minute composition, the audience is an active participant in the music-making, intoning single words from the poem for long intervals before moving on to subsequent words, thus providing long drawn, continuous sounds at a single pitch.

The entire participating population produces a multilayered machinery of drones. The music is slow to change, and when it does, it requires the cooperation of an entire organization that “employs rather than repels people.” Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, with notes from Elena Rivera Mirano

 

Source

 

Maceda, Jose. 1979. “Inventions, Drones and Populations as Elements for a New Music in Asia,” Paper read at the 6th Asian Composers’ League Conference, Seoul, Korea. 11-18 Oct.

photos.desc:
Image of the eagle in the Anino Shadowplay Collective’s interpretation of “Agila, Haring Ibon,” 2012

(Anino Shadowplay Collective)

text:
(Eagle, Bird King). 1982. Music and lyrics, Joey Ayala. Commissioned by the Philippine Eagle Conservation Project based in Davao. It became the official anthem of Haribon Foundation. First performed by Joey Ayala in 1982, and included in his 1991 album titled Panganay ng Umaga (Morning’s Firstborn).

 

This ballad in moderate duple time was first recorded in 1982 for the album Panganay ng Umaga. After a visit to the Philippine Eagle Center in Davao—which eventually adopted “Agila” as its official song­—Ayala was struck by the beauty of the birds and used the eagle as a symbol for nature and marginalized peoples displaced by the aggressive exploitation of the environment. The song’s doleful melody mourns the degradation of the environment. It criticizes humans who consume and extract at a rate faster than the earth can regenerate. There are so few eagles left:

Tiniklop na nila ang kanilang mga pakpak

Hinubad na nila ang kanilang mga plumahe

Sila’y nagsipagtago sa natitirang gubat

Ang lahi ba nila’y tuluyan nang mawawala?

 

(They have folded up their wings

They have shed their feathers

They have hidden in the remnants of the forests

Is their race doomed to extinction?)

Ayala added guitar, octavina, and sticks to the arrangement when he recorded it a second time in 1989. In 1991, he recorded it for Wea (now Universal) Records, again varying the instrumentation using more guitars and bongo drums. It was also recorded by KC Concepcion in 2008. Finally, the song was arranged for children’s choir by Annie Roque-Nepomuceno in a version commissioned by the UP Cherubim and Seraphim and included in their 2005 album, Bata ang Bukas (Child is the Future).  Written by Milagros Carunungan, updated by Arwin Q. Tan, with additional notes from Elena Rivera Mirano

photos.desc: Apo Hiking Society performing at the Pantages Playhouse, Winnipeg, Canada, 2007 (Josel Catindoy)

text:
1985. Music and lyrics, Jim Paredes. Produced by Wea (now Universal) Records. First performed by the APO Hiking Society.

This novelty number in fast duple time decries the pervasiveness of American Top 40 music on Philippine radio. It is part of APO Hiking Society’s campaign to promote original Pilipino music or OPM and to break away from the trend obsessing many a Filipino songwriter—recording American-sounding music hoping for international recognition.

The song calls on Filipinos to curb their excessive devotion to American pop. The ample airtime given the overtly political song was due to its jocose treatment of an otherwise weighty political issue. One stanza goes:

Leave me alone to my third world devices

I don’t need your technology

You just want my natural resources

And then you leave me poor and in misery.

Set to the commanding throb of the singkil rhythm, the number opens with a colorful ethnic mood enhanced by the fluid tones of the kulintang and the rhythmic buzz of the kubing (mouth harp). From a wistful ethnic-inspired melody, “American Junk” swings off to a chorus representing “Third World rock ‘n’ roll.” The absurd, hilarious dialogue between Pidro, the English-speaking Filipino, and Joe, the American, contributes to the political sting of the song.

This song has been recorded by the rock groups Kamikazee and Parokya ni Edgar in a tribute album to the APO Hiking Society titled Kami nAPO Muna Ulit (It’s Our Turn Now Again) under Universal Records in 2007. It was a sequel to their earlier album titled Kami nAPO Muna (It’s Our Turn Now) in 2006. The song has also been included in Noel Cabangon’s Throwback: Ang Songbook ng Apo (Throwback: The Apo Songbook) CD, in a medley which includes “Tuloy ang Ikot ng Mundo/American Junk/Bawat Bata” (The World Continues to Turn/American Junk/Every Child), released by Universal Records in 2014.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

photos.desc:
Vinyl record cover of Freddie Aguilar’s Anak, 1977

(Vicor Records)

text:
(Child). 1977. Music and lyrics, Freddie Aguilar. First performed by Freddie Aguilar at the First Metro Manila Popular Music Festival in 1978.

One of the most popular folk ballads ever recorded in the Philippines and Aguilar’s first hit, the song upholds traditional family values by showing how parents dote on their children and make many sacrifices for them. It also criticizes the prodigal children, who, when they are grown, forget what their parents have done for them.

Aguilar strikes an emotional chord by speaking directly to the children. It ends with the singer calling the children to ask their parents for forgiveness and understanding thusly:

Nagdaan pa ang mga araw

At ang landas mo’y naligaw

Ikaw ay nalulong sa masamang bisyo.

At ang una mong nilapitan

Ang ’yong inang lumuluha

At ang tanong “anak, ba’t ka nagkaganyan?”

At ang iyong mga mata’y

Biglang lumuha nang di mo napapansin

Pagsisisi ang sa isip mo

Nalaman mong ika’y nagkamali.

 

(And the days passed

And you lost your way

You got hooked on vices

And the first person you approached

Was your crying mother

Who asked you, “Son, why have you done this to

yourself?”

And your eyes

Suddenly shed tears without your noticing them

Remorse was foremost in your mind

Knowing that you had done wrong.

The lyrics are performed in a style that is half sung and half spoken. The acoustic guitar accompaniment exhibits a folk-rock influence. The song was a hit in Asia and has been translated into several languages including English, Japanese, French, Russian, and German.

The song has been arranged for mixed choir by several composers, among them Robert Delgado Jr whose version has been popularized by the Philippine Madrigal Singers; and the German composer Ralph Hoffmann, whose interpretation has been rendered for international audiences by the Novo Concertante Manila and the UP Concert Chorus. Sharon Cuneta’s version of “Anak” was used as the soundtrack for the movie of the same title, released in 2000, featuring Vilma Santos playing the role of an overseas Filipino worker (OFW). In 2014, the song was featured in the movie Gangnam Blues starring Korean superstar Lee Min Ho. Written by Milagros Carunungan, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

photos.desc: Cast of Andres Bonifacio, Ang Dakilang Anak Pawis, 2013 (Andres Bonifacio Concert Choir)

text:
(Andres Bonifacio, The Great Plebeian). 1979. Music and musical direction, Jerry A. Dadap; libretto, Jerry A. Dadap, Paulino Capitulo, Rogelio Mangahas, and Dionisio Salazar; stage direction, Tony Espejo; choreography, Gener Caringal; set design, Salvador Bernal; costume design, Warto Torrevillas; lighting design, Monino Duque.

 

Commissioned by the Manila Bankers Life Insurance Corporation and the Loyola Group of Companies. First performed on 16 Nov 1979 at the Tanghalang Nicanor Abelardo, Cultural Center of the Philippines. Cast: Elmo Makil, Jay Valencia-Glorioso, Tommy Abuel, and 200 other performers.

Based on Teodoro Agoncillo’s Revolt of the Masses, the three-hour, five-act opera closely follows the life of Andres Bonifacio from his early days as the breadwinner for his orphaned brothers and sisters, to his marriage to Gregoria de Jesus, his involvement with La Liga Filipina, and his leadership of the Katipunan. He leads several successful battles against the Spanish army. However, two factions develop within the movement: the Magdiwang faction of Andres Bonifacio based in Manila, and the Magdalo faction of General Emilio Aguinaldo based in Cavite. In the climactic Tejeros Convention in Cavite, Bonifacio is grilled by the Magdalo faction who finds him “unworthy” of a position in the movement. Appalled, he leaves the convention with his followers. They are later arrested by Aguinaldo’s soldiers. After a mock trial, Bonifacio and his brother Procopio are brought to Mount Buntis where they face their execution with dignity.

Dadap used period music such as the danza and marcha. Indigenous instruments, like the kalatong, a pair of sticks which warns people of an impending attack, was also employed.

Between 1979 to 1992, the piece was staged around 150 times, from Lagaue, Mountain Province, to Zamboanga City. It was restaged at the University of the Philippines College of Music (UPCM) Abelardo Hall Auditorium in Sep 2013 in celebration of Abelardo Hall’s 50th anniversary and Andres Bonifacio’s 150th birth anniversary. The 2013 production was directed by Alegria O. Ferrer and featured UP College of Music alumni and students with Jerry Dadap’s Andres Bonifacio Concert Choir (ABCC). ABCC performed it again with the conductor himself directing at the Saint Scholastica’s College Manila in Nov 2013 and at the GSIS Theater, CCP Complex, Pasay City with the Manila Symphony Orchestra (MSO) conducted by Arturo Molina in Nov 2014. Another GSIS Theater version with the MSO and RTU Tunog Rizalia Rondalla was performed in 2015.  Written by Antonio C. Hila, updated by Josephine Cecilia L. Baradas

text:
(What is Fate?). 1939. Music and lyrics, Francisco Santiago.

 

A binary waltz in a minor-major mode with a short cadenza at the end, the song is a favorite showpiece of light sopranos and coloraturas. The song asks what fate awaits a man who professes his undying love with no assurance that it will be reciprocated by the object of his affection:

Ano kaya ang kapalaran

Ng aba’t imbing lagay

Asahan mo’t di palad

Kakamtan mo’y saklap.

 

(What would be the fate

Of my poor and miserable condition

Expect misfortune

Pain is all you gain.)

The year it was composed, Jose A. Estella, the “waltz king of the Philippines,” dragged Santiago to court for plagiarism, claiming that the song was copied from his “Campanadas de Gloria” (Bells of Glory). The celebrated case involved the testimonies of many musicians, including Antonio J. Molina, Bonifacio Abdon, and Juan Silos Jr.

In his defense, Santiago said “Ano Kaya ang Kapalaran?” was based on the San Roque version of “Leron-leron, Sinta” (Leron-leron, Beloved). He further said that he treated the borrowed theme through the use of compositional techniques such as augmentation and ornamentation. He also claimed to have embellished the melody with the “autochthonous rhythm of the kundiman in the first and fifth bars” as the melody did not have the “characteristic Filipino rhythm,” and because he wanted to clothe it with “something native.” Judge Fernando Hugo of the Manila Court of First Instance, and later the Supreme Court, acquitted Santiago. Written by Antonio C. Hila

photos.desc:
“Atin Cu Pung Singsing” interpreted as a funeral dirge in Carlo Catu’s Ari: My Life with a King, 2015

(Photo courtesy of Carlo Catu)

text:
(I Have a Ring). Kapampangan folk song.

 

 

The two-stanza text of this song is made up of four 12-syllable lines each. Each line of the text corresponds to one musical phrase, with the four musical phrases making up two periods. Set in fast triple time, it is cast in a major key, with the second and fourth phrases cadencing on the tonic, and the first and third phrases ending on the dominant and subdominant respectively. The entire melody is based on one rhythmic pattern which is repeated throughout the song. The text expresses the great sentimental value placed by the Filipino on objects inherited from parents. The song is about a missing heirloom piece, a ring with a single gem. Upset, the persona, with crossed arms on the table, promises to obey anyone who can find the ring.

The tune has been used as thematic material by Lucrecia R. Kasilag in her Five Philippine Folk Songs, 1957, for women’s voices with piano accompaniment; Lucino T. Sacramento in his Three Philippine Vistas, 1970, a chamber work; and Antonio J. Molina in Ang Batingaw (The Bell), 1972, a choral symphony for mixed choir and orchestra. The song was recorded by Ramon Acoymo, tenor, and Lisa Florentino, soprano, in their CD album Immortal Philippine Songs, 1997. The song was also arranged for solo piano by Augusto Espino in Seleksiyon (Selection), 2002, a collection of pedagogical arrangements for piano based on Filipino folk songs. It was also recorded on CD by Nita Abrogar-Quinto in Guhit Tugtugin at Seleksiyon (Piano Sketches and Selections) in the same year. In 2015, Ryan Cayabyab included his orchestral arrangement of the song for the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra in the CD Serenata of the Cultural Center of the Philippines.  Written by Corazon C. Dioquino, updated by James C. Diaz

article.value: (I Have a Ring). Kapampangan folk song.

Each line of the text corresponds to one musical phrase, with the four musical phrases making up two periods. Set in fast triple time, it is cast in a major key, with the second and fourth phrases cadencing on the tonic, and the first and third phrases ending on the dominant and subdominant respectively. The entire melody is based on one rhythmic pattern which is repeated throughout the song. The text expresses the great sentimental value placed by the Filipino on objects inherited from parents. The song is about a missing heirloom piece, a ring with a single gem. Upset, the persona, with crossed arms on the table, promises to obey anyone who can find the ring.

The tune has been used as thematic material by Lucrecia R. Kasilag in her Five Philippine Folk Songs, 1957, for women’s voices with piano accompaniment; Lucino T. Sacramento in his Three Philippine Vistas, 1970, a chamber work; and Antonio J. Molina in Ang Batingaw (The Bell), 1972, a choral symphony for mixed choir and orchestra. The song was recorded by Ramon Acoymo, tenor, and Lisa Florentino, soprano, in their CD album Immortal Philippine Songs, 1997. The song was also arranged for solo piano by Augusto Espino in Seleksiyon (Selection), 2002, a collection of pedagogical arrangements for piano based on Filipino folk songs. It was also recorded on CD by Nita Abrogar-Quinto in Guhit Tugtugin at Seleksiyon (Piano Sketches and Selections) in the same year. In 2015, Ryan Cayabyab included his orchestral arrangement of the song for the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra in the CD Serenata of the Cultural Center of the Philippines.  Written by Corazon C. Dioquino, updated by James C. Diaz

text:
1919. Music, Francisco Santiago. Lyrics based on the Latin version of the Catholic “Hail Mary.”

 

The Latin “Ave Maria” or “Hail Mary” has often been set to various forms and styles of music, and not all for church use. Most Philippine composers have written Ave Marias, among them Rosendo Santos, Antonio J. Molina, Manuel Velez, Juan S. Hernandez, Cenon Bernabe, Francisco Buencamino, Rosalina Abejo, Nicanor S. Abelardo, Felipe Padilla de Leon, Lucrecia R. Kasilag, and Francisco Santiago.

Santiago’s version was written in partial fulfilment of the requirements for a teacher’s certificate in science and composition in 1922. Scored for piano, high voice, and violin, it adheres closely to the principles of classical music. It is divided into two: the first part, in 4/4 meter, is in G minor; the second part shifts to 3/4 meter, is in the tonic major, and uses accentuated triplets. Highly expressive and featuring a violin obbligato, it projects solemnity and pious fervor.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes

photos.desc:
Album cover of Josephine Roces’s El Alma Filipina, 1998,
which includes “Ay Kalisud” (Photo courtesy of Leo Cloma)

Album cover of Josephine Roces’s El Alma Filipina, 1998,
which includes “Ay Kalisud” (Photo courtesy of Leo Cloma)

text:
(Ah, Misery). Ca 1910. First performed in public by Jovita Fuentes in 1919 at a concert sponsored by the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas. Recorded by Fuentes for Odeon Records of Germany in 1928.

The somber minor key and brooding Ilonggo lyrics make this traditional song an intensely romantic, sighing piece. Its lyrics speak of the despair of one who has been abandoned by the beloved:

 

Ay, ay, kalisud

Kalisud sang binayaan

Adlaw gab-i

Firme kita guina tangisan

Ahay, Inday

Nga walay sing kapalaran

Walay guid

Walay guid

Sarang co kalipayan.

 

(Ah, misery

Misery of the abandoned

Night and day

Always, I weep for you

Ah, Inday

Fortune lost

None

Nothing else

Can make me happy.)

Francisco Santiago transcribed the song in 1928, while Nicanor S. Abelardo arranged it as a foxtrot for orchestra in 1930. It has been sung, recorded, and arranged countless times. Mezzo-soprano Priscilla V. Magdamo and classical guitarist Michael Dadap included the song in an album, Ang Katahum Mubihag: Songs of the Visayans. Coloratura soprano Zonia Elvas-Velasco arranged the song for her US-produced solo album From East to West. In the late 1930s, Filippine Films produced the movie Ay Kalisud, inspired by the folk song. Soprano Conching Rosal included the song in a CD album Immortal Kundiman of the Philippines. Soprano Josephine Roces also included the song in her CD album El Alma Filipina (The Filipino Soul) in 1998. Restie Umali and Lucio D. San Pedro have both done choral arrangements of the song. Lucio D. San Pedro also arranged the song for two voices, included in 50 Immortal Filipino Duets, a collection of timeless Philippine duets published by the National Philharmonic Society of the Philippines in 1998, with Redentor L. Romero as the music director. Gilopez Kabayao transcribed the song for violin and piano in 1974, and in the same year performed it with Corazon Kabayao at the piano, on their concert tours abroad. The song which was originally recorded in 1974, is included in their CD album Gilopez Kabayao Plays Philippine Folk Songs, 2000. Augusto Espino arranged the song for solo piano in “Recuerdo Variations” based on Jovita Fuentes’s “Ay Kalisud” in 2002. In 2015, Ryan Cayabyab included the orchestral arrangement of the song for the Philippine Philharmonic in the CD Serenata of the Cultural Center of the Philippines.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by James C. Diaz

photos.desc:
Inang Laya performance, ca 1980

(CCP Collection)

text:
(You’re a Woman). 1981. Music and lyrics, Ananias Montano. First performed by Something Special in the Fourth Metro Manila Popular Music Festival in 1981 where the song won the grand prize. “Babae Ka” was also a bronze-prize winner in the 1981 Seoul Song Festival.

 

The haunting yet rousing feminist tune in moderate duple time lays bare the contradictions that stifle women:

 

Babae ka, hinahangad, sinasamba

Ipinagtatanggol, ikaw nama’y walang laya

Ang daigdig mo’y lagi lang nasa tahanan

Ganda lang ang pakinabang, sa buhay walang alam.

 

(You’re a woman, longed for and worshipped;

Defended, yet you’re not free.

Your world is limited to the home

Your beauty is your only worth, and you know

nothing about life.)

 

It exhorts women to step out of the portals of home towards advancement and freedom. The song bids women to work for emancipation and the struggle for national liberation.

This song became part of the repertoire of Inang Laya, who sang it in protest rallies and mass assemblies during the Marcos regime. It was aired constantly on television as the theme of Nikki Coseteng’s TV program Womanwatch.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes

text:
(You Will Be Back). Circa 1930s. Music and lyrics, Constancio de Guzman. Recorded by Sylvia la Torre (Songs of Love, 1958) for Villar Records and Celeste Legaspi (Bagong Plaka Lumang Kanta, 1979) for Wea (now Universal) Records.

 

A typical danza menor in 4/4 beat and in tempo moderato, the song’s structure is AAB. The song tells of one’s despair over the loss of a beloved, using the image of a bird unable to fly after a long and unsuccessful search for its nest. The song ends, however, with a hope that the beloved will come back:

 

Babalik ka rin

Upang ako ay aliwin

Sa mga tinitiis kong

Kalungkutan.

 

(You will be back

To give me comfort

From the loneliness

That I bear.)

 

The song is said to have been sung by bodabil performers during the Japanese Occupation to allude to General Douglas MacArthur’s promise (“I shall return”) and to keep the people’s faith in freedom alive.

“Babalik Ka Rin” was arranged for vocal duet by Alfredo S. Buenaventura and included in 50 Immortal Filipino Duets, 1992. Ryan Cayabyab wrote an orchestral arrangement for the San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra (SMPO). The song, performed by Basil Valdez and accompanied by the SMPO, is included in their CD album The Filipino Classics, 2006. Written by Michael M. Coroza, updated by James C. Diaz

photos.desc:
Sheet music of “My Nipa Hut,” 1914 (The Philippines

Progressive Music Series for the Primary Grades, compiled

by Norberto Romualdez. Silver Burdett Co., 1914.)

text:
(Nipa Hut). Tagalog folk song.

 

Among the best-known traditional Tagalog folk songs in the country, the title refers to the typical rural dwelling on stilts with walls of nipa, and frames, floor, and posts of bamboo. The song as transcribed by Norberto Romualdez was published in The Philippine Progressive Music Series, 1932, a compendium of music used in Philippine elementary schools nationwide. The text notes that though the hut is small, it has a great variety of vegetables—string beans, pumpkin, peanuts, eggplant, and others grown in the garden around the hut:

Kundol, patola

Upo’t kalabasa

At saka mayro’n pang

Labanos, mustasa

Sibuyas, kamatis

Bawang at luya

Sa paligid-ligid

Ay puro linga.

(White gourd melon, vegetable gourd

Bottle gourd and pumpkin

And there also are

Radish, mustard

Onion, tomato

Garlic and ginger

And all around

Are sesame seeds.)

The song is made up of four 4-measure phrases making up two 8-measure periods. It is cast in the major mode, with each of the two consequent phrases ending on the tonic and the two antecedent phrases ending on the dominant. When harmonized, the melody calls for simple tonic, subdominant, dominant progressions.

“Bahay Kubo” has been used as thematic material in large works by some composers, notably Lucio D. San Pedro in his Lahing Kayumanggi (Brown Race), 1961, Felipe Padilla de Leon in his Awit ng Buhay (Song of Life), 1969, and Ramon P. Santos in his Canon on a Folk Theme, 1972. The theme, set in duple meter, paso doble style, has been continuously used in the Arakyo, a local version of the komedya performed in the town of San Jose, Peñaranda, Nueva Ecija. Bernardino Custodio also used the theme in his variations for solo piano, Pauli-uli, a competition piece for the National Music Competitions for Young Artists (NAMCYA) category C. Gilopez Kabayao transcribed the song for violin and piano in 1974, and performed it with Corazon Kabayao at the piano, on their concert tours abroad. This transcription, which was originally recorded in 1974, is included in their CD album Gilopez Kabayao Plays Philippine Folk Songs in 2000. Written by Corazon C. Dioquino, updated by James C. Diaz

photos.desc:
Album cover of  Ogie Alcasid’s Ogie 10th All the Best, 1998,

which includes “Bakit Ngayon Ka Lang” (Universal Records)

text:
(Why Have You Come Only Now). 1994. Composed by Ogie Alcasid and Aaron Paul del Rosario. The song is included in the album Ogie Alcasid On Air released in 1994 by PolyEast Records.

“Bakit Ngayon Ka Lang” expresses the singer’s distress about meeting the love of his life too late, after he has committed to someone else. The chorus reads:

 

Bakit ngayon ka lang dumating sa buhay ko

Pilit binubuksan ang sarado ko nang puso

Ikaw ba ay nararapat sa akin

At siya ba’y dapat ko nang limutin

(Why have you come to my life only now

Compelling my already committed heart to open

Are you the right one for me

And should I forget her)

In the key of G major, this is a pop song in the common verse-refrain-chorus form. The two verses span eight bars, each made up of “square” (or symmetrical) phrases. These contrast with the refrain, in which the eight bars are extended to two more and the chorus, which accelerates after the eight bars. The pattern of regularly phrased verses followed by the extended chorus section articulates the moving message of the lyrics that goes hand in hand with the transformation of Alcasid’s voice from tenderness in the verses to an impetuous rendering of the questioning in the chorus, especially in its repeats with notes in high register. The strings-laden accompaniment supports this transformation, creating a mood of endearment that “embraces” Alcasid’s voice.

In 2001, the band Freestyle, with its lead vocalist Top Suzara, sang the song in concert with Pops Fernandez, interpreting it as a male-female duet. While Alcasid’s version presents a one-sided perspective, the duet of Suzara and Fernandez expands the song’s narrative with both parties now seemingly engaged in a conversation about their longing for each other and the regret that comes with the realization that they can never be together.

Suzara and Fernandez’s live performance was recorded and included in the album Love Concert: The Album Vol. 1, 2002, a collection of love songs by Freestyle, Zsa Zsa Padilla, and Lani Misalucha, released by VIVA Records. “Bakit Ngayon Ka Lang” also became one of Freestyle’s most popular songs. Suzara with fellow vocalist Jinky Vidal performed it several times and most recently in their 2016 concert, years after their disbandment.

Alcasid’s version became the theme song for the movie Jeannie, Bakit Ngayon Ka Lang, 2002, starring Robin Padilla and Judy Ann Santos. In 2005, Freestyle recorded the song with Pops Fernandez for their album Greatest Hits. Pilipinas Got Talent Season 2 champion Marcelito Pomoy performed the song for his album Duet Yourself, 2011. His unique vocal range allowed him to sing both male and female parts, making it seem as if two people are singing the duet.

Alcasid has also included this song in several of his albums: Ogie 10th All the Best, 1998; OA sa Hits Live (Ogie Alcasid’s Hits Live), 2002; All the Classics, 2007; Ogie Alcasid Greatest Hits Vol. 2, 2010; and a vinyl release of All the Classics, 2014.

“Bakit Ngayon Ka Lang” remains to be one of Alcasid’s most endearing and popular compositions. The album Ogie Alcasid On Air where this song was first included achieved Double Platinum status when it was released by PolyEast Records in 1994. The song also won for Alcasid Best Performance by a Male Recording Artist and Best Movie Theme Song in the 1994 Awit Awards. Written by Ariel Lev L. Pinzon, with additional notes from Jose S. Buenconsejo

photos.desc:
Scene from Bakya Mo Neneng, 1947, which used Santiago Suarez’s compositions

(National Library of the Philippines Collection)

text:
(Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng). Circa 1946. Music, Santiago Suarez; lyrics, Dominador Santiago.

 

A vocal duet in balitaw style, the song was inspired by the lowly bakya (wooden clogs) which became standard footwear during the Japanese Occupation owing to the exigencies of the times. Soon after the war, a movie by the same title directed by Consuelo P. Osorio was produced in 1947 by Premiere Productions starring Rosa del Rosario and Leopoldo Salcedo. This was the first in a series of Tagalog movie musicals based on titles of Suarez’s compositions which include “Caprichosa” (Capricious Woman) and “Bulaklak at Paruparo” (Flower and Butterfly).

The music is cast in binary form, with the first part in minor key, modulating to the parallel major in the second part. Two independent melodic lines, one for soprano and the other for baritone, are sung in counterpoint to each other. The soprano text is idealistic, extolling the simple but honorable Filipino whose pain and sufferings are assuaged by the beauty of the kundiman and balitaw. On another more realistic plane, the baritone text speaks of a love symbolized by a discarded bakya.

Bakya mo, Neneng

Luma at kupas na

Ngunit may bakas pa

Ng luha mo, sinta.

(Your wooden clogs, Neneng

They’re old and faded

But they still bear the marks

Of your tears, beloved.)

In the 1960s, Rey T. Paguio arranged a choral medley, titled Neneng, consisting of some Suarez’s balitaw that included this song. The song was once again revived in the 1980s with a new treatment by Ryan Cayabyab in his song album, One. The arrangement was choreographed by Tony Fabella in a work titled Limang Dipa (Five Armstretches) commissioned by Dance Theater Philippines in 1981. In 1996, Redentor L. Romero transcribed the song for the orchestra and conducted its performance by the Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra. The song is included in his CD album Damdaming Pinoy (Filipino Feelings), recorded in Moscow, Russia. It is also arranged for two voices and included in 50 Immortal Filipino Duets, published by the National Philharmonic Society of the Philippines in 1998, with Redentor L. Romero as music director. Written by Corazon C. Dioquino, updated by James C. Diaz

Luma at kupas na
Ngunit may bakas pa
Ng luha mo, sinta.
(Your wooden clogs, Neneng
They’re old and faded
But they still bear the marks
Of your tears, beloved.)

In the 1960s, Rey T. Paguio arranged a choral medley, titled Neneng, consisting of some Suarez’s balitaw that included this song. The song was once again revived in the 1980s with a new treatment by Ryan Cayabyab in his song album, One. The arrangement was choreographed by Tony Fabella in a work titled Limang Dipa (Five Armstretches) commissioned by Dance Theater Philippines in 1981. In 1996, Redentor L. Romero transcribed the song for the orchestra and conducted its performance by the Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra. The song is included in his CD album Damdaming Pinoy (Filipino Feelings), recorded in Moscow, Russia. It is also arranged for two voices and included in 50 Immortal Filipino Duets, published by the National Philharmonic Society of the Philippines in 1998, with Redentor L. Romero as music director. Written by Corazon C. Dioquino, updated by James C. Diaz

text:
(Darling). Music, folk gabbang song popularized by the 1960s touring Tausug musician Albani and his Dalling Dalling troupe. Lyrics in Cebuano by Max Surban. First released with Surban performing in his cassette album of Visayan songs, Madmax Kuno, on 24 Sep 1984.

 

“Baleleng” is derived from the word “leleng” which means “darling” with a prefix “ba.” The song in moderate quadruple meter is a ballad in simple strophic form. The original lyrics of the folk song from Jolo, Sulu are those of a man bidding goodbye to his beloved as she leaves for Sitangcay and Sibutu islands:

Pila na baleleng, layu-layu

Pila na baleleng pasibutu

Bungkaw bunnal matuyu

Pila na baleleng, layu-layu.

(Even if you go far away, darling

Even if you go as far as Sibutu

I will always remember you

Even if you go far away, darling.)

Surban discovered the song while he was on a tour in Tawi-Tawi, performing for surrenderees during the administration of Pres Ferdinand Marcos. The audience asked him to sing the song, but he was not familiar with it. Later, while having a drink in a restaurant in Zamboanga, Surban heard a local singer sing the song. He took note of it and, upon arrival in Manila, began to work on his own version.

Retaining the first stanza of the original version, Surban added stanzas which describe the girl as the pearl of the island, whiter than the white sand, worthy of anyone’s love. Surban explains that it was necessary for a recording personality like him to translate the song into Visayan to cater to bigger audiences in the region.

A version in the Cordilleras titled “O Marcos Baleleng” (Oh Marcos, Darling) retains the melody of the song, but the lyrics, which were altered, protest the displacement of indigenous groups whose ancestral lands were seized by the abusive government for its projects. Another version comments on the 1981 plebiscite held as part of the “normalization program” of the Marcos government. These alternative versions were sung by Patatag during protest actions in the early 1980s.  Written by Milagros Carunungan, with notes from Josephine Cecilia L. Baradas

text:
(Return to Native Land). 2001. Music, Angel M. Peña. First performed by the University of the Philippines (UP) Jazz Ensemble under the direction of Rayben Maigue in 2002.

 

A jazz piece for big band that utilizes the Filipino folk tune “Magtanim ay Di Biro” (Planting Rice Is Never Fun), Balik-bayan was composed after Peña decided to return to and stay in the Philippines for good after many years of residence in foreign countries.

The piece begins in E-flat major, in 4/4 time, and starts slow. The first measure contains the first three notes of “Planting Rice.” This is harmonized by consecutive 7th chords, which is a traditional jazz chord progression. From measures 2 to 3, the theme is transposed twice, forming a sequence. The timbre of the band in these measures is low and thick, with the theme played by five saxophones and four trombones. Then, the theme is augmented (i.e., note values are lengthened). Meanwhile, the pianist improvises in a lazy blues style. This creates the effect of piano improvisation becoming the subject, while the theme serves as the background behind it. A few moments later, the meter suddenly changes to cut-time tempo (i.e., 2/2). This is the loud swinging shout chorus or tutti. The baritone sax continues the syncopation alone leading to the “vamp.” The final cadence of the theme, starting with the tutti in measure 55, is played ferociously as before. Then the five saxophones play swinging rhythms. Thereafter, the brasses join the saxophones rhythmically.

Measures 129 to 134 serve as a transition, with the drummer playing in unison with the band and leading back to the main theme. Later, the main theme is played by the trombones with syncopated rhythms of the brass and saxophone sections, giving the drummer a chance to employ his incisive “combination kicks” to relentlessly push the big band. This effect lasts for a brief moment.

In measure 147, the key changes from E-flat major to F major. The saxophone section is again featured with cluttered notes in a syncopated pattern. Then comes a brief modulation to the key of A-flat major. In these measures, the rhythm section is in unison with the band in order to enhance the excitement. Measure 155, which is now in the key of A-flat, culminates the piece by restating the theme, this time in a clearer way. Towards the end, the piece is in blues style (4/4 time). The note A-flat is intoned by the lead trumpet in order to stress the final key.

Balik-bayan is inspired by the few big bands in the country and is significant because it enriches original Philippine music literature for big band. Peña has been an exponent of this genre abroad and, as a whole, the piece demonstrates his learned musical style as evident in the abstract and technical way he treats his material. It also exhibits his compositional arrangement skills that improvise on an existing folk theme.  Written by Ricardo C. Quirino

photos.desc: Aicelle Santos, center, performing “Balut” in a scene from Katy! The Musical, CCP, Manila, 2013 (CCP Collection)

text:
(Duck Egg). Music and lyrics, Jerry Brandy. First performed by Katy de la Cruz in the 1930s. Recorded by Pilita Corrales in 1974 and the New Minstrels in 1975. Arranged by Ryan Cayabyab for the musical Katy, 1988.

 

This bawdy and risque song from the vaudeville repertoire pays homage to the balut or fertilized duck egg. In the song, a balut vendor extolls the egg as the antidote to restore the strength of those weak-kneed, presumably from nocturnal exertion:

Balut, penoy, balut

Bili na kayo ng itlog na balut

Sapagkat itong balut

Ay mainam na gamot

Sa mga taong

Nanlalambot ang tuhod.

(Balut, penoy, balut

Why don’t you buy the egg balut

Because this balut

Is a good medicine

For people

Whose knees are weak.)

The melody is frisky, with a Dixieland jazz beat. It was part of the new wave in Philippine popular music in the period before World War II. Much of the popularity of the song is undoubtedly due to Katy de la Cruz’s naughty performance, in the hot jazz-mama style with her signature low, raspy voice.  Written by Milagros Carunungan

photos.desc: Figure 1: Section of the score of Banwa

text:
(Community). 2001. Music, Jonas Baes. Music for four bamboo percussionists and 100 bird whistles distributed among members of the audience. Commissioned by the ASEAN Committee on Culture and Information (COCI) in 1997 and premiered in Bangkok, Thailand in the same year.

The instrumentation of this piece may vary, depending on the context and site of performance. One version replaced the bird whistles with stones, another one with wind chimes made from iron nails. In the original version, the four percussionists, who used bamboo scrapers and who functioned as “animators,” also performed on Maguindanaon tamlang agung (bamboo xylophones). The latter would subsequently be replaced by a sarunay and a khaen (Southeast Asian oboe and mouth organ, respectively) with the addition of a solo vocalist singing an obbligato and a performer from Papua New Guinea doing trail calls. Another version makes use of various Chinese instruments such as the sheng (mouth organ), suona (oboe), pipa (lute), and gong. These changes in instrumentation due to varying social settings and availability of resources in particular performance settings are also manifest in Baes’s other pieces such as Ibo-Ibon (Bird Woman), 1995; Daluy (Flow), 2000; Patangis Buwaya (And the Crocodile Wept), 2003; and Aguyoy (Gentle Wind), 2006. The variations question the very notion of a composition as a finished and fixed entity.

 

Unlike changes in the instrumentation, the role of the audience as performers is constant in the piece. They are transformed from being passive observers and become involved music-making participants as instruments are distributed to them. This circulation of instruments among participants creates an effect akin to the concept of what Benedict Anderson has called the “imagined community,” a bringing of people together with the sole task of filling up the performance space with a “forest of sound.” The size and configuration of the space, the number of people present, the type of local musical resources available, as well as the local musical language directly impact the realization of the work. Four percussionists positioned on each corner around the performance site play a constant eighth note pulse throughout the piece on bamboo scrapers, alternately pausing briefly to distribute instruments to the audience-performers. These four performers play a role that Baes refers to as “animator.” The audience-performers are instructed to play on their instrument as soon as they receive them. Three or four instruments are distributed at a time. At certain sections of the piece, these four percussionists are given the option to perform traditional musical passages, adding a third layer to the music. As the number of audience-performers receiving the instruments gradually increases, the density of the sound forest accumulates as well. Succeeding versions of Banwa also involved other instruments available in the locality. Another element added later is a solo vocal part recalling the melody of a song about the singer’s banwa that the composer heard while doing fieldwork in Mindanao. The last section of the piece involves the retrieval of the instruments from the audience-performers, thus decreasing the overall volume of sound until the piece ends. In other versions, however, the instruments, comprised of homemade wind chimes, are never retrieved and these are offered as gifts by the composer to the people.

Banwa is written in a minimalist score which resembles a spreadsheet rather than a typical music piece. It utilizes a limited number of symbols available in a computer keyboard (see Fig. 1).

Ideally, this score should not be used by the musicians during the performance. Before the performance, a 5- to 10- minute “workshop” is held to explain to the audience how to play the instruments. The work has been performed in several countries including Thailand, Malaysia, Vietnam, and the Philippines. A performance of the piece in New York City in 2011 involved dance choreographed by Kristin Jackson.  Written by LaVerne David C. de la Peña

photos.desc: Performance during the Kaamulan festival, Malaybalay, Bukidnon, 2011 (BukidnonOnline.com)

text:
(Proverbs). 1974. Music, Fabian V. Obispo Jr; lyrics from Bukidnon folk literature, transcribed by Ludivina R. Opeña. First performed by the UP Madrigal Singers and the UP New Music Players and Dancers on 26 Feb 1974 at the University of the Philippines (UP) on the occasion of a concert titled Abang-gardista ’66-’74.

The composer’s first avant-garde composition, it was also the first Filipino New Music work to use choreography. Basahanan refers to the proverbs and aphorisms which are recited during the kaamulan, a social gathering, and kagun, the official rite asking for a woman’s hand in marriage among the Bukidnon.

Scored for soprano, alto, tenor, and bass, with no instrumentation except for the ending, which features an ominous drumbeat, the work shows the marked influence of German New Music advocate Karlheinz Stockhausen. A haunting cloud of sustained voices opens the piece. Performers dance in a circle, while assorted vocal utterances, slides, gasps, shouts, grunts, tremors, echoes, and syllabic enunciations are heard. There are momentary bouts of silence as the performers continue their circular dance. The vocalizations take on a ritualistic air that is punctuated at the end by the savage throb of a drum.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes

text:
(Drenched in the Rain). 1998. Music and lyrics, Celso Abenoja. First performed by Aegis featuring Juliet, Mercy, and Ken Sunot on vocals, Rey Abenoja on lead guitar, Stella Pabico on keyboards, Vilma Goloviogo on drums, and Rowena Adriano on bass guitar. The song is included in the group’s debut album titled Halik (Kiss), released in 1998 under Alpha Records.

 

“Basang-basa sa Ulan” was one of the songs that Celso Abenoja had written about 30 years ago for his former band but was unable to produce due to personal reasons. Aside from its strong recall, the song has heartfelt lyrics about the pain of being alone after losing one’s love. The guttural vocal quality of the music is in the idiom of rock. It is anthem-like in sound, as suggested by the unison melodic fragments that connect the phrases. The song is built around a simple verse-structure (symmetrically of 8-bars each with no bridge) in the key of B. This modulates to C after the second repeat of the chorus. The image of braving the rain as a metaphor for surviving the crisis of abandonment is made more palpable by Aegis’s catchy guitar riffs and the vocalists’ admirable belting of high notes that speaks of triumph over the experience of love lost, thus tugging at the hearts of the Filipino listeners.

After about two decades, the fame and novelty of “Basang-basa sa Ulan” and other Aegis’s songs continued to resonate across all ages and social classes that it even made a crossover to the theater and inspired Liza Magtoto’s musical Rak of Aegis, one of the longest-running original Filipino musical productions today. The production featured Aegis’s iconic songs, including “Basang-basa sa Ulan.” The musical’s debut in 2014 was a critical and commercial success, and the production had its fifth run in 2016.

Together with “Luha” (Tears), “Halik,” and “Sinta” (Beloved), “Basang-basa sa Ulan” was one of Aegis’s hit singles and continues to be a crowd favorite, both local and international, at videoke or karaoke sessions. The song has appeared in three out of seven albums that Aegis has produced so far, particularly in their compilation albums Ating Sayawin (Let’s Dance to It), a dance mix, 2004, under Harmony Music; and Aegis Greatest Hits, 2005, under Alpha Records. Written by Giesil Carina Merin, with additional notes from Jose S. Buenconsejo

Sources

Aegis Band Facebook Page. Accessed 21 Feb 2017. https://www.facebook.com/pg/ aegisband/about/?ref=page_internal.

“Celso Abenoja.” Philippine Music Registry. Accessed 22 Feb 2017. http://philippinemusicregistry.com.ph/main/artist/view/12.

Esteves, Patricia. 2015. “Aegis music is for all ages,” The Philippine Star, 18 Jul. http://www.philstar.com/ entertainment/2015/07/18/1478037/aegis-music-all-ages.

Sanchez, Raymund. 2014. “Rak of Aegis: Pinoy musical wows viewers with world-class production,” Astig.ph. 21 Mar. http://astig.ph/rak-of-aegis-peta-review/

photos.desc:
Album cover of Kami nAPO Muna: Tribute to the

APO Hiking  Society, 2006, which includes “Batang Bata Ka Pa”

(Universal Records)

text:
(You’re Just a Child). 1980. Lyrics and music, Jim Paredes. Performed by the APO Hiking Society.

 

The song echoes Cat Stevens’s 1970s hit, “Father and Son,” in which a father speaks to a son who is pleading with him to be heard and be set free. In Paredes’s composition, written after the birth of his first child, a male parent, speaks to his child who responds in turn. In the first verse, the parent tells the child that he is young and does not comprehend the vicissitudes of life. The verse ends with the father telling the son that as a child, he should listen to his elders.

Batang-bata ka pa at marami ka pang

Kailangang malaman at intindihin sa mundo,

’Yan ang totoo.

Nagkakamali ka kung akala mo na

Ang buhay ay isang mumunting paraiso lamang.

(You are very young and there is so much

You have to learn and understand about the world,

That is the truth.

You are mistaken if you think

That life is just a little paradise.)

In the second verse, the child responds, accepting that his knowledge is limited because of his youth. But he declares that even if he does not understand much about life, he still has the right to question his elders’ moral and ethical decisions and articulate his own views on matters of right and wrong.

Batang-bata ako nalalaman ko ’to,

Inaamin ko rin na kulang ang aking nalalaman

At nauunawaan.

Ngunit kahit ganyan ang kinalalagyan

Alam ko na may karapatan ang bawat nilalang

Kahit bata pa man.

(I am very young and I know it,

I also admit that there is much I don’t know

And understand.

But even in this state

I know that every creature has rights,

Even the very young.)

In the ensuing duet that serves as a refrain, the parent maintains moral ascendancy. This is expressed in the musical line which the parent continues to sing over the child’s vocal line still feebly asserting his desire to comprehend the complexities of life.

Ganyan talaga ang buhay, lagi kang nasasabihan,

Pagka’t ikaw ay bata at wala pang nalalaman,

Makinig ka sa ’king payo pagka’t musmos ka lamang,

At malaman nang maaga ang wasto sa kamalian.

(Life is really like that, people constantly give you

advice,

Because you are a child and you don’t know anything,

Listen to my counsel because you are so innocent,

So you can learn right from wrong as early as possible.)

The song is arranged in 4/4 time, and the refrain sung in a lilting fashion that effectively asserts the primacy of the parental voice. The choice of the fuller-voiced Danny Javier to sing the father part, and the lighter-voiced Buboy Garovillo to perform the child’s role in the original recording further emphasizes the distinction between the old and the young.

The song was part of the APO Hiking Society’s album Ten Years Together in 1980. It has since been used as a cover by Sugarfree in their album Tala-Arawan (Diary), 2006; included in a compilation album released the same year, Kami nAPO Muna (It’s Our Turn Now); and sung by Noel Cabangon in a duet with his son, Gabriel, in a tribute album Throwback: Ang Songbook ng Apo (Throwback: The Apo Songbook), 2014.  Written by Lara T. Mendoza

Source

 

Jimenez, Joyce. 2015. “Noel Cabangon Makes Tribute Album for APO.” Philstar, 24 Jan. http://www.philstar.com/music/2015/01/24/1416311/noel-cabangon-makes-tribute-album-apo.

article.value: (You’re Just a Child). 1980. Lyrics and music, Jim Paredes. Performed by the APO Hiking Society.

value.desc:
Album cover of Kami nAPO Muna: Tribute to the

APO Hiking  Society, 2006, which includes “Batang Bata Ka Pa”

(Universal Records)

article.value: The song echoes Cat Stevens’s 1970s hit, “Father and Son,” in which a father speaks to a son who is pleading with him to be heard and be set free. In Paredes’s composition, written after the birth of his first child, a male parent, speaks to his child who responds in turn. In the first verse, the parent tells the child that he is young and does not comprehend the vicissitudes of life. The verse ends with the father telling the son that as a child, he should listen to his elders.
Batang-bata ka pa at marami ka pang
Kailangang malaman at intindihin sa mundo,
’Yan ang totoo.
Nagkakamali ka kung akala mo na
Ang buhay ay isang mumunting paraiso lamang.
(You are very young and there is so much
You have to learn and understand about the world,
That is the truth.
You are mistaken if you think
That life is just a little paradise.)

In the second verse, the child responds, accepting that his knowledge is limited because of his youth. But he declares that even if he does not understand much about life, he still has the right to question his elders’ moral and ethical decisions and articulate his own views on matters of right and wrong.
Batang-bata ako nalalaman ko ’to,
Inaamin ko rin na kulang ang aking nalalaman

Kahit bata pa man.
(I am very young and I know it,
I also admit that there is much I don’t know
And understand.
But even in this state
I know that every creature has rights,
Even the very young.)

(Life is really like that, people constantly give you
advice,
Because you are a child and you don’t know anything,
Listen to my counsel because you are so innocent,

The song is arranged in 4/4 time, and the refrain sung in a lilting fashion that effectively asserts the primacy of the parental voice. The choice of the fuller-voiced Danny Javier to sing the father part, and the lighter-voiced Buboy Garovillo to perform the child’s role in the original recording further emphasizes the distinction between the old and the young.

The song was part of the APO Hiking Society’s album Ten Years Together in 1980. It has since been used as a cover by Sugarfree in their album Tala-Arawan (Diary), 2006; included in a compilation album released the same year, Kami nAPO Muna (It’s Our Turn Now); and sung by Noel Cabangon in a duet with his son, Gabriel, in a tribute album Throwback: Ang Songbook ng Apo (Throwback: The Apo Songbook), 2014.  Written by Lara T. Mendoza

photos.desc: Scene from Bato sa Buhangin, 1976, starring Vilma Santos and Fernando Poe Jr (Photo courtesy of FPJ Productions)

text:
(Stone in the Sand). 1976. Music, Ernani Cuenco; lyrics, Snaffu Rigor. First performed by Yolly Samson. Recorded by Cinderella under RCA in 1976.

The song compares love to a stone in the sand. Romantic love at its onset offers unending and lifelong promises, but once accepted, it diminishes like a stone in the sand, eroding into the sea. A stanza goes:

Kay hirap unawain

Bawat damdamin

Pangakong magmahal

Hanggang libing

Sa langit may tagpuan din

At do’n hihintayin

Itong bato sa buhangin.

(It’s hard to understand

Each feeling

The promise to love

Unto the grave

We shall meet in heaven

And there I will wait

For this stone in the sand.)

A 1976 movie of the same title starring Fernando Poe Jr and Vilma Santos used this song as its theme. In 1980, Ernani Cuenco did a two-piano arrangement of the song which was performed by duo pianists Della Besa and Anna Maria de Guzman. Dick Zamora also arranged the song for two pianos in 1992. Ryan Cayabyab transcribed the song for the orchestra, along with some of the best songs of Ernani Cuenco. The song is included in a CD album he produced in 2000, Tribute to Ernani Cuenco, with the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra.  Written by Milagros Carunungan, updated by James C. Diaz

photos.desc:
“Bayan Ko” being sung at Corazon Aquino’s last campaign rally, Tarlac, 1986
(Bayan Ko! Images of the Philippine Revolt by Project 28 Days, Ltd., 1986.)

text:
(My Country). 1928. Music, Constancio de Guzman; lyrics, Jose Corazon de Jesus.

“Bayan Ko” was written at a period when the Philippines was actively clamoring for independence from the United States. The nationalist sentiment expressed by the text made the song a battle cry against colonialism and oppression at different periods in Philippine history. It was popular during the Japanese occupation, and later, in the rallies and protest marches during the Marcos regime that culminated in the 1986 EDSA Revolution. During the Marcos years, the word umiiyak (crying) in the phrase ibon man may layang lumipad, kulungin mo at umiiyak (a bird with freedom to fly, imprison it and it cries) was changed to pumipiglas (struggling) in order to emphasize that active participation is necessary to achieve freedom.

Cast in the slow triple time of the traditional kundiman, this plaintive and melodious love song is dedicated to the beloved Inang Bayan (Mother Country). In binary form, the first part is written in a minor key and the second, in its relative major. The text of the first part describes the Philippines as a beautiful woman that has been imprisoned and enslaved by colonial masters.

At sa kanyang yumi at ganda,

Dayuhan ay nahalina

Bayan ko, binihag ka

Nasadlak sa dusa.

(And due to her gentleness and beauty

Foreigners have been attracted.

My country, you were imprisoned

You fell into disgrace and suffered.)

The shift in key marks a change in the tone of the lyrics that look forward to a day when the natural desire for freedom is achieved:

Pilipinas kong minumutya,

Pugad ng luha at dalita,

Aking adhika

Makita kang sakdal laya.

(My beloved Philippines,

Nest of my tears and poverty,

It is my goal

To see you totally free.)

Music and lyrics build up to an emotional ending that prompts singers at rallies to cap the song with the cry, “Mabuhay ang Pilipinas!” (Long Live the Philippines!).

In 1970, it was included in the revival of Severino Reyes’s Walang Sugat (No Wounds) by the Zarzuela Foundation, and has since then been included in all revivals of this popular sarsuwela. The song was arranged for a mixed choir and orchestra by Lucio D. San Pedro in 1978. It has also been adapted for the violin and recorded by the National Philharmonic Orchestra with violinist Redentor L. Romero assisted at the piano by Rey T. Paguio. The transcription for the violin is included in Great Philippine Classics, 1991, a compendium of Philippine compositions for violin and piano. Composer Francisco F. Feliciano likewise used it as thematic material in his opera La Loba Negra (The Black She-wolf). Freddie Aguilar’s soulful revival of the song contributed to its popularization as the anthem of protest marches in the 1980s. The song was used as the culminating piece in the 1998 Philippine Centennial production of the resident companies of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (Ballet Philippines, Bayanihan Philippine National Folk Dance Company, and the Philippine Madrigal Singers) at the ’98 Lisbon Expo in Portugal.

It has been recorded by the Japanese harpist, Tadao Hayashi, and was sung by the visiting British boys’ choir, Libera, in 2008.  Written by Antonio C. Hila, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

Related Content

Protest Songs

photos.desc:
“Beautiful Girl” used in a Philippine Ballet Theatre dance piece of the same title, 2007

(CCP Collection)

text:
1989. Music and lyrics, Jose Mari Chan; arrangement, Jun Orenza; first sung by Jose Mari Chan.

 

This pop song, a ballad, was a selection in Jose Mari Chan’s diamond album titled Constant Change and became an instant hit. The narrative song is in 3/4 time signature with an AABABA form. Chan was inspired to create the song in triple time after he saw a lovely woman from a distance and was captivated by but never met her. The haunting memory of the unknown beauty is the subject of the song:

It was destiny’s game,

For when love finally came on,

I rushed in line only to find

That you were gone.

Beautiful girl,

I’ll search on for you,

‘Til all of your loveliness

in my arms come true.

You’ve made me love again

after a long, long while,

In love again

And I’m glad that it’s you.

The romantic lyrics and lilting melody explain the song’s tremendous appeal to millions of listeners.

In 1990, Seiko Films was quick to ride on the song’s popularity and used “Beautiful Girl” as the theme song of a feature film with the same title. Directed by Laurice Guillen with screenplay by Ricardo Lee, the top-grossing romantic movie starred Gretchen Barretto in the title role in 1990. It also inspired Tony Fabella’s choreography Beautiful Girls that is in Philippine Ballet Theatre’s repertory. The song, at the height of its popularity, was recorded in Japan, Indonesia, Malaysia, and Hong Kong. The Chinese version was sung by Asian superstar Aaron Kwok (Lo 2009, 2011).

In 2010, balladeer Christian Bautista revived “Beautiful Girl” and included it in his double platinum album titled Romance Revisited: The Love Songs of Jose Mari Chan. The music video of this version featured images of the country’s stunning models and actresses like Anne Curtis, Angel Locsin, Georgina Wilson, and Solenn Heusaff. This music video stayed on top of the charts on cable TV’s MYX and Channel [V] for over two months in 2010. “Beautiful Girl” subsequently won the Favorite Remake award in the 2011 MYX Music Awards. The success of the song’s revival is a testament to the enduring charm and mass appeal of the Original Pilipino Music ballad (Universal Records Philippines 2010, MYX Philippines 2011).  Written by Rosalie Matilac

Sources

 

Lo, Ricky. 2009. “20 Years with Constant Change.” Philstar. 12 Oct. http://www.philstar.com/entertainment/513097/20-years-constant-change.

MYX Philippines. 2011. “MYX Music Awards 2011 Winners.” Myx, 16 Mar. http://myxph.com/ features/1782/myx-musicawards-2011-winners/.

Universal Records Blog. 2010. “Christian Bautista’s ‘Beautiful Girl’ is #1 for the 5th Week on MYX.” Universal Records Philippines Fan Page. https://www.facebook.com/media/set/?set=a.10150167474995414.411249.214540185413.

text:
(Seeds of Freedom). Written 1960. Premiered 1962. Music, Eliseo M. Pajaro; lyrics, Ricardo Pascual. First performed on 30 Dec 1962 at the Far Eastern University Auditorium in line with the celebration of Jose Rizal’s birth centennial. Direction, Naty Crame Rogers; scenery design, Ernest Korneld; costumes, Andrea O. Veneracion; musical preparations, Basilisa Geronimo. Commissioned by the Jose Rizal National Centennial Commission (JRNCC). Cast: Aurelio Estanislao, Remedios Bosch-Jimenez, Conching Rosal, Don David, Jimmy Melendrez, Rodolfo Rivas, Vicente Antiporda, and Evelyn Mandac. Accompanied by the National Symphony Orchestra with Pajaro conducting.

The first Filipino modern opera in three acts, it is based on the life of Jose Rizal. Felipe Padilla de Leon notes that it presents the “entire gamut of the hero’s thoughts and aspirations from the time he was exiled to Dapitan, where amidst the valiant efforts of Pio Valenzuela he repeatedly refused to have a hand in an armed revolution, to the mock trial by the Spanish military tribunal, and finally to his calm acceptance of death by firing squad” (Roces 1977-78, Vol IX, 2343-44). The short prologue shows Rizal’s return to the Philippines in 1892. He has just published his second novel, El Filibusterismo (Subversion), the sequel to Noli Me Tangere (Touch Me Not), and has organized La Liga Filipina. Because of all these, he is exiled to Dapitan. The first act focuses on his life at Dapitan. The second act depicts his mock trial. The third act highlights his execution at Bagumbayan.

De Leon further comments that Pajaro’s “characteristic quartal and quintal harmonies and his melodic lines and sparse contrapuntal textures reflecting dodecaphonic musical trends in the West were suitably employed to match the intellectual tenor of the libretto,” and that, “his music was a break away from the traditional concepts of the Filipino opera.”

For the work, Pajaro received the Award of Merit in 1966. Pascual’s libretto won first prize in the contest sponsored by the JRNCC.  Written by Antonio C. Hila

Source

 

Roces, Alfredo R., ed. 1977-78. Filipino Heritage: The Making of a Nation, Vols 1-10. Manila: Lahing Pilipino Publishing Inc.

photos.desc:
“Bituing Marikit” on the cover of Literary Song

Movie Magazine, 1937 (Cesar Hernando Collection)

text:
(Beautiful Star). 1926. Music, Nicanor S. Abelardo; lyrics, Servando de los Angeles.

 

Abelardo composed the music for the Tagalog sarsuwela Dakilang Punglo (Noble Bullet). The three-act sarsuwela by Servando de los Angeles contained 17 songs, including “Bituing Marikit” which was drawn from the third act. De los Angeles’s lyrics for this song were inspired by and dedicated to the lady he married.

Abelardo, a romanticist, produced kundiman, balitaw, balse, and danza now considered immortal Filipino classics for their intense emotion and haunting beauty. Through his music, he elevated the popular folk forms to the level of art song, and used lyrics often infused with a genuine sense of nationalism. In the sweeping rhythm of the danza, “Bituing Marikit” portrays a passionate lover who likens the beloved to an unreachable star shining in the “night of life.” The lover begs to be thrown a ray of light, or be allowed to “drink” from the “pure stream” of love.

In this song, words and music are perfectly matched, flowing in an easy rhythm. Here is the opening stanza:

Bituing marikit sa gabi ng buhay

Ang bawat kislap mo’y ligaya ang taglay.

Yaring aking palad, iyong patnubayan

At kahit na sinag, iyong bahaginan.

(Beautiful star in the night of life

Your light brings happiness.

I beg you to guide my destiny

Spare me even a ray.)

In her lifetime, Atang de la Rama popularized this and other Abelardo songs. It was also used as the theme song for a movie of the same title, the very first film made by Sampaguita Pictures. Premiered in 1937, the musical starred Elsa Oria and Rogelio de la Rosa. The musical had a remake in 1957, with Amalia Fuentes and Juancho Gutierrez as the lead actors.

The song was recorded by sopranos Sylvia La Torre and Conching Rosal in their CD albums Kundiman and Immortal Kundiman of the Philippines, respectively. Raul Sunico arranged the song for two pianos and performed it in his CD album Alaala: Mga Awit ng Pag-ibig ni Nicanor S. Abelardo (Memories: Love Songs by Nicanor S. Abelardo), 2001. The song has become a staple of vocal recitals in the Philippines.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by James C. Diaz

I beg you to guide my destiny
Spare me even a ray.)

In her lifetime, Atang de la Rama popularized this and other Abelardo songs. It was also used as the theme song for a movie of the same title, the very first film made by Sampaguita Pictures. Premiered in 1937, the musical starred Elsa Oria and Rogelio de la Rosa. The musical had a remake in 1957, with Amalia Fuentes and Juancho Gutierrez as the lead actors.

The song was recorded by sopranos Sylvia La Torre and Conching Rosal in their CD albums Kundiman and Immortal Kundiman of the Philippines, respectively. Raul Sunico arranged the song for two pianos and performed it in his CD album Alaala: Mga Awit ng Pag-ibig ni Nicanor S. Abelardo (Memories: Love Songs by Nicanor S. Abelardo), 2001. The song has become a staple of vocal recitals in the Philippines.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by James C. Diaz

photos.desc:
Vinyl record cover of Sampaguita’s OPM Timeless Hits Vol. 5,

1977, which includes “Bonggahan” (Blackgold Records)

text:
(Razzle-dazzle). 1977. Music and lyrics, Gary Perez. First performed by Sampaguita.

 

The work in fast duple time became Sampaguita’s signature song in the 1970s, the decade of Pinoy rock. Sampaguita, who counts Mick Jagger and the Rolling Stones among her influences, was instantly tagged as the “Queen of Pinoy Rock” after recording this song. In a carefree, mannish voice, Sampaguita belts out the song, which calls for a rollicking good time sans drugs. The term “bonggahan” comes from the gay slang “bongga” which originally meant dazzling drag clothes. “Bonggahan,” which mixes English and Tagalog, now connotes flashiness in clothes, cars, and manner, or good, clean, happy fun in song and dance. The song uses colloquial gay lingo which became popular among showbiz artists especially after the 1970s. The first stanza runs:

Panahon na para magsaya

Forget mo na ang problema

Padance-dance para sumigla

Rock ‘n’ roll hanggang umaga.

Wa ka say na lang kumadre

Bow ka lang ng bow

Pa sing-sing ka lang

Para ikaw ay sumaya.

(It’s time to celebrate

Forget your problems

Dance to feel great

Rock ‘n’ roll till dawn.

Stop complaining, pal

Just ride on

Sing your heart out

And you’ll be fine.) Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes

photos.desc:
Scene from Tunay Na Ina, 1939, where Rosario Moreno
and Rudy Concepcion sing “Buhat”

(Photo courtesy of Excelsior Films)

text:
(Since Then). Circa 1939. Music, Mike Velarde Jr; lyrics, Dominador Santiago.

 

The song in moderate duple time was one of Mike Velarde Jr’s compositions for the movies. “Buhat” was sung by Rosario Moreno in a party scene in Tunay na Ina (True Mother), a movie produced by Excelsior Pictures in 1939. Its lyrics speak of the transformation in the persona’s life after meeting the beloved. A stanza of the song goes:

Buhat nang kita’y masilayan

Buhat nang mapanagimpan

Laging hinahanap at inaasam

Giliw, dinggin mo yaring pagmamahal.

(Since I saw you

Since I dreamt of you

I have always searched and longed for you

Darling, listen to this cry for love.)

In 1977, Rico J. Puno’s passionately quivering rendition made the song a smash hit. Although molded in the traditional style of a danza, the song exudes a sophistication and cosmopolitanism that overlies countrified sentiments. Velarde’s rich harmonic progressions steer the song from a solemn, meditative beginning in the minor mode to a heartfelt, sweeping declaration of instantaneous love in the major mode.

“Buhat” has also been arranged for choir and orchestra by Noel Velasco and Francis M. Dandan, among others. It was also arranged for soprano and tenor by Alfredo S. Buenaventura in 50 Immortal Filipino Duets, 1992. Ryan Cayabyab’s arrangement for the San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra is included in the CD album Great Filipino Love Songs, 2004.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by James C. Diaz

text:
1941. Music, Antonino Buenaventura.

 

A tone poem for orchestra, By the Hillside was awarded first prize for most original composition at the National Music Festival sponsored by the Baguio Music Festival in 1941. Although cited for successfully creating a distinct Filipino sound by means of exploring Philippine indigenous music traditions, Buenaventura’s work may still be largely described as a fusion of Western and local themes. On 12 Jun 1973, Independence Day, the work was played in Tel Aviv, Israel under the auspices of the Philippine Embassy. It was also performed at the Concert at the Park’s “All-Buenaventura” program in 1983 and at the numerous programs held on the occasion of the conferment of the title of National Artist in music on the composer in 1988.

By the Hillside is programmatic in form and essence. Inspired by Buenaventura’s sojourn at the Philippine Military Academy before World War II, the work conjures images of vast, green, rolling landscapes. The music is calm and unhurried, the pace easy, evoking a pastoral ambience.

The Manila Symphony Orchestra II performed this orchestral work in the My Dreams for My Children concert under the baton of Arturo Molina at Far Eastern University in 2010. The Orchestra Nipponica of Tokyo, Japan also performed it at the Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo of the Cultural Center of the Philippines in 2013. In the same year, the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, with Ruggero Barbieri conducting, recorded the symphonic poem for the album PPO Plays Triple B: Brahms, Buenaventura, Bizet. The latest performance of the work was at the Manila Symphony Orchestra II’s Pastorale: Music by Buenaventura and Beethoven, conducted by Arturo Molina, at the CCP’s Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo in 2014.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by Crisancti L. Macazo

text:
1921. Music, Nicanor S. Abelardo.

Cavatina, from the Italian word cavata (which means to produce sound from an instrument) is a short lyrical instrumental piece. This ternary and triple-meter composition for violin and piano marked moderato tranquillo was composed to fulfill the requirements for a Teacher’s Certificate in Science and Composition from the University of the Philippines (UP).

The first section is in D major. The key shifts to B minor (the relative minor) in the middle section. It returns to the original key in the final section with heightened expressiveness in a higher register, completing the ternary design. The melodious violin part and its harmonically rich piano accompaniment has become a vital part of notable Philippine violin and cello repertoire. Violinists Joseph Esmilla, Regina Buenaventura, and cellist Renato Lucas have recordings of the piece. The piece was transcribed for orchestra by Redentor L. Romero, who conducted and recorded it with the London Royal Philharmonic Orchestra in 1978. An arrangement for violin solo and orchestral accompaniment was accomplished by Antonino Buenaventura, whose score was donated to the UP College of Music Library in 1982.  Written by Jeanna B. Malabuyoc, updated by Mauricia D. Borromeo

photos.desc:
Album cover of Jose Mari Chan’s Christmas in Our Hearts, 1990

(Universal Records)

text:
1990. Music, Jose Mari Chan. Lyrics, Rina Cañiza. Sung by Jose Mari Chan and Liza Chan. Universal Records.

 

The song is the track single for the bestselling album in Original Philippine Music (OPM) history, Jose Mari Chan’s Christmas in Our Hearts. The album was given Double Diamond status in 2006, the only album to be thus awarded by the Philippine Association of the Record Industry (PARI). According to Universal Records, which distributed the album, this meant a sale of more than 600,000 copies as of December that year.

Initially written as a jubilee song for the 1963 batch of Assumption High School, the song was originally titled “Ang Tubig ay Buhay” (Water is Life) based on a poem by Chari Cruz-Zarate. Because it was the catchiest melody he had ever written, Chan decided to use it in his first Christmas album, this time with the lyrics by Rina Cañiza.

The song features a duet between Chan and his daughter, Elizabeth (aka Liza), celebrating the simple joys of a Filipino Christmas. The simple melody, punctuated by the pealing of church bells and chimes in the background, conveys the essence of Christmas as a reminder of the birth of the child Jesus in the manger. The song enjoins the listener to find childlike joy in the simple activities that bind families and larger communities together in a season of giving and receiving in the spirit of humility and love.

Chan’s cool, light vocal timbre blends well with his daughter’s untrained yet smooth voice. The mass appeal can be explained by the flowing, symmetrically “rhyming” melodic lines that fall within Chan’s vocal range. The singability of the vocal range partially accounts for its ubiquitous inclusion in children’s caroling repertoires and school Christmas programs.  Written by Lara Katrina T. Mendoza

Source

 

Universal Records Blog. 2009. “Jose Mari Chan’s ‘Christmas In Our Hearts’: The Best-Selling OPM Christmas Album Of All Time!” Universal Records. 20 Nov. http://universalrecph.blogspot.com/2009/11/jose-mari-chans-christmas-in-ourhearts.html.
