photos.desc:
Excerpt from the Cohen transcription

with dissonances in piano and guitar lines

Illustration of Tagalog couple on horses which appeared
in the same book as “Comintang de la Conquista”

(Les Philippines: by Jean Mallat. A. Bertrand, 1846.)

text:
(Comintang of the Conquest). Circa 1846. Music and lyrics, anonymous.

 

“Comintang de la Conquista” is the title of a musical transcription inserted into the atlas of the travelogue Les Philippines, 1846, by the French adventurer Jean Baptiste Mallat. The transcription consists of three parts—voice, guitar, and piano, respectively—and is attributed to Henry Cohen, a 19th century French numismatist, bibliographer, and composer. Three stanzas of poorly transcribed Tagalog text, describing a suitor bemoaning his unrequited love, are also included in the insert. The first stanza goes:

Sinor a un Caya sa sandaigdigan

Ang may dusa nitong aguing cahirapan.

Di mo na nilingot pina lungai lungai

Pagsinta sa iyong valang calilohan.

(Who in the world

Experiences the suffering and difficulties I have gone

through.

You do not turn to look at me and avoid my gaze

Even as I offer my faithful love for you. )

The Cohen transcription was later reprinted in toto in John Bowring’s travelogue, A Visit to the Philippines, 1859. The publisher of Mallat’s book or perhaps Cohen himself incorrectly represented comintang by conflating the guitar and piano accompaniments into a music system so that dissonance from the simultaneous sounding of pitches A and B-flat occurs (see Fig. 1 below). The rhythm of the guitar is, however, nearer the correct representation, but the piano is not because the latter is in common classical style harmonic progression.

What might have been a publication error became a subject of later commentaries. The Cohen transcription finds itself the subject of comments made by Filipinist scholar Epifanio de los Santos (1871-1928) in Wenceslao Retana’s edition of Tomas Morga’s Sucesos de las Islas Filipinas (Events in the Philippine Islands) [Madrid, 1909]. De los Santos, who was also considered one of the finest guitarists in Manila at the time, notes that a portion of the score (measures 24-28) does not conform to his experience of comintang performance. As noted above, de los Santos referred to the dissonant section caused by the piano part as “son de factura moderna” (they are a modern creation).

The musical score of comintang in Mallat’s book is valuable because it is the earliest extant transcription of the traditional comintang. Walls y Merino referred to it in La Musica Popular de Filipinas (Popular Music in the Philippines), 1892, as the canto nacional (national song) of the Tagalog, a comment reflecting its popularity at the time. Except for the piano part and the measures cited by de los Santos, “Comintang de la Conquista” displays the common features of the awit song-and-dance form, also associated with many Tagalog groups, namely: 1) the presence of two distinct and loosely connected lines—vocal and instrumental; 2) the use of the plosa verse form (dodecasyllabic, monorhyming quatrains); and 3) the presence of a loose, flexible ostinato-like instrumental line.

The Cohen transcription and three other extant transcriptions of 19th century comintang (one by Manuel Walls y Merino in 1892 and two by Epifanio de los Santos in 1895), plus late 20th century transcriptions of an awit from Batangas province in the Southern Tagalog region by Rivera Mirano, 1997, allow us to conclude that the comintang or kumintang, as it is rendered in modern orthography, is a type of awit. One can further surmise that the name comintang might refer to a local style of awit singing and dancing that is associated with the Batangas province, since this area was often referred to in the early centuries of Spanish colonization as “la region de comintang.”  Written by Elena Rivera Mirano, with notes by Jose S. Buenconsejo

Sources

 

Bowring, John. 1859. A Visit to the Philippine Islands. London: Smith, Elder & Co.

De los Santos, Epifanio. 1916. “Balagtas y Su Florante, Literature Tagala 1593- 1886.” Philippine Review (Aug): 36-64.

De Morga, Antonio. 1910. Sucesos de las Islas Filipinas. Annotated edition by Wenceslao Retana, Madrid.

Mallat, Jean Baptiste. 1846. Les Philippines; Historie, Geographie, Moeurs, Agriculture, Industrie et Commerce des Colonies Espagnoles dans l’Oceanie. Paris: Tomo Premier.

Perez, Diego. 1900. Recuerdos de Filipinas y Sus Cantares, Gran Potpurri para Piano. Madrid: Biblioteca Nacional de EspanÌƒa. Manuscript in the collection of Felipe de Leon Jr.

Rivera Mirano, Elena. 1997. Ang Mga Tradisyonal na Musikang Pantinig sa Lumang Bauan, Batangas. Manila: National Commission for Culture and the Arts.

Scherzer, Karl. 1861. Reise der oÌˆsterreichischen Fregatte Novara um die Erde in den Jahren 1857, 1858, 1859 unter den Befehlen des Commodore B. von WuÌˆllerstorf-Urbair, Vol 2. Vienna: Court and State Printer.

Walls y Merino, Manuel M. 1892. La Musica Popular de Filipinas. Madrid: Libreria de Fernando Fe.

article_title: Concerto for Piano and Orchestra in B-flat Minor, OP. 12

photos.desc:
Pianist Jourdan Petalver and the UP College of Music Centennial Festival Orchestra performing

Concerto for Piano and Orchestra in B Minor with Josefino Toledo as conductor, 2015 (Photo courtesy of The Laureate Concert Group)

text:
1923. Music, Nicanor S. Abelardo. First performed on Sep 1923.

 

The first Philippine concerto, it was played at the first concert that featured local composers, namely, Tereso Zapata, Cayetano Jacobe, and Juan S. Hernandez. The work unfolds in three movements: Allegro moderato misterioso, Andante romantico, and Rondo or Allegro fantastico with orchestra.

Abelardo composed the piece in fulfilment of the requirements for a Teacher’s Certificate in Musical Science and Composition at the University of the Philippines (UP). Conceived in the romantic style of pianism that demanded a full range of artistry from the performer, the original melodies as thematic material in each movement were positively infused with Philippine folk melodies.

It was performed at the Abelardo Centennial Concert of the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, with Josefino Toledo as conductor and Manuel P. Maramba, OSB as soloist, on 12-13 Feb 1993 at the Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). Another centennial performance was conducted by Regalado Jose, with Nita Abrogar Quinto, soloist. Quinto was also the soloist of the UP Symphony Orchestra concert at the UP Abelardo Hall Auditorium with Edna M. Martinez, conductor. Other performances on record with the collaboration of the same conductor and orchestra anticipated the 91st anniversary of the UP College of Music with UP alumnus Regalado Jose, soloist, on Feb 2007, at the Francisco Santiago Hall, and on 20 Mar 2007, at the UP Abelardo Hall Auditorium.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by Mauricia D. Borromeo

article.value: 1923. Music, Nicanor S. Abelardo. First performed on Sep 1923.

Pianist Jourdan Petalver and the UP College of Music Centennial Festival Orchestra performing

Concerto for Piano and Orchestra in B Minor with Josefino Toledo as conductor, 2015 (Photo courtesy of The Laureate Concert Group)

Abelardo composed the piece in fulfilment of the requirements for a Teacher’s Certificate in Musical Science and Composition at the University of the Philippines (UP). Conceived in the romantic style of pianism that demanded a full range of artistry from the performer, the original melodies as thematic material in each movement were positively infused with Philippine folk melodies.

It was performed at the Abelardo Centennial Concert of the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, with Josefino Toledo as conductor and Manuel P. Maramba, OSB as soloist, on 12-13 Feb 1993 at the Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). Another centennial performance was conducted by Regalado Jose, with Nita Abrogar Quinto, soloist. Quinto was also the soloist of the UP Symphony Orchestra concert at the UP Abelardo Hall Auditorium with Edna M. Martinez, conductor. Other performances on record with the collaboration of the same conductor and orchestra anticipated the 91st anniversary of the UP College of Music with UP alumnus Regalado Jose, soloist, on Feb 2007, at the Francisco Santiago Hall, and on 20 Mar 2007, at the UP Abelardo Hall Auditorium.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by Mauricia D. Borromeo

article_title: Concerto No. 1 for Violin and Orchestra
text:
1960. Music, Eliseo M. Pajaro. First performed by the UP Symphony Orchestra on 12 Mar 1964 at the University Theater of the University of the Philippines (UP), with soloist Divinagracia Montalban, conducted by Luis Valencia. Commissioned by the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines.

Pajaro wrote this work while he was composing the music for the three-act opera Binhi ng Kalayaan (Seeds of Freedom). The concerto won for Pajaro his first Republic Cultural Heritage Award in 1964.

The first movement, “Allegro moderato,” is in traditional sonata form. The second movement, “Andante espressivo,” marked by its masterly treatment of musical ideas, showcases an irregular rondo with a principal and three subordinate themes, each appearing in reverse order. The third movement, “Allegro moderato,” is a series of eight variations on a theme, which makes its last appearance before the final variation.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes

text:
1989. Record album composed, performed, and produced by Jose Mari Chan. Released by Wea (now Universal) Records.

 

The album displays Chan’s mastery of the techniques of ballad composition as he reveals his personal views about the different types and phases of love. The song texts deal with the impermanence of life (“Constant Change,” sung by Chan); the fear that accompanies first love (“Please Be Careful with My Heart,” sung by Chan and Regine Velasquez); a daughter’s expression of love for her father (“Sing Me Your Song Again, Daddy,” sung by Cherie Gil); a man and a woman’s reaffirmation of their love (“My Girl, My Woman, My Friend,” sung by Chan and Janet Basco); and a man’s admiration for an elusive woman (“Beautiful Girl,” sung by Chan). The last song was the biggest hit in the collection and became the title of a Seiko Films-produced movie. Chan also set the poem “I Have Fallen in Love (With the Same Woman Three Times),” by Benigno S. Aquino Jr and dedicated to his wife Corazon C. Aquino, to music in the album.

Constant Change has the distinction of being the only album produced and performed by a Filipino to be accorded a Diamond Award (equivalent of 10 platinum awards or 400,000 units sold), the highest award in the local music industry in terms of record sales during the early 1990s. Constant Change was also a commercial success in other Southeast Asian countries.  Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian

photos.desc:
Movie poster of Dahil Sa Isang Bulaklak, 1966

(Photo courtesy of Simon Santos/Video 48)

text:
(Because of a Flower). 1966. Music, Leopoldo Silos; lyrics, Serapio Ramos.

 

The music was written in 1966 for the motion picture Dahil sa Isang Bulaklak, a Filipino film shot in color, directed by Luis Nepomuceno and starring Charito Solis and Ric Rodrigo, and released in 1967. The song version was popularized in a 1968 recording by the singer Ric Manrique Jr. It was first performed on the concert stage along with other Silos compositions “Ang Pagkakasala’y Di Akin” (The Sin is Not Mine), “Ang Langit sa Lupa” (Heaven on Earth), and “Nasa sa Iyo” (It Depends On You) by baritone Aurelio Estanislao on 22 Mar 1972 at the Philamlife Auditorium, Manila on the occasion of Liederabend (Evening of Songs) sponsored by the Women’s Auxiliary of the University of the Philippines (UP) Health Service. The concert elevated the music from the Philippine cinema to the art song category and made these popular songs a part of the standard repertoire for professionally trained singers.

The music is set in moderate duple time. The piano version originally recorded by the composer in 1966 features a sentimental melody undergirded by a lush, arpeggiated accompaniment. The lyrics provided by Serapio Ramos celebrate the joys and sorrows of romantic love:

Puso’y sadyang nagtiis

Nagdusa sa pag-ibig.

Di magbabago kailanman

Ang pagmamahal.

‘Yan ang pag-ibig

Dahil sa isang bulaklak.

(The heart endured,

Suffering in the name of love.

This love

Will never change.

That’s what love has become

Because of a flower.)

“Dahil sa Isang Bulaklak” became a part of the choral repertoire in the 1970s after Fabian V. Obispo wrote an a capella arrangement of the song for the UP Madrigal Singers, that became one of their signature songs.  Written by Antonio C. Hila

text:
(Because of You). 1937. Music, Mike Velarde Jr; lyrics, Dominador Santiago.

 

Velarde’s composition, which is in slow duple time, has been described as “urbane as well as urban… the slick verses masking provincial nostalgia.” It is typically the music of the Big City of the 1930s with a sophistication and a lightness of sound that is still filled with the romanticism of the rustic Filipino lover. From its popularity with the Filipino movie crowd of the 1930s, the song enjoyed a revival in the 1960s when it evolved into a classic art song with the interpretation of Aurelio Estanislao. His interpretation influenced virtually all student singers of that time. The song gained popularity abroad as it was performed and recorded by renowned international artists Nat King Cole, Julio Iglesias, and the Lettermen. Tadao Hayashi, Japanese harpist, arranged it for the harp and as recently as 2008, Charlie Green, finalist of British Got Talent, performed the song. A choral arrangement for mixed chorus by Fabian V. Obispo for the UP Madrigal Singers was the version used by many foreign choirs. The National Taiwan University Choir performed the song in 2009. Teresita Z. Ruutu, head of the Eiku Finnish choir, and Teresita G. Marques, choirmaster of the Portugues Europ Cantat group, have adapted and performed this song internationally. It was also recorded by the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra for their album Pintig (Beat).

During the Marcos administration, the song was a favorite of the former First Lady Imelda Romualdez Marcos, and she has been known to sing it at social functions, so much that it is associated with her and is sometimes known as the “Imelda song.” In the 1970s, the song was performed by many pop singers, such as Ric Manrique and Didith Reyes. In 1981 Ryan Cayabyab made a jazz choral arrangement for his album titled One. In 1992, Redentor L. Romero arranged the song for two voices in 50 Immortal Filipino Duets, published by the National Philharmonic Society of the Philippines. In 1996, he transcribed the song for the orchestra and performed it with the Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra as the conductor. The song is included in his CD album Damdaming Pinoy (Filipino Feelings), recorded in Moscow, Russia.

Written by Velarde for the movie Bituing Marikit (Beautiful Star), which starred Rogelio de la Rosa and Elsa Oria in 1937, “Dahil Sa Iyo” has been translated into English, Spanish, Japanese, Chinese, and several Philippine languages. For local audiences interested in pop music, the rendition by Pilita Corrales has been the most acclaimed.  Written by Felicidad Zafra Reyes, updated by James C. Diaz

text:
(Philippine Maiden). Date of composition unknown. Music, Jose Santos; lyrics, Jose Corazon de Jesus. Recorded by Ruben Tagalog for Villar Records.

 

This is a popular song in the fast triple time that is characteristic of the balitaw. It was published in the Philippine Progressive Music Series: Advanced Course and thus was sung in schools nationwide. The text extols the qualities of a traditional Filipina maiden—mayumi (gentle), mahinhin (demure), maganda (beautiful)—a flower both exquisitely beautiful and fragrant. Its opening lyrics are:

Ang dalagang Pilipina

Parang tala sa umaga.

Kung tanawin ay nakaliligaya,

May ningning na tangi

At dakilang ganda.

(The Philippine maiden

Is like a morning star.

Such a delight to see,

With a distinct gleam

And noble beauty.)

Cast in typical balitaw structure, it is in binary form with the first part in the minor key and the second in the parallel major key.

Alfredo S. Buenaventura has an arrangement of the song for soprano and tenor in 50 Immortal Filipino Duets, published by the National Philharmonic Society of the Philippines in 1992. The song was also used for a ballet, Ballet & Ballads, choreographed by Tony Fabella, and performed by Ballet Manila at the Aliw Theater in 2013.

In 4 Sep 2015, “Dalagang Pilipina” was performed by the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO) in a concert titled Serenata (Serenade) at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo. The concert, which was done in celebration of CCP’s 46th anniversary, featured Filipino folk songs with musical arrangements by Ryan Cayabyab. The song, perfomed by the PPO is included in the special collector’s CD Serenata: Well-Loved Philippine Folk Songs and Melodies.  Written by Corazon C. Dioquino, updated by James C. Diaz

photos.desc: Publicity still from Dandansoy, 1965 (Photo courtesy of Simon Santos/Video 48)

text:
(Unfaithful). This traditional Visayan folk song from Kulasi, Antique, is cast in slow triple time like the kundiman. It is set in a minor key, reinforcing the deep sadness of unrequited love. A shift to the major key in the middle heightens the feeling of hope for a probable change of heart. “Dandansoy” is derived from Dansoy, the name of the unfaithful lover to whom the song is addressed.

 

The text has four stanzas of four lines each. The number of syllables for the lines are alternately 9-8-9-8 or 8-9-8-9. The song’s four musical phrases coincide with each line of the text and make up two periods of eight measures each. The first half of each period ends on the subdominant, the second half on the tonic. The melodic contour is characterized by large leaps, moving in triadic intervals.

The song has been performed by a number of well known pop singers and groups from the 1970s until the 2000s. Nora Aunor, Asin, the Mabuhay Singers, and Grace Nono, have included the song in their albums.

Many choral groups include arrangements of this folk song in their repertoire. Lucrecia R. Kasilag includes it in her choral work for women’s voices, Five Philippine Folk Songs, where the tune is quoted in its entirety with minor changes but given a treatment utilizing such devices as modal harmony, parallel fourths and fifths, and contrapuntal countermelodies. She also has an arrangement for soprano with piano accompaniment. This was performed by Josephine Roces in her CD album El Alma Filipina (The Filipino Soul), 1998.

In 1991, the community of the Hacienda Santa Catalina-Tuburan in Talisay, Negros Occidental produced and acted in a sarsuwela bearing the same title. Taking off from the song, director Ricardo Silverio and librettist Msgr Manuel Dormido put together popular Visayan songs for the two-act musical, which focused on the separation and eventual reconciliation of Dandansoy, a hacienda worker who gambles and drinks, and his long-suffering wife, Rosing.

The song has been arranged and re-arranged a number of times in recent years. Fidel Calalang Jr’s choral arrangement was performed by the UST Singers in 2008; and Nilo Alcala’s arrangement for baritone with piano accompaniment was performed by John Panganiban with pianist Rudolf Golez at the Mikhail Glinka Auditorium, in Moscow, Russia, 2013.  Written by Corazon C. Dioquino, updated by James C. Diaz

text:
(You Never Learn). 1985. Music and lyrics, Danny Javier. First sung by Gary Valenciano in May 1985 at his concert Gary V: Can’t Stop at the Folk Arts Theater (now Tanghalang Francisco Balagtas). Recorded by Valenciano under Wea (now Universal) Records.

 

The song is in slow duple time. The text expresses the conflict between the lover’s desire to be free of a hurtful relationship and his or her inability to resist the beloved who is the cause of that heartache. The song then becomes a promise of undying love by a person so blinded by love that he or she is willing to be wounded again.

Riding on the popularity of the song upon its release in 1985, the Puerto Rican boy band, Menudo, sang it in their Philippine concert tours in the late 1980s. “Di Na Natuto” was arranged for orchestra and played by the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra in their album Pintig (Beat). The song has been revived and is included in Noel Cabangon’s album “Byahe” (Journey), released by Universal Records in 2009.  Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

photos.desc:
Ang Sultan, choreographed to Divertissement for Piano and Orchestra, Philippine Ballet Theatre, CCP, Manila, 2008
(Ador G. Pamintuan)

text:
1960. Music, Lucrecia R. Kasilag. Commissioned by the League of Filipino Composers for its Music Festival. First performed by Milagros de Ocampo and the Manila Symphony Orchestra conducted by Bernardino F. Custodio.

 

Full orchestration for this two-piano modern concerto employs southern Philippine instruments: kulintang, agong, babandil, dabakan, and gandingan. Kasilag chose to call the work a divertissement despite its form.

The first movement uses the rhythm of the bamboo poles in the Muslim dance, singkil, in the style of a ground-bass. It is also called the “Allegro in white,” as it uses only the white keys of the piano. The second movement is slower and cast in a simple variation form; the theme is based on a nine-measure Muslim chant called dende-o-dende. The movement is veiled in oriental mysticism with an underlying syncopated ostinato background. The final movement is a rondo of heightening excitement and is achieved with the use of a triple rhythm set against a duple rhythm.

The piece is often performed and figures prominently in all of Kasilag’s concerts, whether locally or abroad. Pianist Zenas Lozada, who often performed the work with orchestra, recalls that it was featured in Hong Kong with Luis Valencia conducting, as well as in Taipei, at this time with the composer conducting. Divertissement was likewise featured in a special concert at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) in 1998 to celebrate Kasilag’s 80th birthday.

In 1973, choreographer Gener Caringal used this composition for his folkloric ballet Ang Sultan (The Sultan) produced by the CCP Dance Workshop Company (now Ballet Philippines).  Written by Edna Marcil M. Martinez, updated by Mauricia D. Borromeo

text:
Circa 1921. Music, Nicanor S. Abelardo. Published by Sixta N. Abelardo after World War II.

 

A genre for solo piano, the nocturne (French: nocturne, German: nachstucke, and Italian: notturno) is a piece of night music and aims to evoke a tranquil and reflective nocturnal mood. The distinctive features of the genre are first exemplified in the 18 nocturnes of the Irish pianist-composer John Field: 1) right hand melody with optional upper register figurations; 2) left hand accompaniment following a planned sequence of arpeggiated chords; and 3) the conventional ABA form. The artistic performance of these nocturnes was contingent on an understanding of the idiomatic and expressive capabilities of the “modern” piano, notably the effects of the sustaining pedal. Field’s nocturnes paved the way for subjective and dramatic emotionalism of subsequent nocturnes which reached an apex in the musical poetry of Frederic Chopin.

Although listed among Nicanor S. Abelardo’s 19 compositions in 1921, its exclusion from the formidable repertoire of his composition graduation recital on 11 Feb 1921 has generated a question on the specific month and date of the First Nocturne. In 1931, barely two months after Abelardo’s admission to the master’s degree program in composition in the Chicago Musical College, the then pianist-director Rudolf Ganz, impressed with the performance of the violin sonata by this new student from the Philippines in the composition class of Dr La Violette, chose First Nocturne for his repertoire class on interpretation.

First Nocturne reveals the impact of tutelage by local and foreign based artist-pedagogues on Abelardo’s creative musical gifts that were manifested in early childhood and which blossomed through the years. By 1921, at age 28, Abelardo created a piece where the characteristics of the nocturne as established by Field can be identified, i.e., a song-like melody (right hand) with arpeggiated chordal accompaniment (left hand), and return of the first section after a contrasting section (ABA). From hereon, Abelardo departed from this structural convention. In the return of the first section (A), the melody is restated but within a brief contrapuntal texture. The B section is also restated but in another surprising tonality of D-flat major (B-flat major tonality was used in the first statement), again featuring the creative expansions of the B section melody with right hand octaves and a chromaticism of the left hand accompaniment that enhances the increasing dramatic intensity of the song-like melody. Appropriate symbols for expressive performance levels are also indicated in the whole piece. A sudden but smooth return to the initial C-sharp minor tonality signals the start of a coda. A brief statement of the initial melody leads to an ad libitum chromatic cadenza with both hands, a performance practice in concert piano pieces of the Romantic period. Then, a right hand trill two octaves above the first note (C-sharp) of the initial melody in Section A, leads to the C-sharp minor chord, re-establishing the tonality of the piece with tranquil finality.  Written by Mauricia D. Borromeo

Sources

 

Epistola, Ernesto. 1996. Nicanor Abelardo: The Man and the Artist, a Biography. Manila: Rex Bookstore.

Manuel, E. Arsenio. 1955-86. Dictionary of Philippine Biography. Quezon City: Filipiniana Publications.

Randel, Don Michael. 1986. The New Harvard Dictionary of Music. Massachusetts: Harvard University Press.

article.value: Circa 1921. Music, Nicanor S. Abelardo. Published by Sixta N. Abelardo after World War II.

A genre for solo piano, the nocturne (French: nocturne, German: nachstucke, and Italian: notturno) is a piece of night music and aims to evoke a tranquil and reflective nocturnal mood. The distinctive features of the genre are first exemplified in the 18 nocturnes of the Irish pianist-composer John Field: 1) right hand melody with optional upper register figurations; 2) left hand accompaniment following a planned sequence of arpeggiated chords; and 3) the conventional ABA form. The artistic performance of these nocturnes was contingent on an understanding of the idiomatic and expressive capabilities of the “modern” piano, notably the effects of the sustaining pedal. Field’s nocturnes paved the way for subjective and dramatic emotionalism of subsequent nocturnes which reached an apex in the musical poetry of Frederic Chopin.

Although listed among Nicanor S. Abelardo’s 19 compositions in 1921, its exclusion from the formidable repertoire of his composition graduation recital on 11 Feb 1921 has generated a question on the specific month and date of the First Nocturne. In 1931, barely two months after Abelardo’s admission to the master’s degree program in composition in the Chicago Musical College, the then pianist-director Rudolf Ganz, impressed with the performance of the violin sonata by this new student from the Philippines in the composition class of Dr La Violette, chose First Nocturne for his repertoire class on interpretation.

First Nocturne reveals the impact of tutelage by local and foreign based artist-pedagogues on Abelardo’s creative musical gifts that were manifested in early childhood and which blossomed through the years. By 1921, at age 28, Abelardo created a piece where the characteristics of the nocturne as established by Field can be identified, i.e., a song-like melody (right hand) with arpeggiated chordal accompaniment (left hand), and return of the first section after a contrasting section (ABA). From hereon, Abelardo departed from this structural convention. In the return of the first section (A), the melody is restated but within a brief contrapuntal texture. The B section is also restated but in another surprising tonality of D-flat major (B-flat major tonality was used in the first statement), again featuring the creative expansions of the B section melody with right hand octaves and a chromaticism of the left hand accompaniment that enhances the increasing dramatic intensity of the song-like melody. Appropriate symbols for expressive performance levels are also indicated in the whole piece. A sudden but smooth return to the initial C-sharp minor tonality signals the start of a coda. A brief statement of the initial melody leads to an ad libitum chromatic cadenza with both hands, a performance practice in concert piano pieces of the Romantic period. Then, a right hand trill two octaves above the first note (C-sharp) of the initial melody in Section A, leads to the C-sharp minor chord, re-establishing the tonality of the piece with tranquil finality.  Written by Mauricia D. Borromeo

photos.desc:
Sheet music cover of “La Flor de Manila”

(CCP Collection)

text:
(The Flower of Manila). Circa 1879. Music attributed by Norberto Romualdez to Dolores Paterno; lyrics, Pedro Paterno. In 1880, Pedro Paterno published a book of poems titled Sampaguitas.

 

The composition is a three-part piece, which was written for soprano in the slow duple time of the danza. A facsimile of the 1880 print of the song is in the key of D major. This was reprinted in 1950 with lyrics in Spanish. Another print dated 1964, in the key of A major, was copied by Johnny Benasa, with lyrics in both Tagalog and English, the latter made by Abbie Farwell Brown. In addition, the melody of the piece was quoted in Ladislao Bonus’s 1902 opera of Sangdugong Panaguinip (Dreamed Alliance), which had Pedro Paterno as librettist. Norberto Romualdez reprinted the 1880 piece (in D major) in the public school music textbook The Philippine Progressive Music Series: Advanced Course, published in New York, Chicago, and San Francisco, by the Silver Burdette Company, between 1915 and 1950.

The opening stanzas of the original text run:

Sampaguita gentil que halagas

Con tu aroma a mi Filipina

Sampaguita flor peregrina

Que sus trenzas bordando estas.

Tu que en breve collar prendida

Dulce besas su ardiente seno

Quien pudiera de amores lleno,

Flor venturosa, cual tu gozar.

(Lovely bloom of the Sampaguita

By my Philippine maid beloved

Not a flower in the world is sweeter

As you circle her lovely brow.

In the daintiest collar encircling

With one bud like a pendant clinging

Round the neck of the gentle and beautiful one

How happy and fortunate now.)

One of the more outstanding songs that emerged during the Spanish colonial period, it is more popularly known as “Sampaguita.” Relatives of Dolores said that one moonlit night, Dolores Paterno, in a fit of restlessness and inspiration, and fascinated by a poem her mother had told her about the sampaguita, went to the piano and composed the familiar tune, the lyrics of which finds a parallel between the pristine flower and the unblemished virtue of Filipina maidenhood (Romualdez 1915, 291). The song is popular because of its wide circulation in print, and it became even more popular when the sampaguita was acknowledged the national flower in the early American period.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by Jose S. Buenconsejo

Source

Romualdez, Norberto, comp. 1950. Philippine Progressive Music Series: Advanced Course. New York: Silver, Burdette and Company.

photos.desc: Album cover of Side A’s Side A 25: A Silver Anniversary Collector’s Edition, 2011, which includes “Forevermore” (Warner Music)

text:
1995. Music and lyrics, Joey Benin. First performed by Side A featuring Joey Generoso on lead vocals and guitar, Naldy Gonzales on keyboards, Ernie Severino on drums, and Joey Benin on bass. The song appeared in Side A’s album By Your Side, 1995, and in Side A Live! The 10th Anniversary Concert, 1996, both of which were released by Warner Music Philippines.

 

The song, in E major, is set to a simple and symmetrical verse-chorus form consisting of eight bars of verse, four bars of transition, and eight-bars of chorus. After two repeats of the verse-chorus, the song goes to a bridge that is unprepared harmonically in C major. This effectively evokes the image of changes in time. But this brief modulation reverts back to E major, which affirms the realization of once-a-dream-but-now-real love that the whole song is about.

Endearing itself to millions of Filipinos both in the Philippines and abroad, the song became popular because it is a sincere expression of romantic sentiment made palpable by Generoso’s tender and breathy voice. His vocals soar in the chorus, where there is an affirmation of true love, a confession of desire, and a longing for the past in the verses.

In 1996, the song was released as a single that became a commercial hit. The song thereafter was included in a number of Side A’s compilations and anthologies in the 2000s. The song was covered by Juris Fernandez for her album of the same title released in 2011 by Star Records. American Idol runner-up David Archuleta also performed the song for his 2012 album of the same title under Ivory Music and Video. “Forevermore” also became the title and theme song of a primetime television series produced by ABS-CBN in 2014, starring the popular love team of Enrique Gil and Liza Soberano.

The recorded single won Song of the Year in the 1996 Awit Awards in 1996, with Side A also bagging the award for Best Performance by a Duo or Group.  Written by Jose S. Buenconsejo

text:
(How Much Do I Love You). 1979. Music, Ernani Cuenco; lyrics, Levi Celerio. First recorded by Ric Manrique under the Cuenco-Manrique-Celerio or CMC label. Recorded by Celeste Legaspi under Blackgold Records.

 

First performed as a duet by sopranos Conching Rosal and Evelyn Mandac in a recital held at the Cultural Center of the Philippines, “Gaano Ko Ikaw Kamahal” was also used as movie theme for a Lito Lapid starrer of the same title in the 1980s which won one Gawad Urian for best musical direction, as well as three FAMAS (Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences) awards.

Often called by other titles such as “Ikaw Lamang” (Only You) and “Ang Aking Buhay” (My Life)—words taken from the songtext—“Gaano Ko Ikaw Kamahal” speaks of a genuine and undying love and loyalty. It is set in moderate duple time. Opening with a majestic introduction marked fortissimo, the chordal buildup tapers to a gentle hush as the song proper begins. Cuenco’s style calls for a full, luxuriant sound punctuated by a high soprano obligato leading to a climactic finish.

The song remains a favorite at weddings and other feasts. It is considered a true Filipino classic for having left its mark on local movie music, and on the Filipino music world in general. It was arranged for a mixed choir in the 1970s by Reynaldo Lauron. The said arrangement was popularized by the UP Concert Chorus. An arrangement for two pianos by Cuenco was performed by duo pianists Anna Maria de Guzman and Della Besa in 1980. The song was arranged for two voices by Lucio D. San Pedro and is included in 50 Immortal Filipino Duets, published by the National Philharmonic Society of the Philippines in 1992. Redentor L. Romero arranged the song for orchestra and performed it with the Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra as the conductor. The work is included in his CD album Damdaming Pinoy (Filipino Feelings), recorded in Moscow, Russia in 1996. Ryan Cayabyab also arranged the song for orchestra. The song is included in Tribute to Ernani Cuenco, a CD album he produced in 2000, with the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra.

On 11 Aug 2014, Della Besa and Anna Maria de Guzman again performed the song on two pianos, at their duo-piano concert titled Music Circle, at the Saint Cecilia’s Building Board Room, Saint Scholastica’s College Manila.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by James C. Diaz

photos.desc: Gabaq-an performed by the UST Singers, 2013 (UST Singers Collection)

text:
1979. Music, Ruben R. Federizon. Lyrics, Cynthia Zayas. First performed by the UP Madrigal Singers in 1979.

 

Ruben R. Federizon composed Gabaq-an in 1979 as a requirement for his membership in the League of Filipino Composers. The title refers to the word abang-ga, which is borrowed from the French word avant-garde. The piece is based on a text supplied by then anthropology student, Cynthia Zayas, Federizon’s co-worker at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music Asian Music Department headed by Jose Maceda. The text is a prayer uttered by the babaylan, a religious leader, after a calamity. In the work, Federizon specifies that the prayer is not the usual petition for a favor but one that asks God for an explanation. The appropriated text is not specific to an ethnolinguistic group nor does it depict a particular calamity.

Originally, Gabaq-an was scored for choir and orchestra and was premiered by the UP Madrigal Singers under its director Andrea O. Veneracion in 1979. After its performance, Veneracion suggested that it be revised for her choir. After that, the UP Madrigal Singers performed the work several times. In 2010, the UST Singers included it in their program in the Llangolen International Musical Eisteddfod in Wales, United Kingdom.

The piece starts with the female sections of the choir intoning six layers of sounds sung pianissimo. Each layer is not sung separately but collectively (i.e., heard as if only one layer). Then the solo baritone intones a prayerful chant, which is rendered in a raw, earthy voice. This chant is not traditional to a particular group but is actually composed. The use of finger bells reinforces the chant. The male section of the choir continues the prayer with new melodic material, followed by the female section which brings the work to a crescendo and then to a decrescendo. The next section is rendered sprechstimme (half spoken, half sung), first done tutti, then followed by the male section with female sounds providing an obbligato and basses singing an ostinato. This section is usually omitted by choirs during competitions. The last section consists of different layers of rhythmic ostinatos and interjections, which cap the work.  Written by Antonio C. Hila

photos.desc:
Vinyl record cover of Bobby Gonzales’ Bobby Gonzales Sings,

1958, which includes “Hahabol-habol” (Villar Records)

text:
(In Pursuit). 1958. Music, Clod Delfino; lyrics, Ruben Vega. First recorded by Bobby Gonzales for Mabuhay Records in 1958. Other recordings: Victor Wood, Greatest Hits of Victor Wood, A & W Records, 1980; New Minstrels, Buhat sa New Minstrels; Freddie Aguilar, Greatest Hits, 1992.

 

The lively song set to a boogie-woogie rhythm is the plaint of the confused Cassanova, the harried husband, or the bewildered suitor who can make no sense out of a fickle female:

O ang babae, pag minamahal,

May kursunada’y aayaw-ayaw;

Pag panay ang dalaw ay nayayamot,

Huwag mong dalawin, dadabog-dabog;

Huwag mong suyuin ay nagmamaktol,

Pag iyong iniwan, hahabol-habol.

(Oh when you love a woman,

She may like you, but will resist your advances;

She’ll be irritated if you visit too often;

Stop visiting and she’ll make a scene;

Don’t press your suit and she’ll sulk;

If you leave her, she’ll chase after you.)

The last two lines of the second stanza summarize the plight of the lover:

O, ang lalaki kung nanliligaw

Maloloko siya nang husto sa buhay!

(Oh, the man who courts a woman

Will definitely go crazy!)

“Hahabol-habol” became the signature song of Bobby Gonzales throughout his musical career on the bodabil stage as well as on TV variety shows.

The song has been arranged for mixed choir and piano by Nick Pacis, one of UP Concert Chorus’s resident arrangers. Performed with lively and comical choreography, “Hahabol-habol” was among the choir’s showstoppers in their international concert tours in the 1990s.  Written by Milagros Carunungan, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

text:
(Kiss). 1998. Music and lyrics, Celso Abenoja. First performed by Aegis featuring Juliet, Mercy, and Ken Sunot on vocals, Rey Abenoja on lead guitar, Stella Pabico on keyboards, Vilma Goloviogo on drums, and Rowena Adriano on bass guitar. The song is the carrier single and the title of the group’s first album released in 1998 under Alpha Records.

 

The song starts with a powerful coda—a female persona belting out her misery as her beloved is about to leave her:

Ayoko sana na ikaw ay mawawala

Mawawasak lang ang aking mundo

Ngunit ano’ng magagawa kung talagang ayaw mo na

Sino ba naman ako para pigilin ka?

(I would never want to lose you

My world will be shattered

But what can I do if you want to give up

Who am I to stop you?)

The persona then proceeds to express her disappointment over her beloved’s seeming lack of interest in her:

Nasasaktan ako, oh baby

Sa tuwing nakikita ka...

Naninibugho ako, oh baby

Pag may kasama kang iba

Pagka’t ikaw ang tanging laman ng aking mundo

Ng aking puso, ng aking buhay...

(I’m hurting, oh baby

Whenever I see you…

I feel jealous, oh baby

Whenever you’re with someone else

Because you are my world,

My heart, my life)

In the song’s refrain, the persona speaks of her longing for her lover’s affection:

Ang halik mo, nami-miss ko

Ang halik mo, nami-miss ko

Bakit iniwan mo ako?

(Your kiss is what I miss

Your kiss is what I miss

Why did you leave me?)

The song has a simple tonal structure vacillating between the original home key in A-flat (verses) and E-flat (chorus). The unsettled tonality is compensated, however, by the rudimentary harmonic progression of each section. The first verse has the pattern A-flat-B-flat-E-flat-A-flat and this is immediately repeated with different lyrics. The second verse centers on E-flat-A-flat-B-flat-E-flat, after which a “refrain” moves to Cm-Fm-Cm-Fm-E-flat-B-flat. The chorus is built on the rudimentary E-flat-A-flat-B-flat-E-flat progression with a repeat that rhythmically pounds the pain of the song’s persona. An awkward transition appears towards the end of the piece when the repeat of the progression of the verse jump cuts to the chorus without the transitory harmonic pattern of the refrain.

Although the harmony of this song may be crude, listeners are captivated by the timbre of the angst-filled guttural voices of sisters Juliet and Mercy. The song’s popularity can also be attributed to the simplicity of its lyrics and its unabashed expression of forlornness that many Filipinos find appealing. The use of “oh baby” and the Taglish line “nami-miss” seem to add to the song’s distinct and down to earth character.

“Halik,” “Luha” (Tears), and “Basang-basa sa Ulan” (Drenched in the Rain) are three of Aegis’s songs that have captured the hearts of many Filipinos here and abroad. They are sung during videoke sessions, in amateur singing contests, as well as in reality music competitions on television. The massive appeal of these songs inspired writer Liza Magtoto and director Maribel Legarda to create Rak of Aegis, a musical based on the group’s repertoire of pop rock hits. Produced by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA), the musical premiered in 2014 and was a huge commercial and critical success.

The album Halik received the Platinum Award in Apr 1999 from the Philippine Association of the Record Industry (PARI). It went on to receive Double Platinum in December of the same year, Triple Platinum in 2000, and Quadruple Platinum in 2002. The song is also included in two Aegis compilation albums: Ating Sayawin (Let’s Dance to It), a dance mix, 2004, under Harmony Music, and Aegis Greatest Hits, 2005, under Alpha Records.  Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian, with additional notes from Jose S. Buenconsejo

article.value: (Kiss). 1998. Music and lyrics, Celso Abenoja. First performed by Aegis featuring Juliet, Mercy, and Ken Sunot on vocals, Rey Abenoja on lead guitar, Stella Pabico on keyboards, Vilma Goloviogo on drums, and Rowena Adriano on bass guitar. The song is the carrier single and the title of the group’s first album released in 1998 under Alpha Records.
The song starts with a powerful coda—a female persona belting out her misery as her beloved is about to leave her:
Ayoko sana na ikaw ay mawawala
Mawawasak lang ang aking mundo
Ngunit ano’ng magagawa kung talagang ayaw mo na
Sino ba naman ako para pigilin ka?
(I would never want to lose you
My world will be shattered
But what can I do if you want to give up
Who am I to stop you?)
The persona then proceeds to express her disappointment over her beloved’s seeming lack of interest in her:
Nasasaktan ako, oh baby
Sa tuwing nakikita ka...
Naninibugho ako, oh baby
Pag may kasama kang iba
Pagka’t ikaw ang tanging laman ng aking mundo
Ng aking puso, ng aking buhay...
(I’m hurting, oh baby
Whenever I see you…
I feel jealous, oh baby
Whenever you’re with someone else
Because you are my world,
My heart, my life)
In the song’s refrain, the persona speaks of her longing for her lover’s affection:
Ang halik mo, nami-miss ko
Ang halik mo, nami-miss ko
Bakit iniwan mo ako?
(Your kiss is what I miss
Your kiss is what I miss
Why did you leave me?)

The song has a simple tonal structure vacillating between the original home key in A-flat (verses) and E-flat (chorus). The unsettled tonality is compensated, however, by the rudimentary harmonic progression of each section. The first verse has the pattern A-flat-B-flat-E-flat-A-flat and this is immediately repeated with different lyrics. The second verse centers on E-flat-A-flat-B-flat-E-flat, after which a “refrain” moves to Cm-Fm-Cm-Fm-E-flat-B-flat. The chorus is built on the rudimentary E-flat-A-flat-B-flat-E-flat progression with a repeat that rhythmically pounds the pain of the song’s persona. An awkward transition appears towards the end of the piece when the repeat of the progression of the verse jump cuts to the chorus without the transitory harmonic pattern of the refrain.

Although the harmony of this song may be crude, listeners are captivated by the timbre of the angst-filled guttural voices of sisters Juliet and Mercy. The song’s popularity can also be attributed to the simplicity of its lyrics and its unabashed expression of forlornness that many Filipinos find appealing. The use of “oh baby” and the Taglish line “nami-miss” seem to add to the song’s distinct and down to earth character.

“Halik,” “Luha” (Tears), and “Basang-basa sa Ulan” (Drenched in the Rain) are three of Aegis’s songs that have captured the hearts of many Filipinos here and abroad. They are sung during videoke sessions, in amateur singing contests, as well as in reality music competitions on television. The massive appeal of these songs inspired writer Liza Magtoto and director Maribel Legarda to create Rak of Aegis, a musical based on the group’s repertoire of pop rock hits. Produced by the Philippine Educational Theater Association (PETA), the musical premiered in 2014 and was a huge commercial and critical success.

The album Halik received the Platinum Award in Apr 1999 from the Philippine Association of the Record Industry (PARI). It went on to receive Double Platinum in December of the same year, Triple Platinum in 2000, and Quadruple Platinum in 2002. The song is also included in two Aegis compilation albums: Ating Sayawin (Let’s Dance to It), a dance mix, 2004, under Harmony Music, and Aegis Greatest Hits, 2005, under Alpha Records.  Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian, with additional notes from Jose S. Buenconsejo

photos.desc:
Album cover of Florante de Leon’s The Best of Florante, 1982,

which includes “Handog” (Universal Records)

text:
(Offering). 1978. Music and lyrics, Florante de Leon. First sung by the composer. Recorded by Noel Cabangon in his album titled Tuloy ang Byahe (The Journey Continues), Universal Records, 2009, and by Sarah Geronimo in her album titled Pure OPM Classics, Viva Entertainment, 2012.

 

The song is set in moderately slow duple time. The verses are colloquial and reflective in tone, with a narrow range, while the refrain is more emotionally charged and melodically expansive.

The lyrics affirm the bond between the singer and his or her fans. The former is a modern-day Cinderella, a celebrity who has achieved fame and fortune, coming out of poverty and hard times when he walked the streets and begged for food. The song tells the story of many Filipino artists and celebrities. Thus, its appeal is not only to the listeners but also to the artists that sing it.

Its message is embodied in the title. The song is a gift, an offering, a hymn of gratitude to the fans for all their support that has made a better life possible for the artist:

Parang kailan lang

Halos ako ay magpalimos sa lansangan

Dahil sa inyo

Ang aking tiyan at bulsa’y nagkalaman

Kaya’t itong awitin aking inaawit

Nais ko’y kayo ang handugan.

(Not so long ago

I used to beg for alms in the streets

But because of you

That’s why this song I’m singing

I want to dedicate to all of you.)

The singer reflects that in time he or she will grow old and fade away, but his or her legacy will be this song lingering in the audience’s memory. The artist muses that even after death, he or she will continue to live in the people who remember the song.

The song has been a favorite anthem of successful Filipino singers, because of its singable melody and moving lyrics. Among the Filipino artists who have featured the song in their concerts are Nora Aunor, German Moreno, and Dolphy. It has also been arranged for mixed choir by Ed Nepomuceno, and interpreted by the Philippine Madrigal Singers.  Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

photos.desc: Artists on the cover of Handog ng Pilipino sa Mundo album, 1986 (Universal Records)

text:
(Filipinos’ Gift to the World). 1986. Music and lyrics, Jim Paredes.

 

The song celebrates the peaceful end of the successful 1986 uprising at Epifanio de los Santos Avenue or EDSA, Quezon City, that marked the end of the regime of Ferdinand Marcos. It featured the voices of 15 Filipino artists, among them, Leah Navarro, Celeste Legaspi, Becky Abraham, Heber Bartolome, Lester Demetillo, and the APO Hiking Society. It was recorded in Apr 1986. A few months later, the English version, “A New and Better Way,” was launched in Australia. In Feb 1987, on the occasion of the EDSA uprising’s anniversary, the song was released in London, England.

The song in moderate duple time speaks of the elusive dream of peace and freedom attained without bloodshed:

Handog ng Pilipino sa mundo,

Mapayapang paraang pagbabago.

Katotohanan, kalayaan, katarungan

Ay kayang makamit na walang dahas.

(Filipinos’ gift to the world,

A peaceful way towards change.

Truth, freedom, justice

Can be attained without violence.)

Expressing the sentiments of the citizens of a nation rising from the long years of dictatorship, the song opens softly and builds up slowly, with each individual performer singing a single line and contributing to a passionately triumphant chorus at the end.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes

photos.desc: Album cover of Parokya ni Edgar’s Buruguduystunstugudunstuy, 1997, which includes “Harana” (Universal Records)

text:
(Serenade). 1992. Music and lyrics, Eric Yaptangco.

This Filipino ballad was first recorded as a solo by Tony Lambino, one of the four members of Ryan Cayabyab’s singing group Smokey Mountain. With thick synthesized accompaniment and studio-induced reverberation, this work was released in the cassette album titled Tony Lambino: First Note by Viva Records.

 

The song was later rendered by Alfonso “Chito” Miranda Jr who added a strophe to Yaptangco’s lyrics with complete “unplugged” acoustic guitar sound. This was released in the album Buruguduystunstugudunstuy by the Filipino alternative rock band Parokya ni Edgar (PNE) under Universal Records in 1997. Yaptangco was a member of this band.

The PNE rendition of the song is interesting due to the “adolescent” quality of Miranda’s raw voice. The singer takes the point of view of a teenager who self-consciously notes the irony of singing the old fashioned harana in an age of faded jeans and electronic media.

Meron pang dalang mga rosas,

Suot nama’y maong na kupas.

At nariyan pa ang barkada,

Nakaporma, nakabarong

Sa awiting daig pa’ng minus one

Sing-along.

(You even bring roses with you

While you wear your faded jeans.

Your gangmates are all there

Sleek in their barongs

With a song that beats a minus one

At a sing-along.)

The chorus is quite sentimental and uses outdated romantic expressions:

Puno ang langit ng bituin,

At kay lamig pa ng hangin.

Sa ’yong tingin ako’y nababaliw, giliw.

At sa awitin kong ito

Sana’y maibigan mo.

Ibubuhos ko ang buong puso ko

Sa isang munting harana … para sa ’yo.

(The heaven is filled with stars,

The breeze is so cool.

Your gaze drives me crazy, dear.

I hope you like

This song of mine

I will pour my heart out

In a little serenade … for you.)

The singer pokes fun at himself for setting up the rather contrived “old Tagalog movie” character of the scene to woo his lady love:

Hindi ba’t parang isang sine,

Isang pelikulang romantiko?

Hindi ba’t ikaw ang bidang artista

At ako ang ’yong leading man

Sa istoryang nagwawakas

Sa pag-ibig na wagas

(Isn’t this like a movie?

A romantic comedy?

Aren’t you the lead actress

and I your leading man?

In a story that ends

With a love that is pure.)

APO Hiking Society later recorded another version with arrangement by Jimmy Antiporda, in their 2001 album Banda Rito (On This Side), Universal Records. Akafellas also covered the song under Star Records in 2004. Since then, many other singers such as Regine Velasquez, the Company, and Noel Cabangon, have rendered the song in different styles.

The music video for PNE’s acoustic version received the International Viewer’s Choice Award for Southeast Asia from the MTV Video Music Awards in 1999.  Written by Jose S. Buenconsejo, with notes from Josephine Cecilia L. Baradas

text:
(Midnight). 1925. Music, Antonio J. Molina; lyrics, Levi Celerio (in the 1960s). First published in 1932.

 

It is a danza written for violin with piano accompaniment. Following the ABBACC pattern, it begins in the minor key and modulates to the major in the C part. It has become one of the most popular pieces in the repertoire of the Philippine violinist.

An arrangement for mixed chorus by Restie Umali in the 1960s also made the work a part of the vocal and choral repertoire. The lyrics by Levi Celerio portray a man serenading his beloved at midnight and express the loneliness that the lover feels as the night deepens, and his longing for his beloved’s presence grows stronger:

Ah! Halina, irog ko

Sa aking piling

Lapitan mo ako

Sa gitna nitong hilahil.

(Ah! Come to me, darling

Be by my side

Come near to me

In the midst of this misery.)

The song was also arranged for two voices by Redentor L. Romero, and is included in 50 Immortal Filipino Duets, published by the National Philharmonic Society of the Philippines in 1992.  Written by Antonio C. Hila, updated by James C. Diaz

text:
(Holding Hands). 2006. Music and lyrics, Yeng Constantino aka Josephine Constantino-Asuncion. First performed by Constantino in the reality television series Pinoy Dream Academy aired on ABS-CBN in 2006.

 

Constantino was only 14 when she wrote “Hawak-Kamay.” The simplicity and innocence of the music reveals this tender age. The song was inspired by the singer’s strong bond with a cousin who left home. The song relates to themes of friendship and solace, as in the words of the chorus:

Hawak-kamay,

di kita iiwan sa paglakbay

dito sa mundong walang katiyakan.

(Hands held together,

I will not forsake you in our journey,

in a world without certainty)

As singable as a church song, it has an arrangement that projects an obvious “easy feel.” The “easy feeling” one gets in the song is partly due to the use of nondistorted “sparkling” guitar sound and lightly plucked bass and struck rhythms on the maracas. The music is set to the common verse-chorus structure in which phrases are perfectly “square” or symmetrical (four bars each).

After performing the song in Pinoy Dream Academy, Constantino went on to win the top prize in the reality competition and became a household name. The following year, she released her debut album Salamat (Thanks), which included the song in the track listing. In 2011, American singer and songwriter David DiMuzo created an English version titled “I’m By Your Side.”

The song has been widely played and performed in music competitions such as The Voice Philippines. It became the theme song of the movie Kasal, Kasali, Kasalo (Partner, Participant, Partaker), 2006, a romantic comedy directed by Jose Javier Reyes and starring Judy Ann Santos and Ryan Agoncillo. “Hawak Kamay” was also used for the Department of Education’s Brigada Eskwela campaign for out-of-school youth and the Adopt-a-School Program in 2008, of which Constantino was an advocate. Actor Piolo Pascual covered the song for the TV series of the same title in 2014, where he also starred.

“Hawak Kamay” won Best Theme Song in the 32nd Metro Manila Film Festival, 2006, and the 55th FAMAS Awards and the 3rd ASAP Pop Viewers Choice Awards, both in 2007.  Written by Ariel Lev Pinzon, with additional notes from Jose S. Buenconsejo

photos.desc:
Vinyl record cover of Juan de la Cruz’s Ang Himig Natin,

1973, which carried the titular single (Vicor Music)

text:
(Our Hymn). 1973. Music, Mike Hanopol, Joey Smith, and Wally Gonzales; lyrics, Joey Smith. First performed by Juan de la Cruz Band. Recorded by Vicor Records.

The song expressed the sentiments of the youth of the late 1960s and early 1970s and signaled the beginning of a movement towards the Filipinization of Western pop music.

Ang himig natin

Ang inyong awitin

Upang tayo’y magsama-sama

Sa langit ng pag-asa.

(Our music

Is what you should sing

So that we can come together

In the heaven of hope.)

The first rock song in the Filipino language, this song is credited with being the “father” of Pinoy rock.  Written by Milagros Carunungan

text:
(Philippine National Hymn, Land Dear and Holy). 1898. Music, Julian Felipe; lyrics, Jose Isaac Velasquez Palma. English translations by Paz Marquez Benitez, Camilo Osias, and M.A. Lane. Filipino translation by the Department of Education, 1956. Commissioned by Emilio Aguinaldo. First performed by Banda San Francisco de Malabon (now General Trias) in Kawit, Cavite, on the occasion of the declaration of Philippine independence on 12 Jun 1898.

 

The manuscript of the composition bore the heading “Marcha Filipina Nacional” (Philippine National March) although it was also known as the “Marcha Filipino Magdalo” (Philippine Magdalo March), Magdalo being Aguinaldo’s nom-de-guerre. Gen Emilio Aguinaldo and some leaders of the 1896 Revolution liked Felipe’s work, and after a brief discussion, suggested that it be officially adopted as the Philippine national anthem. Some scholars aver that the music of the anthem shows the influence of the Spanish and French national anthems.

A year after the melody was composed, Palma wrote a poem, “Filipinas, Letra Para La Marcha Nacional” (Philippines, Lyrics for the National March), which was published on 3 Sep 1899 in La Independencia, the official organ of the Philippine revolution edited by Antonio Luna. The poem became the lyrics of the national anthem. The “Himno” was reportedly first sung by the staff of the newspaper.

In 1906, the wife of Fernando Canon, Teresa Battle, commissioned a composer to use the melody of the marcha in nine-sectioned piano variations in popular music style and published this in Madrid in a piece titled “A Rizal: Lirismo Patriotico” (To Rizal: Patriotic Lyricism). In 1928, Alexander Lippay, then director of the University of the Philippines Conservatory of Music, composed a complicated symphonic work titled Thirteen Variations on the Philippine National Hymn, based on the melody of the march.

In 1943, then president Jose P. Laurel ordered the Institute of National Language to translate the original Spanish text into Filipino and English. The first stanza of the original Spanish text, the Filipino translation (then titled “Diwang Bayan” or National Ideal), and the English translation, are as follows:

 

SPANISH

Tierra adorada

Hija del sol de Oriente

Su fuego ardiente

En ti latiendo esta.

 

FILIPINO

Lupang mapalad na mutya ng Silangan

Bayang kasuyo ng sangkalikasan

Buhay at yaman ng Kapilipinuhan

Kuha’t bawi na sa banyagang kamay.

 

ENGLISH

Land of the morning

Child of the sun returning

With fervor burning

Thee do our souls adore.

In 1956, the Department of Education formed a committee of musicians, writers, and technical staff of various government departments which sat down to create a more spontaneous and apt Filipino translation of the anthem. The result was “Lupang Hinirang.” Under Presidential Proclamation No 60 that took effect on 19 Dec 1963, this Filipino version of the Palma text became the official anthem of the Philippines that is sung to the present. It runs:

Lupang Hinirang

Bayang magiliw

Perlas ng Silanganan

Alab ng puso

Sa dibdib mo’y buhay

Lupang hinirang

Duyan ka ng magiting

Sa manlulupig

Di ka pasisiil

Sa dagat at bundok

Sa simoy at sa langit mong bughaw

May dilag ang tula at awit

Sa paglayang minamahal

Ang kislap ng watawat mo’y

Tagumpay na nagniningning

Ang bituin at araw niya

Kailanpama’y di magdidilim

Lupa ng araw, ng luwalhalti’t pagsinta

Buhay ay langit sa piling mo

Aming ligaya na pag may mang-aapi

Ang mamatay nang dahil sa iyo.

(Land of the morning,

Child of the sun returning,

With fervor burning

Thee do our souls adore

Land dear and holy,

Cradle of noble heroes,

Ne’er shall invaders

Trample thy sacred shore

Ever within thy skies and through thy clouds,

And o’er thy hills and seas,

Do we behold the radiance, feel the throb

Of glorious liberty

Thy banner dear to all our hearts,

Its sun and stars alight,

O, never shall its shining field

Be dimmed by tyrants’ might

Beautiful land of love, O, land of light,

In thine embrace ‘tis rapture to lie,

But it is glory ever, when thou art wronged

or us, thy sons, to suffer and die.) Written by Antonio C. Hila, updated by Jose S. Buenconsejo

article.value: (Philippine National Hymn, Land Dear and Holy). 1898. Music, Julian Felipe; lyrics, Jose Isaac Velasquez Palma. English translations by Paz Marquez Benitez, Camilo Osias, and M.A. Lane. Filipino translation by the Department of Education, 1956. Commissioned by Emilio Aguinaldo. First performed by Banda San Francisco de Malabon (now General Trias) in Kawit, Cavite, on the occasion of the declaration of Philippine independence on 12 Jun 1898.

The manuscript of the composition bore the heading “Marcha Filipina Nacional” (Philippine National March) although it was also known as the “Marcha Filipino Magdalo” (Philippine Magdalo March), Magdalo being Aguinaldo’s nom-de-guerre. Gen Emilio Aguinaldo and some leaders of the 1896 Revolution liked Felipe’s work, and after a brief discussion, suggested that it be officially adopted as the Philippine national anthem. Some scholars aver that the music of the anthem shows the influence of the Spanish and French national anthems.

A year after the melody was composed, Palma wrote a poem, “Filipinas, Letra Para La Marcha Nacional” (Philippines, Lyrics for the National March), which was published on 3 Sep 1899 in La Independencia, the official organ of the Philippine revolution edited by Antonio Luna. The poem became the lyrics of the national anthem. The “Himno” was reportedly first sung by the staff of the newspaper.

In 1906, the wife of Fernando Canon, Teresa Battle, commissioned a composer to use the melody of the marcha in nine-sectioned piano variations in popular music style and published this in Madrid in a piece titled “A Rizal: Lirismo Patriotico” (To Rizal: Patriotic Lyricism). In 1928, Alexander Lippay, then director of the University of the Philippines Conservatory of Music, composed a complicated symphonic work titled Thirteen Variations on the Philippine National Hymn, based on the melody of the march.

In 1943, then president Jose P. Laurel ordered the Institute of National Language to translate the original Spanish text into Filipino and English. The first stanza of the original Spanish text, the Filipino translation (then titled “Diwang Bayan” or National Ideal), and the English translation, are as follows:
SPANISH
Tierra adorada
Hija del sol de Oriente
Su fuego ardiente
En ti latiendo esta.
FILIPINO
Lupang mapalad na mutya ng Silangan
Bayang kasuyo ng sangkalikasan
Buhay at yaman ng Kapilipinuhan
Kuha’t bawi na sa banyagang kamay.
ENGLISH
Land of the morning
Child of the sun returning
With fervor burning
Thee do our souls adore.

In 1956, the Department of Education formed a committee of musicians, writers, and technical staff of various government departments which sat down to create a more spontaneous and apt Filipino translation of the anthem. The result was “Lupang Hinirang.” Under Presidential Proclamation No 60 that took effect on 19 Dec 1963, this Filipino version of the Palma text became the official anthem of the Philippines that is sung to the present. It runs:
Lupang Hinirang
Bayang magiliw
Perlas ng Silanganan
Alab ng puso
Sa dibdib mo’y buhay
Lupang hinirang
Duyan ka ng magiting
Sa manlulupig
Di ka pasisiil
Sa dagat at bundok
Sa simoy at sa langit mong bughaw
May dilag ang tula at awit
Sa paglayang minamahal
Ang kislap ng watawat mo’y
Tagumpay na nagniningning
Ang bituin at araw niya
Kailanpama’y di magdidilim
Lupa ng araw, ng luwalhalti’t pagsinta
Buhay ay langit sa piling mo
Aming ligaya na pag may mang-aapi
Ang mamatay nang dahil sa iyo.
(Land of the morning,
Child of the sun returning,
With fervor burning
Thee do our souls adore
Land dear and holy,
Cradle of noble heroes,
Ne’er shall invaders
Trample thy sacred shore
Ever within thy skies and through thy clouds,
And o’er thy hills and seas,
Do we behold the radiance, feel the throb
Of glorious liberty
Thy banner dear to all our hearts,
Its sun and stars alight,
O, never shall its shining field
Be dimmed by tyrants’ might
Beautiful land of love, O, land of light,
In thine embrace ‘tis rapture to lie,
But it is glory ever, when thou art wronged
or us, thy sons, to suffer and die.) Written by Antonio C. Hila, updated by Jose S. Buenconsejo

text:
(I Won’t Forget You). 1979. Music, Manuel “Manoling” Francisco, SJ; lyrics taken from the Book of Isaiah of the Old Testament. In connection with the songwriting contest at the Ateneo High School in 1979, Onofre Pagsanghan gave his students the broad outline of the theme for the required song. The winner was Manoling Francisco who later entered the Jesuit novitiate after graduation.

 

This song in two parts was an instant liturgical hit. First sung by the composer’s friends, it was later reworked and arranged for male chorus and introduced by an Ateneo High School group, the Dulaang Sibol, to the neighboring parish churches, from where it spread all over the country. It is sung during mass, since it speaks of God’s love for His people. It is also a popular choice for weddings and burials because of its lyrics:

Hindi kita malilimutan

Hindi kita pababayaan

Nakaukit magpakailanman

Sa aking palad ang ’yong pangalan.

Malilimutan ba ng ina

Ang anak na galing sa kanya

Sanggol sa kanyang sinapupunan

Paano niya matatalikdan.

(I won’t forget you

I will not desert you

Your name

Is forever carved in my palm.

How could the mother forget

The child which she bore

The babe in her womb

How could she abandon.)

Basil Valdez placed this sacred song in the realm of popular music with its inclusion in his album of the same name in an arrangement by Ryan Cayabyab. The Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO) has also recorded their own orchestral arrangement in a cassette tape, Pintig (Beat). All the major choirs in the Philippines have their own arrangements. Due to the migration of Filipino workers all over the world today, there has been a high incidence of masses celebrated in Filipino with Filipino choir members popularizing this song in their respective parishes.

The rock band Asin recorded this song in their album Himig Kayumanggi (Brown Melodies) in 2003. Gary Valenciano included the song in his Revive album in 2007. Still another version is found in Noel Cabangon’s music video produced by the Jesuit Music Ministry in 2012.  Written by Felicidad Z. Reyes, updated by Crisancti L. Macazo

photos.desc:
Cover of Celeste Legaspi’s album, 1982,

which includes “Hindi Kita Malimot” (Universal Records)

text:
(I Cannot Forget You). 1939. Music and lyrics, Josefino Cenizal.

The song was composed for the movie Rosa Birhen (Rose the Virgin), which was directed by and starred Cenizal. Produced by Del Monte Pictures in 1939, the movie is about a rural lass (played by Raymunda Guidote) who chances upon and falls in love with a radio star, who falls in love with her in turn, but soon deserts her for another woman. Upon listening to the radio one day, she hears him singing “Hindi Kita Malimot.” She turns off the radio, but the voice continues; it turns out that the man has returned, and they sing together. The movie became a hit due to the hauntingly evocative theme song. The lyrics speak of a love that cannot be forgotten.

 

Hindi kita malimot

Alaala kita

Hindi kita malimot

Minamahal kita.

Isinusumpa ko

Sa iyong kagandahan

Ikaw lamang

Ang tangi kong paraluman.

(I cannot forget you

I will always be reminded of you

I cannot forget you

I love you.

I swear

On your beauty

That only you

Will be my muse.)

Like the traditional love songs of its epoch, it begins in the lower case mode, sweeping toward a refrain of harmonic sensuality. In 1970, Josefino Cenizal arranged the song for four voices. Alfredo S. Buenaventura also has an arrangement for two voices, soprano and tenor, that is included in 50 Immortal Filipino Duets, published by the National Philharmonic Society of the Philippines in 1992. Undoubtedly a classic, the song was given a new interpretation in Ryan Cayabyab’s One. Two movies have used it as title and theme song: one in 1948 starring Carmen Rosales and Leopoldo Salcedo and directed by Eddie Romero, and another in 1982 starring Maricel Soriano and William Martinez, directed by Ishmael Bernal, and produced by Regal Films.   Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by James C. Diaz

photos.desc:
Raimund Marasigan, left, Marcus Adoro, Ely Buendia, front, and Buddy Zabala, the original members of Eraserheads, 1992

(Photo courtesy of Jessel Baltazar)

text:
The Last El Bimbo). 1996. Music and lyrics, Ely Buendia. Performed by Eraserheads (aka Eheads) featuring lead singer Ely Buendia with Raimund Marasigan (drums and percussion), Buddy Zabala (bass guitar), and Marcus Adoro (guitar). Included in the album Cutterpillow released by BMG Records (Pilipinas) under its Musiko Label. Produced by Robin Rivera and Romel Sanchez.

 

In the song, a once-upon-a-time lover recalls the past with his beloved, whose beauty is likened to Paraluman, a Filipino movie icon from the 1950s. The use of “paraluman”—an archaic Tagalog word which means muse—signals the distance of the vision of the past filled with desire and enchantment. The beauty’s dancing skills—especially to the music of “El Bimbo,” a 1970s disco hit—are so sensuous to the former lover, titillating (nakakaindak, nakakaaliw) him and eliciting gooseflesh (nakakatindig balahibo) on his body. In the first part of the song, erotic images abound, like the clasped lovers’ arms, body stiffening as response to dance music, lovers’ caresses, and hands sliding down the smooth flesh of the beauty’s arm. These past images present a stark contrast to the second part of the song which is set in the real present, in which the beauty is now depicted as a single unwed mother who works a menial job washing dishes in Ermita, a red light district, and who later dies in darkness. The song is remarkable because it evokes the plight of a young, once innocent, woman from the province ending a tragic life in the urban squalor of Manila.

This soft rock music is set to the standard 32-bar (verse-verse-bridge-chorus) form and is built on a simple chord progression (G-Am-C-G) that is repeated throughout the piece. Interest in the song lies in the raw voices of Eraserheads and the music arrangement whose texture progresses from “bare” solo guitar in the verses to lush instrumentation characterized by strong guitar strumming in the chorus. Simple though the chord progression is, the shift from G to the succeeding A minor incrementally impresses the listener because the speechlike rendition (parlando style) of many verses gravitates towards this deceptive cadence in A minor in most parts.

The song was nominated in the Best Musical Arrangement category of the Awit Awards and won Best Rock Song in the 1996 Katha Awards. Cutterpillow garnered platinum sales in 1996 and also won the Album of the Year recognition from Awit Awards of the same year. The music video directed by Auraeus Solito aka Kanakan Balintagos won the International Viewer’s Choice Award for Asia at the 1997 MTV Video Music Awards held in New York City’s Radio City Music Hall. Singer Rico J. Puno performed the song in the Eraserheads tribute album Ultraelectromagneticjam! The Music of the Eraserheads, released in 2005.  Written by Jose S. Buenconsejo

text:
1959. Music, Angel M. Peña. First prize in the 1958-1959 Symphonic Poem Competition held under the auspices of the University of Santo Tomas Conservatory Alumni Association.

 

The term Igorot is used to refer collectively to ethnolinguistic groups of people living in the Northern Cordilleras of Luzon in the Philippines. Angel M. Peña’s Igorot Rhapsody celebrates these groups, basing his work on three Igorot themes, liberally developed and treated in the modern idiom, yet preserving their indigenous character through the use of Igorot instruments. The score calls for the use of a northern gangsa (flat gong); the bunkaka (bamboo buzzer); the sulibaw (wooden drum); the litguit (a bamboo fiddle); and any kind of Igorot flute.

The work employs native thematic material which Peña creatively spins into an intricate rhapsody. In doing so, the composer was motivated by a sincere desire to preserve a rich aboriginal heritage which he saw as rapidly vanishing in the onslaught of Western music.

Igorot Rhapsody was chosen by Oscar C. Yatco for the inaugural concert of the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra in Aug 1982.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes

photos.desc:
“Ili-ili Tulog Anay” featured in

Folk Songs: Songs of the Visayas Volume 1

by Priscilla Magdamo, 1957

text:
(Go to Sleep Now). Collected by Priscilla V. Magdamo during fieldwork in 1956 in Banga, Aklan, this traditional Visayan lullaby appears in Songs of the Visayas, 1957.

 

A simple song, it is made up of two musical phrases, AB, set to a four-line text. The minor-key melody soars gently through one octave and a fourth.

In the text, the child is lulled to sleep by assurances that the absent mother has merely gone to the store to buy bread. Its lyrics go:

Ili-ili tulog anay

Wala diri imong nanay

Kadto tienda bakal papay

Ili-ili tulog anay.

(Go to sleep now

Your mother is away

She went to the store to buy some bread

So go to sleep, my darling baby.)

Lucrecia R. Kasilag arranged the song for three voices (soprano, alto, tenor) and piano accompaniment. The more popular choral setting of the piece is Priscilla Magdamo’s mixed choir arrangement, premiered by the Philippine Madrigal Singers. A modern neo-ethnic rendition has been recorded by Chin Chin Gutierrez in her album titled Uyayi (Lullaby), which is a compilation of Philippine lullabies, released in 2004. Written by Corazon C. Dioquino, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

photos.desc: Scene from In Despair, 1930 (Photo courtesy of Simon Santos/Video 48)

text:
1947. Music and lyrics, Salvador Asuncion. First performed and recorded by Johnny Astor for Lirio Records in 1947.

 

One of the earliest attempts in English to romanticize forsaken love is this ballad composed by Salvador Asuncion. Known to be the first English ballad composed by a Filipino, “In Despair” typifies the composer’s romantic character and shows him as the hapless victim of a failed romance.

The song’s text can be regarded as Asuncion’s real-life outpouring of his frustration over the loss of his wife, who left him for another man. The emotionally shattering experience propelled Asuncion to compose the song. The song, which was released under the Lirio Records label, was a commercial success, and the record sold over 30,000 copies and was considered a big hit at that time.

“In Despair” became the title song for a 1950 LVN movie directed by Lamberto Avellana, starring Jaime de la Rosa and Mila del Sol. The song was revived by Victor Wood in the 1970s. A Tagalog version, translated by Philip Maninang, and titled “Hanggang Langit Mahal Kita” (I Love You As High As the Sky), was included in Pilita Corrales’s album Pilita/Filipiniana released by Vicor in the late 1970s.  Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian
