photos.desc:
Sheet music cover of “Jocelynang Baliwag”

(Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection)

text:
(Jocelyna of Baliwag). Circa 1896. A favorite among the Bulacan revolutionaries of 1896, its printed score was found among the papers of Juan Molina, leader of Orquesta Molina. The score bore an inscription: Musica del legitimo kundiman procedente del campo insurrecto (Music of the authentic kundiman coming from the insurgents’ camp).

 

Cast in the slow triple time of the traditional kundiman, the song has two parts. While the melody of the song has been praised for its haunting but mellifluous quality, its prosody has been criticized as flawed, because the lyrics do not seem to conform to the rhythm. The first letters of the first words of the six-stanza lyrics spell out the name “Pepita,” which refers to Pepita (nickname of Jocelyna) Tiongson, a beautiful woman from Baliuag, Bulacan, to whom the song is dedicated. The song’s melody is hauntingly sad, revealing an underlying pensiveness.

Although the kundiman, like many others, is dedicated to an individual lady, it is clear that the lady referred to here could also be the Mother Country. Felipe Padilla de Leon observes that it was quite easy and natural to equate the love for a woman with the adoration and reverence felt for the country. Thus, the image of the forlorn lover pleading to the beloved finds perfect parallel in the downtrodden Filipino soldiers risking their lives in the battlefield and pleading the cause of liberation from the oppressive Spanish rule at the end of the 19th century.

This kundiman was used as the love theme in Nicanor G. Tiongson ’s sarsuwela, Pilipinas Circa 1907, 1982, and in Bienvenido Lumbera’s sarsuwela Hibik at Himagsik nina Victoria Laktaw Atbp. (Plaint and Rebellion of Victoria Laktaw and Others), 1998. Jocelynang Baliwag was dubbed by Antonio Molina as one of the few “kundiman ng himagsikan” (kundiman of the revolution), and it was among the signature songs representing the revolutionary period. The Philippine Madrigal Singers included this piece in their 1998 centennial program, as well as in their 100th year Philippine independence commemorative album titled Bayan Ko, Aawitan Kita (My Country, I Will Sing For You), released by BMG Records, Inc. The same choral arrangement by Christopher Borela was also featured in a rare concert featuring original Philippine music from 18th century to 1986 at the University of the Philippines College of Music, and sung by the Novo Concertante Manila.  Written by Antonio C. Hila, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

article.value: (Jocelyna of Baliwag). Circa 1896. A favorite among the Bulacan revolutionaries of 1896, its printed score was found among the papers of Juan Molina, leader of Orquesta Molina. The score bore an inscription: Musica del legitimo kundiman procedente del campo insurrecto (Music of the authentic kundiman coming from the insurgents’ camp).

value.desc:
Sheet music cover of “Jocelynang Baliwag”

(Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection)

article.value: Cast in the slow triple time of the traditional kundiman, the song has two parts. While the melody of the song has been praised for its haunting but mellifluous quality, its prosody has been criticized as flawed, because the lyrics do not seem to conform to the rhythm. The first letters of the first words of the six-stanza lyrics spell out the name “Pepita,” which refers to Pepita (nickname of Jocelyna) Tiongson, a beautiful woman from Baliuag, Bulacan, to whom the song is dedicated. The song’s melody is hauntingly sad, revealing an underlying pensiveness.

Although the kundiman, like many others, is dedicated to an individual lady, it is clear that the lady referred to here could also be the Mother Country. Felipe Padilla de Leon observes that it was quite easy and natural to equate the love for a woman with the adoration and reverence felt for the country. Thus, the image of the forlorn lover pleading to the beloved finds perfect parallel in the downtrodden Filipino soldiers risking their lives in the battlefield and pleading the cause of liberation from the oppressive Spanish rule at the end of the 19th century.

This kundiman was used as the love theme in Nicanor G. Tiongson ’s sarsuwela, Pilipinas Circa 1907, 1982, and in Bienvenido Lumbera’s sarsuwela Hibik at Himagsik nina Victoria Laktaw Atbp. (Plaint and Rebellion of Victoria Laktaw and Others), 1998. Jocelynang Baliwag was dubbed by Antonio Molina as one of the few “kundiman ng himagsikan” (kundiman of the revolution), and it was among the signature songs representing the revolutionary period. The Philippine Madrigal Singers included this piece in their 1998 centennial program, as well as in their 100th year Philippine independence commemorative album titled Bayan Ko, Aawitan Kita (My Country, I Will Sing For You), released by BMG Records, Inc. The same choral arrangement by Christopher Borela was also featured in a rare concert featuring original Philippine music from 18th century to 1986 at the University of the Philippines College of Music, and sung by the Novo Concertante Manila.  Written by Antonio C. Hila, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

text:
(Always). 1996. Music and lyrics, Jay Oliver Durias. Recorded by the band South Border, with vocals by Durias and Brix Ferraris, for their self-titled album released in 1996 by Sony Music Philippines.

“Kahit Kailan” is an intense declaration of loyalty to a lover. Two singers (Durias and Ferraris) sing alternately the lines of the verses and the chorus of the song in a speech-like, mannerist manner of extreme emotion. The raspy voice of Durias in low register, characteristic of many R&B singers of the early 1990s to 2000s, provides a contrast to the high-pitched “pleading” voice of Ferraris. The song is remarkable for its extraordinary bridge in which Ferraris delivers a climactic “screaming” high note (above high C) that is caught by the saxophone (played by Ric Junasa) on the same note. The saxophone instrumental that follows accentuates the song’s quirky qualities that encapsulate the experience of a romantic emotion about to lose control.

 

The music of this piece is unusual, sounding more like an experimental dramatic vocal piece. While jazz is often associated with rhythm and beats, this song does not have these elements. In fact it is introduced by a gossamer of string sounds, as if a hallucination, that presages the idiosyncratic nature of the music: high vocal register and obsessive syncopations resulting in an unsingable melody, and abrupt harmonic meanderings.

Along with other hit songs of their first self-titled album such as “May Pag-Ibig Pa Kaya” (Would There Still be Love) and “Love of My Life,” “Kahit Kailan” has put South Border on the charts and accorded them recognition. Since the song was first released, “Kahit Kailan” has become a familiar and well-loved contemporary Filipino R&B classic.

When Ferraris left the band, Boholano singer Luke Mejares replaced him and sang the former’s part in subsequent performances. In 2002, Mejares also left South Border to pursue his solo career. Two talented vocalists, Duncan Ramos and Vince Alaras, thereafter took turns to sing the same part. Despite the changing of lead singers, the band has retained the way the song was sung by the previous singers. Another version of the song featured Durias, Ramos, and Kyla on vocals. “Kahit Kailan” also became the theme song of an afternoon drama series of the same title, starring Jolina Magdangal and James Blanco, aired on GMA Network from 2002 to 2003.

The song was awarded Song of the Year by various local radio stations immediately after its first release. In 1997, the original ensemble’s first album achieved gold and platinum status. On the same year, South Border also won four trophies in the 10th Awit Awards, three of which are: Album of the Year, Best Performance by a New Duo or Group Recording Artist/s, Song of the Year, and Best Produced Record of the Year.  Written by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya, with additional notes from Jose S. Buenconsejo

photos.desc:
Cassette jacket of Buklod’s Sa Kandungan ng Kalikasan, 1992, which includes “Kanlungan”
(Buklod Musical Group)

text:
(Life’s Chance / In One’s Own Time). 1992. Music and lyrics, Rom C. Dongeto. First performed by Buklod featuring Noel Cabangon, Rom Dongeto, and Rene Boncocan.

 

The song was first categorized as “alternative music” because it circulated back then as an independently produced cassette album titled Sa Kandungan ng Kalikasan (In the Cradle of Nature). A few years later, however, it gained mainstream popularity when the song was utilized as theme for a McDonald’s advertisement. It is now categorized as “pop” in the repertoire of Original Pilipino Music (OPM).

The form of the song is strophic. It is built harmonically unto two types of four-bar harmonic progressions. One is centered on its tonic E, articulating the hook of the rhyming lines “Pana-panahon ang pagkakataon / maibabalik ba ang kahapon” (Time is a chance / Can the past be taken back?). The contrasting pattern (articulating the song text’s verses) is centered on A. The latter pattern evades the E chord, “escaping” for the most part into deceptive cadences that end on the substitute “dominant” C sharp minor. The alternation between stable E chord progression and A-to-C sharp minor pattern creates an overall cyclical feel that suits the message of the text, which paints alternating images of past and present.

The song is one of nostalgia for the bygone days of innocence and unfettered freedom. It is spoken to an absent Beloved, which can be taken as a metaphor for nature or life (in such case the lyrics can be an environmentalist song) or of a real person in one’s childhood (in such case it is a romantic song). The message of the song is however transcendent as the protagonist of the poem expresses the enigma of experiencing time. Physically, linear time cannot be taken back, but phenomenologically it can be, as the cyclical nature of the music suggests. The nondescript voice of the singer captures this existentialist wonder. The deceptive cadences in many lines makes the listener question the banality of everyday life.

The song is included in Noel Cabangon’s album Byahe (Journey), 2009, under Universal Records. The song’s continuing popularity is proven by the number of covers it has enjoyed such as those featuring Paolo Santos, 2009, and Basil Valdez, 2011. Written by Jose S. Buenconsejo

photos.desc: Figure 1: Passage adopted from a Tagabawa chant which functions as the work’s core idea
Figure 2: Diagram showing the structure of Kantus: Tagabawa

text:
1999. Music, Josefino “Chino” Toledo.

 

Commissioned for the annual Hong Kong Musicarama, the piece represents a culmination of Philippine orchestral composition in the 20th century. Toledo’s unmistakable eruptive writing style is amplified by the use of indigenous music as central material built into a reconfigured Western structure and marked by a decisive departure from orchestral convention.

Toledo was motivated to compose the piece after chancing upon a recording of a chant from the Tagabawa of Mindanao. From this music, he adopted a brief passage to serve as the core idea of the work, not in the conventional sense of a melodic theme, but as a structural foundation that provides coherence to the entire piece, highlighting the composer’s penchant for form-based writing. Toledo, moreover, deconstructed the chant to extract idiosyncratic components such as ornamentation, articulation, and phrasing along with vocal interjections. Figure 1 shows an abstraction of the Tagabawa passage exhibiting a falling contour.

The Tagabawa passage above constitutes the recurring section of the piece, which provides a contrast to a transforming section that it alternates with, thus resembling the ritornello form [ABACADA…]. Toledo assigns the recurring section to the woodwinds, instead of full orchestra as in the conventional Baroque concerto grosso which utilizes the ritornello form, and relegates the transforming section to the entire orchestra. Rather than opening the piece with the recurring section, Toledo begins with the transforming section, a concept he has applied before as a student composer, in a piece titled Barasyon, Tema, Barasyon at Tema Uli (Variation, Theme, Variations and Theme Again, 1980) which rearranges the theme and variation sequence. Figure 2 below summarizes this structure.

Apart from instrumentation, the contrast between the transforming and recurring sections plays out in the texture and the use of time. In the former, thick layers of homophonic and polyphonic sonorities commingle with heavy, driving rhythms punctuated by shouts and sharp attacks, all written in (but not really perceived as) quadruple time. On the other hand, the recurring section executed by woodwinds retains the lyrical character of the Tagabawa chant, transcribed without measures and marked with elapsed time in seconds. Here, the instruments quickly leap in unison to E-flat, then gradually cascade an octave down while disintegrating out of phase or pace with each other, resulting in heterophony.

The stark dissimilarities between the alternating sections lend drama to the piece and provide a sense of forward motion. Moreover, orchestral treatment is distinguished by a negation of established notions of role, hierarchy, and balance; all instruments for the most part are foregrounded, bringing everything at certain points to the verge of anarchy. A further striking element—the massive barrage by two bass drums positioned on opposite sides of the stage—functions as a framing device to the entire work. In the end, at the point of resolution, all the instruments coalesce into a single melody, now, for the first time, in strict unison resembling a colossal yet tranquil wave swelling and surging before disintegrating once more into detached fragments and strands, until finally all that remains is the soft rumbling of the two bass drums. Written by LaVerne David C. de la Peña

photos.desc:
Cassette jacket of Kapantay ay Langit original

motion picture soundtrack, 1994 (Viva Records)

text:
(High as the Sky). 1958. Music and lyrics, George Canseco. English version first performed by Amapola.

 

The song took 13 years to make. Seven years after composing the music, George Canseco wrote the English lyrics and titled the work “You’re All I Love.” Pilita Corrales turned it into a hit in 1965. Six years later, Canseco wrote the Filipino lyrics and the song was used for a movie of the same title. Its opening lyrics go:

Mahal kita,

Kapantay ay langit, sinta

Ang lagi kong dasal sa Maykapal

Ay lumigaya ka…

( I love you

As high as the sky, my dear one

I always pray to the Lord

For your happiness…)

“Kapantay ay Langit” won Best Movie Theme Song in the 1971 Manila Film Festival Awards. It has been interpreted by foreign singers and translated into local and foreign languages. Viva Films used it as the title and theme song of a 1994 movie starring Sharon Cuneta and Richard Gomez and directed by Joel Lamangan. In 1996, Redentor L. Romero arranged the song for the orchestra and performed it with the Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra as the conductor. The song is included in his CD album Damdaming Pinoy (Filipino Feelings), recorded in Moscow, Russia.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by James C. Diaz

photos.desc:
Rogelio de la Rosa and Norma Blancaflor in Victory Joe, 1946,
which used the song “Kataka-taka” (Cesar Hernando Collection)

text:
(How Strange). 1946. Music, Santiago Suarez; lyrics, Dominador Santiago.

 

This lighthearted and jocose love song has a lilting melody and lively rhythm. The disjunct melodic contour outlining triadic intervals is set to a four-measure rhythmic pattern which is repeated throughout the first part. Although the rhythmic pattern changes in the second part, the new pattern is similarly treated. Written in the major mode, it modulates briefly to the minor as the text becomes more serious and implores eternal love.The lyrics are light and flirtatious:

Kataka-takang mahibang

Ang katulad ko sa iyo

Biro-biro ang simula

Ang wakas pala ay ano.

Aayaw-ayaw pa ako

Ngunit ’yan ay di totoo

Dahil sa iyo, puso kong ito’y

Binihag mo.

(How strange that someone like me

Should go mad over someone like you

It all started as a joke

But look where it has led us.

I was hesitant at first

But that was just a front

Because of you, this heart of mine

Has been captivated.)

The song was sung by Rogelio de la Rosa and Norma Blancaflor in Victory Joe, a 1946 movie produced by LVN Pictures. Emmanuel Laureola’s arrangement for the Philippine Madrigal Singers is popular among choral groups today. In 1997 they performed the song during their concert tour to Europe and recorded it live in Italy. In 1992, Redentor L. Romero arranged the song for two voices in 50 Immortal Filipino Duets, published by the National Philharmonic Society of the Philippines. In 1996, he arranged and conducted the song with the Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra. The song is included in his CD album Damdaming Pinoy (Filipino Feelings), recorded in Moscow, Russia. The song was arranged for piano duet in four hands by Augusto Espino and published in Seleksiyon (Selection), a collection of his pedagogical pieces based on Filipino folk songs in 2002. It was performed in Guhit Tugtugin at Seleksyon (Piano Sketches and Selections) by Nita Abrogar Quinto. In 2015, Ryan Cayabyab included his orchestral arrangement of the song as performed by the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra in the CD Serenata of the Cultural Center of the Philippines.  Written by Corazon C. Dioquino, updated by James C. Diaz

photos.desc:
Hajji Alejandro singing at the Metro Manila Popular Music Festival, 1978

(Photo courtesy of Hajji Alejandro)

text:
(How Beautiful Is Our Music). 1978. Music and lyrics, Ryan Cayabyab. First performed by Hajji Alejandro in the First Metro Manila Popular Music Festival in 1978 where it won the grand prize. Also in 1978, Alejandro and Cayabyab won the Best Singer and Best Composer awards, respectively, with both also bagging the prestigious Grand Prix award at the First Annual Seoul International Song Festival.

 

Acclaimed as an opportune piece of musical creation, the song exalts the emergence of Filipino nationalism in music. It describes in metaphorical language the beautiful experience of discovering the gift of song. The chorus, endowed with powerful recall, emphatically expresses national pride in the music of one’s own homeland. Its refrain has become famous:

Kay ganda ng ating musika

Kay ganda ng ating musika

Ito ay atin, sariling atin

At sa habang buhay, awitin natin.

(How beautiful is our music

How beautiful is our music

It is ours, our very own

And as long as we live, let us sing.)

The Metropop festival, held at the Folk Arts Theater and sponsored by the Popular Music Foundation of the Philippines, carried the rallying cry “Today’s Hits, Tomorrow’s Classics.” From its initial performance, the song has been performed by individual singers and choralgroups and has been arranged for orchestra as well. The song is included in Alejandro’s third long-playing album also titled Kay Ganda ng Ating Musika.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes

text:
1920. Music, Bonifacio Abdon; lyrics, Patricio Mariano.

 

“Kundiman” was written for Bogumil Sykora, Russian cellist and conductor who wanted to conduct a Filipino piece for his concert for the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas. The three-part piece with lyrics by Abdon’s brother-in-law is based on the folk song “Kundiman de 1800” (Kundiman of 1800). It is popularly known as “Kundiman ni Abdon” (Abdon’s Kundiman) to distinguish it from all others. In the 1980s, it was turned into a protest song titled “Mutya” (Muse). The original lyrics of the song run:

Sa tapat ng laging palangiting araw

Na lumalaganap sa dagat Silangan

May Mutyang masuyo’t libid kayamanan

Na giliw ang handog sa pusong may damdam.

Oh! Bayang maligaya ng aking paggiliw

Pusong lakambini kalong salamisim

Ang iyong pagluha’y sandaling pigilin…

Ang Kundimang ito! Mutya iyong dinggin.

Bulaklak ng aking laging pinithaya

Ang ikaw makitang may sariling laya’t

Aa dagat Silanga’y butihing diwata,

Mayama’t mapuri, bihis sa dalita.

(Beneath the ever-smiling sun

That shines throughout the Eastern Ocean

There’s a loving and precious Muse

Who eases the anguished heart.

Oh! Joyful land of my affection

The heart of a lady cuddled in my memory

Hold your tears for a moment

And listen, my Muse, to this kundiman.

Flower of my constant adoration

To see you finally free

Kindred nymph of the Eastern Ocean

Humbly dressed, yet brimming with dignity.) Written by Antonio C. Hila

article.value: 1920. Music, Bonifacio Abdon; lyrics, Patricio Mariano.

“Kundiman” was written for Bogumil Sykora, Russian cellist and conductor who wanted to conduct a Filipino piece for his concert for the Asociacion Musical de Filipinas. The three-part piece with lyrics by Abdon’s brother-in-law is based on the folk song “Kundiman de 1800” (Kundiman of 1800). It is popularly known as “Kundiman ni Abdon” (Abdon’s Kundiman) to distinguish it from all others. In the 1980s, it was turned into a protest song titled “Mutya” (Muse). The original lyrics of the song run:
Sa tapat ng laging palangiting araw
Na lumalaganap sa dagat Silangan
May Mutyang masuyo’t libid kayamanan
Na giliw ang handog sa pusong may damdam.
Oh! Bayang maligaya ng aking paggiliw
Pusong lakambini kalong salamisim
Ang iyong pagluha’y sandaling pigilin…
Ang Kundimang ito! Mutya iyong dinggin.
Bulaklak ng aking laging pinithaya
Ang ikaw makitang may sariling laya’t
Aa dagat Silanga’y butihing diwata,
Mayama’t mapuri, bihis sa dalita.
(Beneath the ever-smiling sun
That shines throughout the Eastern Ocean
There’s a loving and precious Muse
Who eases the anguished heart.
Oh! Joyful land of my affection
The heart of a lady cuddled in my memory
Hold your tears for a moment
And listen, my Muse, to this kundiman.
Flower of my constant adoration
To see you finally free
Kindred nymph of the Eastern Ocean
Humbly dressed, yet brimming with dignity.) Written by Antonio C. Hila

photos.desc:
Scene from Lamberto V. Avellana’s Anak Dalita, 1956, which used
“Kundiman/Anak-Dalita” as theme song (Photo courtesy of Simon Santos/Video 48)

text:
(Kundiman, Child of Woe). 1917. Music, Francisco Santiago; lyrics, Deogracias A. Rosario; Spanish text, Jesus Balmori.

 

A cancion Filipina, “Kundiman” is written as a serenade. Based on Rosario’s poignant poem, it is also known as “Ako’y Anak ng Dalita” (I Am a Child of Woe). The work is noted for its simplicity and intimacy. Originally scored for piano, violin, and voice, the work, like Santiago’s other kundiman, is a powerful piece. This is regarded as the first art song-kundiman, and makes Francisco Santiago the “father of kundiman as art song.” In the typically romantic words of Rosario, the heartsick lover pleads for the beloved to show him her face and let her heart fall on him to relieve his suffering.

Ako’y anak ng dalita

Na tigib ngluha

Ang naritong humihibik

Na bigyan ng awa.

(I am a child of woe

Drowning in tears

I am here pleading

For your pity.)

The song culminates with a heart-rending finale:

Sa dilim ng gabi

Aking nilalamay

Tanging larawan mo

Ang nagiging ilaw.

Kung ikaw ay mahimbing

Sa gitna ng dilim

Ay iyong ihulog

Puso mo sa akin.

(In the darkness of the night

I have held my vigil

Only your image

Provides me with light.)

If you should fall into a deep sleep

In the middle of the darkness

Let your heart

Fall on me.)

In 1956, Lamberto Avellana used this song as the theme for the LVN movie also called Anak Dalita (The Ruins). Here the title referred to the urban poor who lived a hand-to-mouth existence in the ruins of old Intramuros right after World War II.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes

Sheet music cover of “Kundiman ng Luha,” 1924, dedicated by
Nicanor Abelardo to Atang de la Rama (Atang de la Rama Collection)

text:
(Kundiman of Tears). 1924. Music, Nicanor S. Abelardo; lyrics, Jose Corazon de Jesus.

 

Dedicated to the Samahang Bulakan, this kundiman was published in 1925, and later republished in the second edition of A Selection of Abelardo’s Immortal Kundimans in 1949. It was first recorded by Galia Arellano. Later in 1954, Italian tenor Arrigo Pola recorded it with the Philippine Recording System Inc.

For his kundiman, Abelardo drew inspiration from a friend’s personal experience that he shared with the composer. Thus, like his other kundiman, the work is intensely personal. It is perceived as a perfect merging of text and music, an exemplary union of words and melody achieved because of the composer’s close empathy with the lyrics.

The song begins in the minor mode as the disconsolate lover in the throes of despair pleads for the beloved’s attention. The song seems to sigh expressively, agonizingly, until the tonality shifts to a more optimistic one, and the promise of eternal love is declared.

The song’s last stanza is a classic:

Iladlad mo ang panyo mong may pabango

Papahirin ko ang luha ng puso ko

Ah pag-ibig, kung ang “Oo” mo ay matamo

Ah pag-ibig, kung ang “Oo” mo ay matamo

Hanggang sa hukay, hanggang sa hukay

Magkasama, ikaw at ako.

(Unfold your perfumed kerchief

I will wipe away my heart’s tears

Ah, beloved, if I win your love

Ah, beloved, if I win your love

Unto the grave, unto the grave

We will be together, you and I.)

“Kundiman ng Luha” was the theme song of an LVN movie directed by Lamberto Avellana titled Kundiman ng Lahi (Kundiman of the Race), 1959, which starred Charito Solis and Eddie Rodriguez.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes

photos.desc:
“Kung Ako na Lang Sana” popularized by singer
Bituin Escalante, 2015 (Photo courtesy of
Kimberly Pauig/UPAA Maroon Pride)

text:
(If It Were Me). 2002. Music and lyrics, Soc Villanueva. First performed by Bituin Escalante in the 2002 Himig Handog Pinoy Pop Love Songs, a songwriting and music video competition organized by ABS-CBN and its music subsidiary, Star Music. The song is included in Bituin Escalante’s first self-titled album released in 2003 by Star Records.

 

The song is in the rhythm and blues pop style of the period. Musically, the song is structured in the “32-bar” verse-chorus format (8+8+16 bars). Its melody, however, hovers fluidly on top of the grid of harmonic progression in both the verses and chorus. The protagonist of the song is a woman who is secretly pining for her friend. She belts out her unrequited love in the chorus, promising the unsuspecting friend her waiting and hopeful heart. This passion intensifies toward the repeat of the chorus, particularly in a climactic section which modulates a key up. From then on, the music demands more from the singer-storyteller who responds by exhibiting “belting,” voluptuous melismatic endings that are a hallmark of rhythm and blues singing.

The song was made into a movie of the same title directed by Jose Javier Reyes in 2003. It was also covered by Sarah Geronimo, and her version was included in the soundtrack of the primetime television series Pangarap na Bituin (Dream of Stardom), 2007, aired in ABS-CBN.

“Kung Ako Na Lang Sana” won the grand prize in the 2002 Himig Handog Pinoy Pop Love Songs, with Escalante also bagging the Best Interpreter of a Song award. In the 2003 Awit Awards, the song received the following recognition: Best Produced Record of the Year, Best Pop Recording, and Best Performance by a Female Recording Artist.  Written by Jose S. Buenconsejo

text:
1995. Music, Ramon P. Santos. Commissioned by the Association for Southeast Asian Nations Committee on Culture and Information (ASEAN-COCI) and premiered in Bangkok, Thailand in 1995. Subsequent performances followed, notably in Manila, 1997, and in Tokyo, 2014. Scoring is for standard orchestra of woodwinds, brass, three percussions, piano, harp, and strings. Duration is 16 minutes.

 

The title is derived from the word lebad of the Yakan of Basilan Island and refers to the smallest musical unit in the structure of tagunggo instrumental music. But while the Yakan musical practice of building from lebad musical units relate to an oral tradition in Southeast Asia, Santos developed this as a basic musical unit for a fully written-out piece for a standard concert orchestra.

The piece opens with three- and four-note musical cells, based on the scale structure “re-(mi)-fa-sol-la” first emerging from the strings and punctuated by percussion sounds. The pitches emanating from the strings are extended to the brass and woodwind instruments and develop the whole sound palette into a variety of colors as the music unfolds. The variety of “permutations of basic cells” relate to a compositional process, which, as mentioned above, appropriates the lebad system. A screen of high-pitched bowed-string sounds (a la Ligeti) ushers a subsequent section in measure #110, where a rhythmic figure on percussion and brass instruments emerges in opposition to the opening section. However, the most notable part of the piece begins in measure numbers 181-182, emerging from the oboe solo and the harp, ushering in a new section rather more “tranquil” in character. It is notable in this section how the same process of juxtapositions and layering of basic cells is maintained, as prevalent in the section starting from measure number 224. The music sinks into more agitated percussion sounds as the piece comes to a close.  Written by Jonas U. Baes

photos.desc: The Manila Symphony Orchestra performing Lahing Kayumanggi, 2010 (Manila Symphony Orchestra)

text:
(Brown Race). 1962. Music, Lucio D. San Pedro. Commissioned by the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines. Recipient of the Republic Cultural Heritage Award, 1962.

 

A tone poem dedicated to those who fought against colonialism, the piece builds upon the first four notes of the folk song “Bahay Kubo” (Nipa Hut). San Pedro explained his use of the nipa hut, a symbol of the common person: “In my works, I have always attempted to immortalize the virtues and aspirations of the masses who I believe are the pillars of our nation … I want them to be revered, and as such, the manner of emulating them cannot be done through a vulgar or popular approach, but rather through utmost creativity.” (Hila 2013)

The work has four parts. The first, Larghetto throbs to the tender yet aggressive rhythm of the kumintang, evoking the pathos of the lowly and oppressed. In the main body, marked Allegro animato con eleganza, the theme twists and turns, reflecting the joyful life of the simple country folk despite their poverty and hardship. A contemplative section follows in Largo ma non troppo con somma fervore, expressing fervent thanksgiving after a day in the fields. This is followed by a section in a lilting, lighthearted mood reflecting happiness and prosperity suggesting an idyllic period before the colonizers occupied the land and trampled on the people’s dignity. In the final section, the folk theme is plaintively reiterated and intoned by the French horn. The theme swells to a Grandioso and Allargando section in all its majesty to suggest that the power of the Filipino soul prevails.

The piece continues to be a favorite among bands and orchestras. It has been recently performed by the University of the Philippines (UP) Symphonic Band under Rodney Ambat’s direction at the UP Abelardo Hall Auditorium in 2011, by the Citizens’ Brigade Band of Dasmariñas in the same year, by BYB 83 and Binangonan Banda Central No. 1 in 2012, and by the Pampanga Provincial Capitol Band in 2013. The piece also has a symphonic version performed by the Manila Symphony Orchestra in 2014. The work was recorded by the FilHarmoniker Orchestra in 2006 and released in the compact disc titled Musika Natin (Our Music), a Song Stream Record distributed by Sony-BMG Music Entertainment.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by Josephine Cecilia L. Baradas

Source

 

Hila, Antonio C. 2013. “Remembering Maestro Lucio D. San Pedro, the Creative Nationalist.” Philippine Daily Inquirer, 10 Feb. http://lifestyle.inquirer.net/89325/remembering

photos.desc: Mike Hanopol performing at Ang Pagkalas: The Juan de la Cruz Reunion Concert, Manila, 2005 (Mari Arquiza)

text:
(Spoiled Brat). 1977. Music and lyrics, Mike Hanopol. First sung by Mike Hanopol.

Mike Hanopol composed “Laki sa Layaw (Jeproks)” during the heyday of Pinoy rock in the 1970s. Hanopol was one of the original members of the rock group Juan de la Cruz Band in the early 1970s, together with Joey “Pepe” Smith and Wally Gonzales. In 1977, he broke his ties with the group and carved a name for himself via his album Buhay Musikero (Musician’s Life), and the hit single “Laki sa Layaw,” contained in a later album Awiting Pilipino (Filipino Songs).

“Jeproks” is the reverse of “Project,” a reference to the youth who come from the middle- to low-income housing projects of the government, e.g., Project 2 and 3 (Quirino District). The term was widely used in the late 1960s and 1970s, tagged as the “Jeproks” era. Later, the term could mean anything—a lumpen rocker, a drug-dazed hippie, a flamboyantly dressed rebel, or a plain enfant terrible. The song remains one of the more enduring examples of Pinoy mellow rock.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes

text:
(The Portrait). 1943. Music, Francisco Buencamino Sr.

Along with the three-movement piece for piano and orchestra Mayon, “Ang Larawan” is one of more popular Francisco Buencamino works for solo piano. Leopoldo Querol, a Spanish pianist, performed the piece in 1947 in Meycauayan, Bulacan. It was published by Rhapsody Music House in 1943 and by the Philippine Music Publishers in 1949.

 

The music is based on the folk music genre balitaw. In three-part form (ABA1), the piece is characterized by variations, distant key shifts, and sequential expansion of melodic fragments. It gravitates towards the simple tonic-dominant harmonic pattern, but the pianistic treatment is the opposite. The arpeggios, sixths, and octaves test the technical prowess of the pianist. The closing section of the piece, for example, is reminiscent of Lisztian pianistic writing where syncopated chords, arpeggios, and chromatic octave passages signal the inevitable resolve to C major.

Recent interest in “Ang Larawan” was sparked by Cecile Licad’s superb performance of the piece in international and local concerts. Licad, a granddaughter of the composer, regularly programs “Ang Larawan” as an encore in her concerts. Adolovni Acosta, a Philippine-born pianist, recorded it in her album Malagueña: Piano Music from Cuba and the Philippines under Orion Master Recordings label.  Written by Raul C. Navarro

photos.desc: Movie poster of Leron-Leron Sinta, 1964 (Photo courtesy of Simon Santos/Video 48)

text:
(Leron-leron Beloved). Tagalog folk song.

Known to practically every school child, this traditional Tagalog folk song is a polka set in a lively duple-time rhythm. The rhythmic patterns of each of the four music phrases are identical. The melody moves stepwise throughout, covering a limited range of a fifth. Except for the last phrase, the first three begin with a similar motif. The lilting rhythm of the song matches the light-hearted mood of the three-stanza text which is made up of seemingly unrelated, rhyming phrases.

 

The courting song contains allusions to unfulfilled love, a search for a new love, and the building of a masculine image. Its opening stanza is famous:

Leron-leron sinta

Buko ng papaya

Dala-dala’y buslo

Sisidlan ng bunga

Pagdating sa dulo

Nabali ang sanga

Kapus kapalaran

Humanap ng iba.

(Leron-leron beloved

Bud of papaya

Carrying a basket

A container for fruits

Upon reaching the top

The branch broke

The unfortunate one

Looked for another.)

Choral arrangements are numerous, including a four-part harmonization by Francisco Santiago and a soprano-alto-tenor-bass arrangement with piano accompaniment by Lucio D. San Pedro. Constancio de Guzman used it as one of the musical numbers in Sampaguita Pictures’s Leron-Leron Sinta, 1964.  Written by Corazon C. Dioquino

article.value: The courting song contains allusions to unfulfilled love, a search for a new love, and the building of a masculine image. Its opening stanza is famous:
Leron-leron sinta
Buko ng papaya
Dala-dala’y buslo
Sisidlan ng bunga
Pagdating sa dulo
Nabali ang sanga
Kapus kapalaran
Humanap ng iba.
(Leron-leron beloved
Bud of papaya
Carrying a basket
A container for fruits
Upon reaching the top
The branch broke
The unfortunate one
Looked for another.)

Choral arrangements are numerous, including a four-part harmonization by Francisco Santiago and a soprano-alto-tenor-bass arrangement with piano accompaniment by Lucio D. San Pedro. Constancio de Guzman used it as one of the musical numbers in Sampaguita Pictures’s Leron-Leron Sinta, 1964.  Written by Corazon C. Dioquino

text:
1951. Music, Eliseo M. Pajaro. First performed by the Eastman-Rochester Symphony Orchestra in the United States in May 1951 with Howard Hanson conducting. Premiered in the Philippines by the Manila Symphony Orchestra (MSO) in 1954 under the baton of Dr Herbert Zipper.

 

Pajaro composed the symphonic legend The Life of Lam-ang for orchestra while still a composition student at the Eastman School of Music, University of Rochester in New York. Based on the Ilocano epic Biag ni Lam-ang (Life of Lam-ang), the work uses Philippine folk songs as thematic materials. Described as “most original and mature” by ethnomusicologist William P. Malm, the work brims with exotic and expressive color, and unconventional and discordant sounds produced by the fusion of unusual timbres and instrumental combinations such as piccolo, bass drums, and gong.

In 1955, it was performed by the MSO for the First Southeast Asia Regional Music Conference with conductor Bernardino F. Custodio and by the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra with conductor Thor Johnson. The National Symphony Orchestra of New Zealand also performed the piece in 1959, this time with conductor John Hopkins. Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes

photos.desc:
Album cover of Eraserheads’ Ultraelectromagneticpop!,

1989, which includes “Ligaya” (BMG Records)

text:
(Happiness). 1989-1993. Music and lyrics, Ely Buendia. Performed by Eraserheads (aka Eheads) featuring lead singer Ely Buendia with Raymund Marasigan (drums and percussion), Buddy Zabala (bass guitar), and Marcus Adoro (guitar). This song was included in the Eraserheads debut studio album titled Ultraelectromagneticpop! Produced by Eraserheads and Ed Formoso with recording engineer Willie Munji, the album was released by BMG Records (label Musiko Records) in Jul 1993.

 

“Ligaya” is about a college male student who wonders why his object of desire has not taken an interest in him despite his attempt to catch her attention. Growing impatient, the boy promises happiness, peace, and love. Though his love is unrequited, the song’s persona does not project sentimentality nor frustration, but speaks in a natural, “truthful,” candid manner, drawing attention to the ordinary experience of a student in college (presumably the setting of the song is a neighborhood near a university) and the images associated with it, such as t-shirts, street food (isaw or fried chicken intestines), bottled soft-drink caps (tansan) that are counted as days passed, thesis writing, and shaving. The song is appealing because of its unpretentiousness as well as the catchiness of the lyrics in terms of its textual rhythm and the rhymes of the verses. These poetic devices project a youthful exhuberance that young audiences have not ceased to appreciate since its first performance.

The appeal of the song is due to the raw voices of Eraserheads and, musically, in its light, easy-to-follow beat. After the eight-bar introduction with sampled handclaps that invite bodily response from the listeners, the song is patterned after a modified “32-bar” pop song form (verse-verse-bridge-chorus). However, the count of measures is not strictly followed. In fact, the song displays more ingenuity than formula, especially in the truncations of the bridge section which makes a sudden, albeit awkward, unprepared direct modulation to an unrelated key. Even if the melody in this bridge section is difficult to follow, the total effect is rhetorical for it paints a feeling of impatience—a rush—to the theme of unending happiness, which is the message of the chorus.

This song, together with other hits like “Toyang” and “Pare Ko” (My Friend) had a strong impact in the local music scene, in particular, in the revival of Pinoy rock in that decade. The album was released again, along with other Eraserheads albums, in 2008. Prior to this, singer-songwriter Kitchie Nadal did a cover of “Ligaya” for the Eraserheads tribute album, Ultraelectromagneticjam! The Music of the Eraserheads, released in 2005.  Written by Jose S. Buenconsejo

text:
(Nature-ing). 1978. Music, Ramon P. Santos. Composed for the University of the Philippines 70th Anniversary Music Festival. First performed in 1978 at the Cultural Center of the Philippines back-to-back with Jose Maceda’s Ading.

 

Santos’s environmental New Music brims with sound forms that may be described as both musical and nonmusical, created by assorted sound categories from all kinds of instruments: the traditional such as the gong, the electronically generated such as the synthesizers and transistors, steel junk recycled into instruments such as the carillon, hammers, and nails, and the newly developed instruments such as the kantawayan and whistles.

Likas-an is improvisational in form. It may take on musical forms other than what the composer has prescribed to suit specific performance sites and occasions. The sounds are the natural result of the collaboration of human energy and nature. Performers need not be trained musicians. In 1978, non-academic personnel, carpenters, electricians, custodial workers as well as music students performed the piece. The use of untrained performers affirms Santos’s fascination with the interaction of human energies and the merging of natural forces, and the distinct musical structures that they can create. Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes

photos.desc: Poster of La Loba Negra, 1984 (CCP Collection)

text:
(The Black She-wolf). 1984. Music and musical direction, Francisco F. Feliciano; stage direction, Lamberto Avellana; scenario, Fides Cuyugan-Asensio; choral direction, Elmo Makil; choreography, Joji Felix-Velarde; production design and technical direction, Allan Cosio. Commissioned and produced by the Zarzuela Foundation of the Philippines. First performed in Aug 1984 at the Main Theater (now Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo), Cultural Center of the Philippines. Cast: Fides Cuyugan-Asensio, Eleanor Calbes, Jimmy Melendrez, Nolyn Cabahug, Gamaliel Viray, Elmo Makil, Lito Carating, Nomer Son, Amy Bonnevie, Jonathan Malicsi, Sal’My Neo Malaki, Ligaya Castillo Garcia, Joaquin Sanchez, and the Zarzuela Choral Ensemble. Accompanied by the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra with Francisco F. Feliciano conducting.

 

The three-act Filipino opera, based on a forgery attributed to Fr Jose Burgos, revolves around the grisly murder of the Spanish Gov-Gen Bustamante by the friars and the revenge exacted by his wife, Doña Luisa, dubbed “la loba negra” or the black she-wolf. The action is set in the 17th century against the backdrop of the corrupt colonial administration in the Philippines, which was dominated by the frailocracy. Bustamante, sent by Spain to take on the herculean task of instituting reforms in the administration, soon earns the ire of the friars, who then plot and execute his gory assassination. Acclaimed by critics as an extraordinary work of the 1980s, La Loba Negra contains all the ingredients for commercial success: magic, mystique, intrigue, corruption, romance and passion, revenge, and warfare.

The music, in a vibrant expressionist style, contains violent contrasts in pitch and instrumentation, rapidly shifting keys and meters, and vivid instrumental color, as heard in eerie wolf calls and forest sounds. Feliciano employs familiar Filipino melodies fused with 20th-century music. He uses the music of the provincial town banda and the pasyon chant as a leitmotif that links the three acts together and provides musical colors derived from Philippine folk music. The overall orchestration, cast within the harsh, atonal expressionist idiom, showcases different musical styles. Of interest is the lead soprano’s mad scene. Here, an incantation sung by the Mexican widow of Bustamante begins as a lullaby and later grows into a hair-raising vociferation, clashing head on with massive church music evoking pompous religiosity.

It was restaged in 1985, under the direction of Peque Gallaga and Jorge V. Ledesma.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by Josephine Cecilia L. Baradas

photos.desc:
Cassette jacket of Luha & Halik, 1995

(Alpha Records)

text:
(Tears). 1998. Music and lyrics, Celso Abenoja. First performed by Aegis featuring Juliet, Mercy, and Ken Sunot on vocals, Rey Abenoja on lead guitar, Stella Pabico on keyboards, Vilma Goloviogo on drums, and Rowena Adriano on bass guitar. The song is included in their album Halik (Kiss) under Alpha Records released in 1998.

 

“Luha” is the singer’s expression of resentment after finding out that her love for someone will never be reciprocated. The chorus reads:

Ikaw ay aking minahal

Kasama ko ang Maykapal

Ngunit ako pala’y naging isang hangal

Naghahangad ng isang katulad mo

(I loved you

as the Lord loves you

But I was a fool

Yearning to be with someone like you)

Introduced by a static chord in A major (the key of the piece), the song is structured on cyclical harmonic patterns such as A-E-D-E (the pattern that ends all the verses) and F-sharp minor-C-sharp minor-D-A (which sets the first melodic line of verse 3) and the chorus. The static harmonic underpinning of the song is also depicted by the one-chord-per-measure. By employing these devices, the song is reminiscent of late 17th century Baroque music.

In 2014, playwright Liza Magtoto wrote the musical Rak of Aegis, featuring Aegis’s songs, including their hit “Luha.” The play had a successful run, with repeat stagings in 2015 and 2016, and is now touted as the longest running original Filipino musical.

Halik, the album where “Luha” is included, received the Platinum Award in Apr 1999 from the Philippine Association of the Record Industry (PARI). It went on to receive Double Platinum in December of the same year, Triple Platinum in 2000, and Quadruple Platinum in 2002.  Written by Ariel Lev L. Pinzon, with notes from Jose S. Buenconsejo

text:
aka “Lolay.” This popular acculturated song and dance was documented in the 19th century in the Visayan region. In triple meter and in binary form and with text in dodecasyllabic quatrain, the song is sung by a male voice, courting a maiden. Graciano Lopez Jaena translated the text of “Lolay” from Iloilo in a music collection printed in Madrid in the 1890s, titled “Islas Filipinas: Cantares Visayos” (Philippine Islands: Visayan Songs). This “lolay” was a music transcription by A. Lopez Almagro. In Robustiano Echaus’s travelogue Apuntes de la Isla de Negros (Notes on the Island of Negros), 1894, the genre was defined as “song and dance of the country.”

 

The song and dance genre later spread to Manila and the song came to be known also as a traditional Tagalog serenade in balitaw style on a theme that is common to many Filipino love songs. Like the balitaw, the first part utilizes the same four-measure phrase throughout. The melody, beginning characteristically with a rapidly reiterated note, is repeated three times. The first repeat is exact, but the second moves up a fourth. The second part, based on a different rhythmic motive, has longer phrases (six measures) than those in the first part.

The first stanza of the text tells of the difficulties encountered in trying to win the heart of a shy and modest maiden. The mood changes in the second stanza which expresses the great joy in winning such a precious maiden.

The melody was quoted in Jose A. Estella’s symphonic poem based on Rizal’s Mi Ultimo Adios (My Last Farewell), 1929, and appeared in Emilia S. Reysio-Cruz’s Filipino Folk Songs, 1950, with four-part harmonization by Francisco Santiago. Lucio D. San Pedro arranged it for solo and four-part chorus in Philippine Choruses for All Occasions, 1953. Many composers have used the song as thematic material. Among them is Francisco Santiago, who used it as the second theme of the first movement of his Taga-ilog Symphony in D major. Nicanor S. Abelardo used “Lulay” as the main theme of Visayan Caprice for piano, violin, and violoncello. Other works based on the tune include Francisco Buencamino’s Brisas de mi patria (Breezes of my Fatherland), Manuel de Cueva’s Lulay, Alfonsa Doronilla’s Philippine Rhapsody, and Antonio J. Molina’s Lulay for string orchestra, piano, and indigenous percussion instruments, like kulintang, gabbang, neguet, gimbal, and gangsa.  Written by Corazon C. Dioquino, updated by Jose S. Buenconsejo

text:
(Philippine National Hymn, Land Dear and Holy). 1898. Music, Julian Felipe; lyrics, Jose Isaac Velasquez Palma. English translations by Paz Marquez Benitez, Camilo Osias, and M.A. Lane. Filipino translation by the Department of Education, 1956. Commissioned by Emilio Aguinaldo. First performed by Banda San Francisco de Malabon (now General Trias) in Kawit, Cavite, on the occasion of the declaration of Philippine independence on 12 Jun 1898.

 

The manuscript of the composition bore the heading “Marcha Filipina Nacional” (Philippine National March) although it was also known as the “Marcha Filipino Magdalo” (Philippine Magdalo March), Magdalo being Aguinaldo’s nom-de-guerre. Gen Emilio Aguinaldo and some leaders of the 1896 Revolution liked Felipe’s work, and after a brief discussion, suggested that it be officially adopted as the Philippine national anthem. Some scholars aver that the music of the anthem shows the influence of the Spanish and French national anthems.

A year after the melody was composed, Palma wrote a poem, “Filipinas, Letra Para La Marcha Nacional” (Philippines, Lyrics for the National March), which was published on 3 Sep 1899 in La Independencia, the official organ of the Philippine revolution edited by Antonio Luna. The poem became the lyrics of the national anthem. The “Himno” was reportedly first sung by the staff of the newspaper.

In 1906, the wife of Fernando Canon, Teresa Battle, commissioned a composer to use the melody of the marcha in nine-sectioned piano variations in popular music style and published this in Madrid in a piece titled “A Rizal: Lirismo Patriotico” (To Rizal: Patriotic Lyricism). In 1928, Alexander Lippay, then director of the University of the Philippines Conservatory of Music, composed a complicated symphonic work titled Thirteen Variations on the Philippine National Hymn, based on the melody of the march.

In 1943, then president Jose P. Laurel ordered the Institute of National Language to translate the original Spanish text into Filipino and English. The first stanza of the original Spanish text, the Filipino translation (then titled “Diwang Bayan” or National Ideal), and the English translation, are as follows:

 

SPANISH

Tierra adorada

Hija del sol de Oriente

Su fuego ardiente

En ti latiendo esta.

 

FILIPINO

Lupang mapalad na mutya ng Silangan

Bayang kasuyo ng sangkalikasan

Buhay at yaman ng Kapilipinuhan

Kuha’t bawi na sa banyagang kamay.

 

ENGLISH

Land of the morning

Child of the sun returning

With fervor burning

Thee do our souls adore.

In 1956, the Department of Education formed a committee of musicians, writers, and technical staff of various government departments which sat down to create a more spontaneous and apt Filipino translation of the anthem. The result was “Lupang Hinirang.” Under Presidential Proclamation No 60 that took effect on 19 Dec 1963, this Filipino version of the Palma text became the official anthem of the Philippines that is sung to the present. It runs:

Lupang Hinirang

Bayang magiliw

Perlas ng Silanganan

Alab ng puso

Sa dibdib mo’y buhay

Lupang hinirang

Duyan ka ng magiting

Sa manlulupig

Di ka pasisiil

Sa dagat at bundok

Sa simoy at sa langit mong bughaw

May dilag ang tula at awit

Sa paglayang minamahal

Ang kislap ng watawat mo’y

Tagumpay na nagniningning

Ang bituin at araw niya

Kailanpama’y di magdidilim

Lupa ng araw, ng luwalhalti’t pagsinta

Buhay ay langit sa piling mo

Aming ligaya na pag may mang-aapi

Ang mamatay nang dahil sa iyo.

(Land of the morning,

Child of the sun returning,

With fervor burning

Thee do our souls adore

Land dear and holy,

Cradle of noble heroes,

Ne’er shall invaders

Trample thy sacred shore

Ever within thy skies and through thy clouds,

And o’er thy hills and seas,

Do we behold the radiance, feel the throb

Of glorious liberty

Thy banner dear to all our hearts,

Its sun and stars alight,

O, never shall its shining field

Be dimmed by tyrants’ might

Beautiful land of love, O, land of light,

In thine embrace ‘tis rapture to lie,

But it is glory ever, when thou art wronged

or us, thy sons, to suffer and die.) Written by Antonio C. Hila, updated by Jose S. Buenconsejo

A year after the melody was composed, Palma wrote a poem, “Filipinas, Letra Para La Marcha Nacional” (Philippines, Lyrics for the National March), which was published on 3 Sep 1899 in La Independencia, the official organ of the Philippine revolution edited by Antonio Luna. The poem became the lyrics of the national anthem. The “Himno” was reportedly first sung by the staff of the newspaper.

In 1906, the wife of Fernando Canon, Teresa Battle, commissioned a composer to use the melody of the marcha in nine-sectioned piano variations in popular music style and published this in Madrid in a piece titled “A Rizal: Lirismo Patriotico” (To Rizal: Patriotic Lyricism). In 1928, Alexander Lippay, then director of the University of the Philippines Conservatory of Music, composed a complicated symphonic work titled Thirteen Variations on the Philippine National Hymn, based on the melody of the march.

In 1943, then president Jose P. Laurel ordered the Institute of National Language to translate the original Spanish text into Filipino and English. The first stanza of the original Spanish text, the Filipino translation (then titled “Diwang Bayan” or National Ideal), and the English translation, are as follows:
SPANISH
Tierra adorada
Hija del sol de Oriente
Su fuego ardiente
En ti latiendo esta.
FILIPINO
Lupang mapalad na mutya ng Silangan
Bayang kasuyo ng sangkalikasan
Buhay at yaman ng Kapilipinuhan
Kuha’t bawi na sa banyagang kamay.
ENGLISH
Land of the morning
Child of the sun returning
With fervor burning
Thee do our souls adore.

In 1956, the Department of Education formed a committee of musicians, writers, and technical staff of various government departments which sat down to create a more spontaneous and apt Filipino translation of the anthem. The result was “Lupang Hinirang.” Under Presidential Proclamation No 60 that took effect on 19 Dec 1963, this Filipino version of the Palma text became the official anthem of the Philippines that is sung to the present. It runs:
Lupang Hinirang
Bayang magiliw
Perlas ng Silanganan
Alab ng puso
Sa dibdib mo’y buhay
Lupang hinirang
Duyan ka ng magiting
Sa manlulupig
Di ka pasisiil
Sa dagat at bundok
Sa simoy at sa langit mong bughaw
May dilag ang tula at awit
Sa paglayang minamahal
Ang kislap ng watawat mo’y
Tagumpay na nagniningning
Ang bituin at araw niya
Kailanpama’y di magdidilim
Lupa ng araw, ng luwalhalti’t pagsinta
Buhay ay langit sa piling mo
Aming ligaya na pag may mang-aapi
Ang mamatay nang dahil sa iyo.
(Land of the morning,
Child of the sun returning,
With fervor burning
Thee do our souls adore
Land dear and holy,
Cradle of noble heroes,
Ne’er shall invaders
Trample thy sacred shore
Ever within thy skies and through thy clouds,
And o’er thy hills and seas,
Do we behold the radiance, feel the throb
Of glorious liberty
Thy banner dear to all our hearts,
Its sun and stars alight,
O, never shall its shining field
Be dimmed by tyrants’ might
Beautiful land of love, O, land of light,
In thine embrace ‘tis rapture to lie,
But it is glory ever, when thou art wronged
or us, thy sons, to suffer and die.) Written by Antonio C. Hila, updated by Jose S. Buenconsejo

photos.desc:
Carmen Rosales and Rogelio dela Rosa in

Maalala Mo Kaya, 1954 (Cesar Hernando Collection)

text:
(Will You Remember?). 1940. Music and lyrics, Constancio de Guzman.

 

Set in the slow duple time of the danza which was popular for the harana (serenade), this song has three parts, with the lovers answering each other in the second part. The song expresses a couple’s enduring promise of love for each other, a love that will transcend time and death. The opening stanza of the song goes:

Maalaala mo kaya

Ang sumpa mo sa akin

Na ang pag-ibig mo ay

Sadyang di magmamaliw.

(Will you remember

Your promise to me

That your love

Will never end.)

The most celebrated rendition of this song was done by Carmen Rosales and Rogelio de la Rosa in the 1954 movie of the same title produced by Sampaguita Pictures. A number of musical artists have included this song in their record albums, among them, Pilita Corrales, Carmen Soriano, the Mabuhay Singers, Celeste Legaspi, Dulce, and Ryan Cayabyab who recorded this song in his one-person performance repertoire, One.

The song is now more known as MMK, after the long-running TV drama anthology produced by ABS-CBN beginning in 1991, hosted by Charo Santos-Concio. It also inspired Star Cinema to produce Maalaala Mo Kaya: The Movie, 1994, starring Aiko Melendez and Chin Chin Gutierrez and directed by Olivia M. Lamasan.

Alfredo S. Buenaventura arranged the song for two voices in 50 Immortal Filipino Duets, 1992, published by the National Philharmonic Society of the Philippines. In 1996, Redentor L. Romero arranged the song for the Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra. The song is included in his CD album Damdaming Pinoy (Filipino Feelings), recorded in Moscow, Russia. Ryan Cayabyab’s arrangement of the song for the San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra was performed by Basil Valdez and accompanied by the same orchestra in the CD album Great Filipino Love Songs, 2004.  Written by Antonio C. Hila, updated by James C. Diaz

photos.desc: Print ad for Madaling Araw, 1938 (Photo courtesy of Simon Santos/Video 48)

text:
(Dawn). Circa 1920s. Music, Francisco Santiago; lyrics, Jose Corazon de Jesus (Tagalog) and Jesus Balmori (Spanish). Arrangement for orchestra, Eliseo M. Pajaro and Hilarion F. Rubio.

 

Considered one of the most beautiful art song-kundiman, it is a fervent plea for love:

Irog ko’y dinggin ang tibok ng puso,

Sana’y damdamin hirap ng sumuyo.

Manong itunghay ang matang mapungay

Na siyang tanging ilaw ng buhay kong papanaw.

(Beloved, hear the throb of my heart,

Feel the anguish of this man in love.

Look at me through your languid eyes

The only light of my vanishing life.)

The music, doleful and tender at first, swells toward a passionate climax that ends with the sonorous clashing of chords. Santiago draws out every nuance of romantic love with his meticulous tempo markings. Mike Velarde Jr used this song as the theme for a 1938 movie of the same title produced by Sampaguita Pictures which starred singer-actors Elsa Oria and Ely Ramos.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes

photos.desc:
Album cover of Yoyoy Villame’s The Best of Yoyoy Villame

Volume 1, 1997, which includes “Magellan” (Vicor Records)

text:
1972. Music and lyrics, Yoyoy Villame. First recorded by the composer in 1972 for Vicor Records.

 

Yoyoy Villame’s light commentary on Philippine history is best exemplified in his song “Magellan.” Written in the traditional ballad style, this novelty song in fast duple time narrates the accidental “discovery” of the Philippines by Ferdinand Magellan in 1521, and his bloody duel with the fierce Cebuano hero Lapulapu that led to his death. Unlike most colonial history books, the ballad is written from the point of view not of the Spanish conquistador but of the native hero.

The song derives its humor from the nursery-rhyme-like lyrics of Villame and his characteristically crisp and thick Visayan accent. The opening stanza goes:

On March sixteen fifteen hundred twenty-one,

When Philippines was discovered by Magellan,

They were sailing day and night

Across the big ocean

And he saw a small Limasawa island.

This song has enjoyed tremendous popularity among the masses, who see in it a continuation of the native ballad tradition. Light and humorous, “Magellan” has inspired other composers to use the ballad form in their own songs.  Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian

text:
(Make a Start). 1978. Music and lyrics, Gines Tan. First recorded by Leo Valdez. Popularized by Dio Marco who essayed the lead role in Magsimula Ka, the Musicale.

 

The song is in the pop style. Cast in A major, it follows the AABA musical form. The A part quickens its tempo as it approaches the B part. The song ends with a repeated B part, whose last two lines are also repeated.

In 1986, Magsimula Ka, the Musicale, a full-length musical drama with this as the title song, was performed at the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Part of the song’s success is its simple message: your life is yours, make the most of it. The chorus section is particularly inspiring:

Iisa lang ang buhay mo,

Kumilos ka, gamitin mo,

Kung may nais ang puso mo,

Mangarap ka, abutin mo,

Upang ito’y makamit mo,

Magsikap ka, simulan mo.

(You’ve only got one life to live,

Act now, make full use of it,

If your heart is set on something,

Aspire to reach it,

So that you’ll achieve it,

Strive hard, start now.)

Due to its encouraging message, “Magsimula Ka” has since been performed countless times, with recent performances by well known local artists like Regine Velasquez, Isay Alvarez, and Lea Salonga. The song has a choral arrangement by Ed Nepomuceno, and was performed by the UP Concert Chorus during their world tour in 1997, and the UP Manila Chorale during their world tour in 2007.

The piece won Song of the Year in the First Cecil Award (First Philippine Music Industry Award) in Apr 1982; grand prize, best composition in the First ASEAN Song Festival in Jun 1981; and third prize, Fourth Metro Manila Popular Music Festival in Apr 1981.  Written by Milagros Carunungan, updated by James C. Diaz

photos.desc:
Rice planting to the rhythm of a small band

(Le Tour du Monde: Nouveau Journal des Voyages by Edouard Charton. Librairie de L. Hachette et Cie, 1884.)

text:
(Planting Rice Is Never Fun). Tagalog folk song.

 

This traditional Tagalog folk song depicts the actual labor in planting rice. The first stanza states that planting rice is no joke since one has to bend and stoop all day. The second stanza is an invitation to the listener to participate in the affair. It suggests that planting rice could also be a social exercise.

The song, which is cast in the fast duple time of the polka, is generally sung by a group and accompanied by a guitar or perhaps a bandurria, whether to accompany and synchronize the planting of the rice or to provide entertainment on other occasions. It uses the 2/4 polka rhythm with eighth notes predominating. The two stanzas of text are in monorhyming quatrains.

Its opening stanza goes:

Magtanim ay di biro

Maghapong nakayuko

Di man lang makatayo

Di man lang makaupo.

(Planting rice is never fun

You have to bend all day

You cannot stand

Neither can you sit.)

This song was popularized in schools via the Progressive Music Series of Norberto Romualdez published in 1923. The song was arranged by Antonio Regalario Jr for the UP Cherubim and Seraphim in 1974. The theme of the song was used by Augusto Espino in his piano arrangement, titled “Pagtatanim ng Palay” (Planting Rice), which is included in his book, Guhit Tugtugin at Seleksyon (Piano Sketches and Selections), a collection of Filipino folk songs arranged for young pianists. The choral arrangement by Fidel Calalang Jr is among the 15 new works which won the choral writing competition organized by the National Commission for Culture and the Arts and is published in the 2007 anthology Mga Awiting Bayan Para sa Korong Pilipino (Songs of the Nation for the Filipino Choir).  Written by Antonio C. Hila, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

text:
(Phantasm). 1939. Music, Antonio J. Molina; lyrics based on Rafael Zulueta da Costa’s poem, “Transfiguration.”

 

A tone poem for piano, it is a compact one-movement composition based on Rafael Zulueta da Costa’s poem, “Transfiguration.” The text reads:

Now is the godly hour when loving hands

Distil the earth anew. We shall awake

And tear the sunrise from the womb of dawn,

Until the running of our mystic blood

Becomes one with the running of the tide

One with the white cathedrals of the sky,

One with the wonder of the bursting seed,

One with the splendor of the rising sap,

One with all glorious flow on glorious earth:

Until the running of our blood becomes

But, lovingly, to lay down arms before

The earth imperative, transfigured Earth:

Until we find night-breathing pray’r upon

Our twisted lips:

We are commemoration

Of dead, but resurrected life.

A tightly constructed ternary work, it alternates impressionistic and romantic styles. The composition inspired Leonor Orosa-Goquingco to choreograph a ballet using the music.  Written by Antonio C. Hila

photos.desc:
Gloria Romero in Dalagang Ilocana, 1954, which used

“Manang Biday” as theme song (Cesar Hernando Collection)

text:
(Elder Woman Biday). Ilocano folk song.

 

Addressed to a woman named Biday (who is called Manang as a sign of respect), this traditional Ilocano folk song is cast in two contrasting eight-measure periods. The text is composed of eight 9-syllable lines. The first four lines or part A express a lover’s plea for attention. The final four lines or part B contain Manang Biday’s refusal of the love. The second stanza, also an exchange between lover and beloved, is sung to the same music as the first. The melody is in the major mode and set in lively 3/4 time. The same two-measure rhythmic pattern is repeated throughout the song. The song opens thus:

Manang Biday ilokat mo man

Ta bintana ikalumbabam

Ta kitaem tuy kinayawak

Ay matayakkon

No dinak kasyan.

(Manang Biday, please open

Your window

So you could see my predicament

I will die if you don’t

Take pity.)

Eliseo M. Pajaro arranged the song for solo voice and piano, and used the melody in his symphony, The Life of Lam-ang, 1951. Lucrecia R. Kasilag included the song in her work for women’s voices, Five Philippine Folk Songs, 1957. It also became the theme song of the 1954 movie Dalagang Ilocana (Ilocana Maiden) produced by Sampaguita Pictures which featured the tandem of Gloria Romero and Ric Rodrigo.  Written by Corazon C. Dioquino

text:
1949. Music, Felipe Padilla de Leon. First performed by the Filipino Youth Symphony Orchestra on 15 Dec 1950 at the Far Eastern University Auditorium, for the All-Felipe Padilla de Leon concert.

 

Manila Sketches is an orchestral suite composed in 1949 and consists of five musical tone-paintings: “Musikong Bumbong” (Bamboo Band), “Carromata” (The Carriage), “Automobile,” “Calle Ongpin” (Ongpin Street), and “Aso’t Pusa” (Dog and Cat). In “Musikong Bumbong,” a tribute to that fast-disappearing ensemble of bamboo instruments that plays from house to house, the bamboo bass thumps a basso ostinato that is grotesque and at times comical. Padilla de Leon captures the jaunty canter of the horse-drawn carriage in “Carromata” and the loud, harsh sound of the klaxon or motor horn in “Automobile.” To write “Calle Ongpin,” the composer took a leisurely walk through Ongpin to get the right atmosphere, which he then vividly depicted in a characteristically Chinese pentatonic scale. He ends the work with a raucous quarrel between a dog and cat in the quiet of night.  Written by Antonio C. Hila

text:
(Noble Hymn of the Tagalog Region). 1896. Music and lyrics, Julio Nakpil. Premiered at the old Teatro Zorrilla by 170 musicians in commemoration of the eighth anniversary of Rizal’s execution on 30 Dec 1904.

 

A musician and revolutionary, Nakpil gave expression to his patriotic sentiments in musical creations that immortalized the Philippine Revolution of 1896. “Marangal na Dalit ng Katagalugan,” one of the patriotic pieces which form the bulk of his output, was written in Balara in November 1896. It was composed to be a national anthem, with Tagalog lyrics by Nakpil himself, at the request of Andres Bonifacio, the Supremo of the Katipunan. However, Gen Emilio Aguinaldo did not use it, preferring instead the composition of Julian Felipe, a fellow Caviteño.

Later, Nakpil revised and lengthened the work, changing its title to “Salve Patria.” The work eventually caught the attention of the distinguished artist and conductor Alexander Lippay who, for several years, was director of the University of the Philippines Conservatory of Music. Lippay rearranged it as a symphonic composition and had it played by the Manila Symphony Orchestra in 1931.

Written for piano and chorus, it may be likened to a march set in simple, strongly accented rhythm. Marked “Allegro Maestoso,” it is a brief but majestic statement of the Revolution’s sentiments:

Mabuhay yaong kalayaan

At pasulungin ang puri’t kabanalan

Kastila’y mairing ng katagalugan

At ngayo’y ipagwagi ang kahusayan.

(Long live freedom

Uphold the cause of honor and holiness

The Spaniards have been overwhelmed by the Tagalog

Now fight for order to triumph.) Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes

A musician and revolutionary, Nakpil gave expression to his patriotic sentiments in musical creations that immortalized the Philippine Revolution of 1896. “Marangal na Dalit ng Katagalugan,” one of the patriotic pieces which form the bulk of his output, was written in Balara in November 1896. It was composed to be a national anthem, with Tagalog lyrics by Nakpil himself, at the request of Andres Bonifacio, the Supremo of the Katipunan. However, Gen Emilio Aguinaldo did not use it, preferring instead the composition of Julian Felipe, a fellow Caviteño.

Later, Nakpil revised and lengthened the work, changing its title to “Salve Patria.” The work eventually caught the attention of the distinguished artist and conductor Alexander Lippay who, for several years, was director of the University of the Philippines Conservatory of Music. Lippay rearranged it as a symphonic composition and had it played by the Manila Symphony Orchestra in 1931.
Written for piano and chorus, it may be likened to a march set in simple, strongly accented rhythm. Marked “Allegro Maestoso,” it is a brief but majestic statement of the Revolution’s sentiments:
Mabuhay yaong kalayaan
At pasulungin ang puri’t kabanalan
Kastila’y mairing ng katagalugan
At ngayo’y ipagwagi ang kahusayan.
(Long live freedom
Uphold the cause of honor and holiness
The Spaniards have been overwhelmed by the Tagalog
Now fight for order to triumph.) Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes

photos.desc:
Album cover of Asin’s Masdan Mo

ang Kapaligiran, 1978 (Vicor Music)

text:
(Look at the Environment). 1978. Music, Cesar “Saro” Bañares Jr; lyrics, Lolita Carbon and L. Lopez; arrangement, Charo Unite. First performed by Asin. Recorded by Vicor Music.

 

This folk-rock song by Asin was the first to express alarm over the environmental destruction caused by human activities at the expense of future generations. The song was ahead of its time. Though political activism was rife in the 1970s under Martial Law, environmental activism was virtually unheard of then. The song not only depicted the grave situation of the natural environment already evident in the 1970s, it also identified the root cause of this destruction—unsustainable economic development.

Wala ka bang napapansin

Sa iyong mga kapaligiran?

Kay dumi na ng hangin

Pati na ang mga ilog natin.

(Haven’t you noticed

Something about your surroundings?

The air is polluted

And so are the rivers.)

The provocative lyrics and memorable melody have kept interest in the song alive over several decades. Asin’s rendition became part of several best-selling albums in succeeding years: Mga Ginintuang Awitin ng Asin (The Golden Songs of Asin), 1983; Asin: Masdan Mo Ang Kapaligiran (Asin: Look At the Environment), 1994; and UGAT: The Best Of Pinoy Folk Rock, 2010. Sarah Geronimo also interpreted the song in her album Pure OPM Classics, 2012.

With the country experiencing extreme weather disturbances due to climate change in the 2000s, the song became the favorite hymn of the environmental movement. Asin received the Likas Yaman Award from the Department of Environment and Natural Resources for this song in 1991. Because of the continued relevance of the song, the group was also cited as Environmental Champions by the World Bank Environmental Monitor in 2004 (Candace 2012).  Written by Rosalie Matilac

Source

 

Candace, David. 2012. “Ang Pagbabalik ni Lolita Carbon ng ASIN in Toronto,’ a big hit!,” The Philippine Courier, Toronto, Ontario. 7 Oct-6 Nov. 9 (3): 18. Accessed 5 Apr 2015. www. philippinecourier.com

text:
(So They Say). Music, Ben Zubiri; arrangement, Luis Natanauan; Tagalog lyrics, Levi Celerio.

 

This well-known Cebuano love song set in the triple time of the balitaw, is cast in binary form—each part consisting of four periods. In the A part, the initial melodic motif is repeated at the start of each period. A contrasting melodic motif in the parallel major key is likewise used to start each period of the B part.

The text tells of the pain of a spurned first love. Despite rejection, the lover vows to cherish the memory of the beloved forever. The opening stanza of the Cebuano version runs:

Matud nila ako dili angay

Nga magmanggad sa imong gugma

Matud nila ikaw dili malipay

Kay wa ako’y bahandi nga kanimo igasa.

(They say I am not worthy

To have your love

They say you will not be happy

For I have no wealth that I can offer you.)

The song was popularized by Pilita Corrales in the mid-1970s. Nora Aunor as well as Sharon Cuneta also did their own versions.  Written by Corazon C. Dioquino

photos.desc:
Sheet music cover of “Ang Maya,” 1905

(UP College of Music Collection)

text:
(The Sparrow). 1905. Music, Jose A. Estella; lyrics, Severino Reyes. A waltz from the sarsuwela Filipinas para los Filipinos (Philippines for the Filipinos).

 

The song is about the maya, a small, swift bird. The bird’s agility is portrayed in the running, staccato passage of the third part, piu vivo. Although the score indicates an ending on a low note, performers, in keeping with the bravura character of the piece, prefer to end on the penultimate. Pedrito Reyes, youngest son of Severino Reyes, testifies that the song was inspired by a maya chirping in the trees in the compound of his father’s summer hut near the San Lazaro Hospital compound.

The popular “Ang Maya” waltz version was first recorded by Maria Carpena in 1908 and then by Nati Arellano in 1929. It was the signature song of soprano Consuelo Salazar-Perez who sang and starred in a movie with the same title in 1938. Conching Rosal included the song in her album titled Conching Rosal Sings Ang Maya ond Other Philippine Immortal Kundiman, which was released by Villar Records. It remains a standard in Filipino art song literature and continues to be a favorite among coloratura and leggiera sopranos like Noemi Manikan-Gomez and Ana Feleo who sang it at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino in 1992 and 2007, respectively, and Stefanie Quintin in the All Filipino Works Concert, at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music Minihall in 2010. The song was also performed by soprano Joan Cano in 2010 to orchestral accompaniment by the Filipino-American Symphony Orchestra under conductor Robert Schroeder.

The staging of Pilipinas Circa 1907 by Nicanor G. Tiongson brought the song into popular attention once again in 1982. This was staged by the Philippine Educational Theatre Association (PETA) at the Dulaang Rajah Sulayman and was used in the CCP productions of Pilipinas in 1992 and 2007 by Tanghalang Pilipino.

The piece has also been arranged for chorus and performed by the UST Singers in 2009 for the 113th Philippine Independence Day Program at the Maritime Hotel, Frankfurt, and by the UP Singing Ambassadors in 2012 for its Homecoming Concert at the Philamlife Auditorium.

From the notes in the Estella Collection of the UP College of Music Library in 2014, we learn that the composer composed not only two versions of “Ang Maya,” i.e., the happy “Ang Maya” for his 1905 sarsuwela and the sad “Ang Maya,” which is in kundiman style in music print, but a third “Ang Maya” titled “Ang Maya Enamorada” or The Bird in Love. Estella combined the three “Ang Maya” songs into Ang Maya Suite, for voice and piano which may have been used as a score in a silent film Ang Maya Pelikula (The Sparrow Movie), as Estella was a pioneer in the medium of film scoring. The Ang Maya Suite was re-arranged by Christopher Borela for the UP Madrigal Singers and performed at a concert at Abelardo Hall in 2014 with Mark Anthony A. Carpio as choirmaster.  Written by Antonio C. Hila, updated by Josephine Cecilia L. Baradas.
