Figure 1. Homophonic parts in parallel movement

reminiscent of pasyon singing

Figure 3. The entire ensemble in strict unison

providing a sense of resolution

text:
(Songs of Compassion). 1999. Music, Josefino “Chino” Toledo.

 

This is a piece of chamber music for 16 voices and bamboo percussion. It is based on ancient Tagalog musical literary forms such as the auit; the comintang, an example of which was transcribed by Mallat in 1846 and the cundiman, samples of which were published by Retana in 1882 and Walls y Merino in 1892. In the piece, the composer utilizes the texts of these samples as the spine that draws together the various elements and establishes the flow of the music from the beginning to the end. Clarity in the conveyance of the words is maintained through the employment of speech rhythm throughout the work’s entirety.

The piece employs simple, unison textures that contrast with the extremely dynamic, highly kinetic, and virtuosic writing style that has become associated with Toledo’s work. In reality, however, the unison is but alluded to throughout most of the piece in the form of variable tempo choices, desynchronized execution of passages, and homophonic sections. Strictly unison segments appear only at the very end of the approximately 16-minute long composition, providing a sense of resolution and finality.

Akin to the “drone plus melody” texture prevalent in many types of music in Asia, Mga Awit ng Paglingap rests on dual, simultaneous components: 1) the core referred to by the composer as the “mainstream” and 2) the periphery composed of an atmosphere of sounds termed “ripples” or “rivulets.” The core component carries the text and provides the piece a forward motion. This component appears in three forms: (1) as spoken or whispered passages; (2) as homophonic part; and (3) as heterophonic segments. Spoken or whispered passages are written with approximate tempi marked as fast or moderately fast and imprecise pitch levels marked as lowest possible voice level or normal voice level. Homophonic parts are composed of 8-voice chords moving in parallel motion and notated in plain-chant style using note heads without stems (see Fig 1).

Here, the use of portamento and occasional grace notes are reminiscent of pasyon singing. Heterophonic segments on the other hand may be seen as “false unisons” written as single melodic lines for entire vocal sections but not intended to be precisely synchronised, thus marked with the instruction “not necessarily together” (see Fig. 2).

The periphery component provides the environment for the core in the form of vocables (ah, hm, loo, dum or deng) set to long tones transcribed as whole notes. These sections gradually incorporate shorter durations notated as black note heads and applying indeterminacy in the sequence of pitches.

Each of the 16 singers plays bamboo percussion (stones may be used alternatively) notated as non-pitched sounds. The percussion functions mainly as a punctuating device played in unison to mark verse-endings. Gradually, however, the composer disperses the beating of the instrument transforming its function to a coloring device.

Towards the end of the piece, the dual components (core and periphery) blend into one homophonic stream using 8-voice chords doubled in octaves—Sopranos 1-4 doubled an octave below by Tenors 1-4 and Altos 1-4 doubled an octave below by Basses 1-4. Penultimately, the entire ensemble fuses into a single melodic line sung in strict unison (Fig. 3), giving the piece a sense of resolution as the stream and ripples merge into a single current.

At the very end, this singular current disperses again into sixteen separate lines of sustained tones, as if the soundstream is dissolving back into the atmosphere.  Written by LaVerne David C. de la Peña

text:
(Women). 1979. Music and lyrics, Mon Ayco.

Ayco’s experience in organizing women peasants in the Cordillera led him to write this anthem of the women’s movement. Its lively rhythm is meant by the song writer to “musically express the strength of women.”

 

The song text refers to two types of women characters depicted in Philippine society. The first, exemplified by the traditional figures of Maria Clara, Sisa, and Juli are weak, passive, helpless in crisis, and subservient to men. The second, typified by Gabriela Silang, Tandang Sora, and Lorena Barros have overcome traditional women roles and contributed to the liberation of the nation by actively joining various revolutionary movements.

The song encourages women to participate in social issues, take up arms, and fight for freedom:

Ang ating isip ay buksan

At lipuna’y pag-aralan

Pa’no nahubog inyong isipan

Ang tanggapin kayo’y mga libangan

Mgababae, ito nga ba’y kapalaran?

(Open our minds

And study the society

Why your minds have been conditioned

To allow yourselves to become playthings

Women, is this your destiny?)

The song was often sung at protest rallies and mass assemblies of cause-oriented groups during the Marcos regime. It was recorded for Dyna Records by Inang Laya in 1987, and again by Fire in 1990.  Written by Milagros Carunungan

photos.desc:
Album cover of  Francis Magalona’s Yo!, 1990,

which includes “Mga Kababayan Ko” (Polyeast Records)

text:
(My Countrymen). 1990. Music and lyrics, Francis Magalona; arrangement, Jimmy Antiporda. First sung by Francis Magalona.

 

Francis Magalona, the first rapper to emerge on the local music scene, achieved unprecedented success with his song, the anthem, “Mga Kababayan Ko.” Included in his platinum debut album, YO!, under the OctoArts International label, the song bagged a Catholic Mass Media Award, the Best Song of the Year title awarded by the Guillermo Mendoza Foundation, the TINIG Song of the Year, and the Best Song of the Year title conferred by two FM radio stations, DWLS 97.1 and DWTM 89.9. The Guillermo Mendoza Foundation also named Magalona 1990 Entertainer of the Year.

The tremendous appeal of “Mga Kababayan Ko” lies in Magalona’s so-called intelligent rapping. The song imparts positive Filipino values but does so with wit and grace. It encourages Filipinos to be proud of their brown color and to have confidence in themselves. The opening stanza goes:

Mga kababayan ko,

Dapat na malaman n’yo,

Bilib ako sa kulay ko,

Ako ay Pilipino.

Kung may itim o may puti,

Meron namang kayumanggi,

Isipin mo na kaya mong

Abutin ang ‘yong minimithi.

(My fellow Filipinos

You should know

That I believe in my color

I am a Filipino

If there is black or white

There is brown, too,

Just remember that you can

Achieve what you desire.)

As the premier proponent of local rap, Magalona—with a “black” haircut, tattoos, and clad in innovative sawwal-inspired trousers—inspired a wave of subsequent local rappers and a generation of Filipino kids, from the streetwise to the exclusive-school bred, who aped his movements and effortlessly spouted the song’s tongue-twisting lyrics.

The musical style which ingeniously fuses black and indigenous Filipino music is experimental and adventurous. Contrast is achieved between the loud, slamming basic beat and the soft, fragile tones of the indigenous instruments. The creative fusion of Eastern and Western influences in his music allows Magalona to express his desire to dismantle both musical as well as social barriers through his works.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes

article.value: (My Countrymen). 1990. Music and lyrics, Francis Magalona; arrangement, Jimmy Antiporda. First sung by Francis Magalona.

photos.desc:
Sheet music cover of “A Million Thanks To You,” 1965

(Atang de la Rama Collection)

text:
1965. Music, Alice Doria Gamilla; lyrics, Luis Trinidad. First sung by Pilita Corrales.

 

One of the early significant English ballads, this song shows sophistication and adeptness in the musical treatment and handling of the English text. At the time of its release, the song was regarded as a breakthrough for it introduced the pop form called “middle-of-the-road” that presaged the birth of contemporary ballads in Filipino and English in the 1970s and decades after.

The song proper consists of three periods ABC. It begins dramatically with the singer performing the C section with its lush orchestration set to the text:

The day you came along

With your song

My heart began to sing

A million thanks to you, my love.

The piece then proceeds to present the ABC sections sung in their proper order. A brief instrumental interlude repeating the A section follows and the work ends with an emphatic and equally dramatic reiteration of the C section. The lyrics develop the metaphor of love as a powerful force that enables the heart to sing.

Pilita Corrales’s impassioned delivery of the song was used as opener for her long-running television show in the 1960s titled An Evening with Pilita and it became a popular favorite.  Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian

A brief instrumental interlude repeating the A section follows and the work ends with an emphatic and equally dramatic reiteration of the C section. The lyrics develop the metaphor of love as a powerful force that enables the heart to sing.

Pilita Corrales’s impassioned delivery of the song was used as opener for her long-running television show in the 1960s titled An Evening with Pilita and it became a popular favorite.  Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian

text:
(I Love You). 1937. Music and lyrics, Mike Velarde Jr. First performed by Elsa Oria in the 1940 movie Niña Bonita (Pretty Girl).

 

The period of the 1930s and 1940s was the golden age of Tagalog popular songs. Many songs were written for the movies, performed and popularized by singing stars such as Elsa Oria, Ely Ramos, Rudy Concepcion, Rosario Moreno, Fely Vallejo, Rogelio de la Rosa, Tita Duran, Carmen Rosales, Pancho Magalona, and Corazon Noble. A famous stanza from this song goes:

Minamahal, minamahal kita

Pagsinta’y hindi mag-iiba

Hindi mo ba nadarama, sinta

Bawat kilos ko’y pangarap ka.

(You’re the one I love

My love will never change

Can’t you feel it, darling

I dream of you always.)

Velarde’s song, which is in the moderate triple time of a waltz, has been described as urbane and sophisticated, a reflection of the mood in the Americanized Manila of the late 1930s. It is light, winsome, and playful, but is also subtly romantic.

The song has been arranged for vocal duet, orchestra, and duet for two pianos. Alfredo S. Buenaventura’s arrangement for soprano and tenor is found in 50 Immortal Filipino Duets, 1992. An orchestral arrangement by Ryan Cayabyab was performed by the San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra and included in their CD album Great Filipino Love Songs, 2004. Dick Zamora’s arrangement for two pianos was performed by Della Besa and Anna Maria de Guzman at their duo concert titled Diwa (Consciousness) at the Cultural Center of the Philippines Tanghalang Aurelio V. Tolentino in 2009.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by James C. Diaz

text:
1947. Music, Antonino Buenaventura.

 

Mindanao Sketches was completed a decade after the composer’s trip to Mindanao where he did research on Manobo music in connection with a project under the President’s Committee on Folk Songs and Dances at the University of the Philippines (UP).

In 1948, it was performed in Hong Kong, Yokohama, and Honolulu during Buenaventura’s Far East tour with the Municipal Symphony Orchestra of Manila. In 1957, it was performed by the Cincinnati Symphony Orchestra under the direction of Thor Johnson. It was the first Filipino orchestral work performed in Russia in 1971. Locally, it has been featured in several concerts: in 1961, at an all-Filipino concert at the UP with the UP Symphony Orchestra, under Eliseo M. Pajaro; in 1983, at the all-Buenaventura program at the Concert at the Park, with the Metro Manila Community Symphony Orchestra, under resident conductor Regalado Jose; and in 1988, at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) with the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Lucio D. San Pedro on the occasion of the conferment of the title of National Artist for Music on Buenaventura.

Recent performances of the piece were by Philippine Youth Symphonic Band in 2009 with conductor Romeo F. San Jose at the Carlos P. Romulo Auditorium in Makati City and by the UP Orchestra conducted by Edna Marcil Martinez at the Philamlife Auditorium in 2010 at the first National Orchestra Festival at the CCP Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo; and in 2012 by the De La Salle Santiago Zobel Symphony Orchestra with Nena Chavez, conductor, at the Sylvia P. Lina Theatre in Muntinlupa City.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by Josephine Cecilia L. Barada

text:
(Mass). 1982. Music, Ryan Cayabyab. First performed by the UP Concert Chorus at the University of the Philippines (UP) Abelardo Hall on 4 Mar 1983.

 

The work is a setting of the Mass Ordinary and is composed of the “Kyrie,” “Credo,” “Gloria,” “Sanctus,” and “Agnus Dei” in Latin. Written for mixed a capella, this contemporary piece is a radical departure from Cayabyab’s award-winning works. Beneath the seeming irreverence is a prayerful undertone. Setting a Catholic text to an Islamic-inspired chant, the piece envisions the unity of Christianity and Islam. This work was groundbreaking in its time. It had a strong impact in choral music repertoire and its combination with dance made it more influential that many masses in the same a capella style were created after it.

The “Credo” is a fine example of the blending of exoticized Eastern chant and Western harmonies. “Sanctus,” in its creative treatment of rhythms, draws attention to the artistry of the work, which results in exultation. Only in “Agnus Dei” does the sacred text lose its preeminence over the music.

A choreographed version of the Misa was created for the international tour of the UP Concert Chorus in 1983. In 1984, Basilio choreographed his own Misa Filipina to Cayabyab’s Misa, to honor the Man in White (Ninoy Aquino) who was killed by soldiers. The work was premiered in full at the Church of the Risen Lord at the UP and performed at the Manila Cathedral in front of Jaime Cardinal Sin and Corazon Aquino on 30 Apr 1985.

The “Gloria” has been sung by the Philippine Madrigal Singers in their historic 1989 international concert tour where they won all the top prizes in the competitions they participated in. Similarly, “Gloria” was one of the five pieces meticulously chosen by their choirmaster, Andrea O. Veneracion, in their 1997 European Grand Prix (EGP) for choral singing finals in Tours, France, which they eventually won.

The entire Mass was performed at a special all-Ryan Cayabyab concert of the Philippine Madrigal Singers by the MADZ et al mass choir consisting of members, alumni, and members of choirs directed by both members and alumni. The concert was titled MADZ about Ryan, staged in 1998.  Written by Flerida G. Nolasco, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

text:
(Mass 2000). 2000. Music, Ryan Cayabyab.

 

Written for choir and orchestra, Misa 2000 served as accompaniment to Douglas Nierras’s ballet, Metanoia, a choreographic masterpiece set to the five-part Latin Mass Ordinary—“Kyrie,” “Gloria,” “Credo,” “Sanctus,” and “Agnus Dei.”

The “Kyrie” is characterized by interlocking rhythms and resultant melodies. These are produced by the different combinations of rhythmic and melodic patterns sounded on western symphonic instruments, Philippine bamboo musical instruments saggeypo (blown tubes), bungkaka (buzzers), and chorus. The “Gloria” is more eclectic and western in treatment. Chant-like singing is very prominent in the “Credo.” The “Sanctus” opens with a rhythmic interplay between vocal sections that recalls the Sanctus of an earlier Misa, 1982, also by Cayabyab. A very short fugue and recurring and extended dialogues between vocal parts and among sections in the “Sanctus” bring it to its final note. The “Agnus Dei” is a play between chant-like soli and western, almost movie theme-like orchestration, melody, and climaxes.

The experimental sound of this work reminds listeners of the use of Moroccan and indigenous Filipino music juxtapositions in the 1982 Misa. In the former, which is sung a cappella, Cayabyab utilized chanting and Kalinga interlocking patterns for voice. The effect is a hauntingly beautiful duet that opens and ends the “Kyrie.” Cayabyab also provides bravura passages at different points in the antiphonal 1983 “Gloria” that ends with prayer-like echoes. The interlocking rhythms of Kalinga gong music are again featured in the texture of the earlier “Sanctus.” More conventional choral writing is found in the “Agnus Dei.” Cayabyab’s important contribution to the Philippine music repertoire in both Misa 1982 and Misa 2000 is innovative choral writing for the concert stage.

Misa 2000 won second prize in the 2001 Onassis International Cultural Competitions’ Original Music Composition for Dance category on 27 Nov 2001 in Athens, Greece (no first prize was awarded). A commercial recording of Misa 2000 was released in 2004 in the two-volume CD titled The Sacred Works of Ryan Cayabyab performed by the San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra and the San Miguel Master Chorale under the baton of conductor Julian Quirit. This album won Best Religious Album in the 2004 Catholic Mass Media Awards. An earlier rendition of the Misa can be found at the University of the Philippines (UP) College of Music Library featuring the UP Concert Chorus with the composer conducting. The “Gloria” was performed and recorded by the World Youth Choir and released in 1997 in an album titled World Youth Choir Best Selection Vol. 1, produced by the All Japan Chorus League.  Written by Raul C. Navarro

text:
Dated 1826. Anonymous Mass Ordinary music setting from Baclayon, Bohol.

It is considered one of the earliest extant western-derived musical work in the country that bears a local place name. The Misa Baclayana is one of the 26 Mass Ordinary compositions contained in a large choir book (cantoral) titled Kirial de esta Iglesia de Baclayon año 1826. The phrase “Mass Ordinary” refers to the sections of the Mass in which the text is invariable, namely, the Kyrie, Gloria, Credo, Sanctus, and Agnus Dei.

The Kirial de Baclayon is one in a set of four choir books that are found in the ecclesiastical museum of Baclayon church. The others are the Antifonario de esta Yglesia de Baclayon año 1826, the Salterio de esta Iglesia de Baclayon año 1826, and the Misal o Yntroitos del Coro de esta Iglesia de Baclayon año 1827.

Cantorales were elegantly fashioned music books used by the choir in the liturgical services of the Catholic Church, i.e., the Mass and the Divine Office. They were intentionally made significantly large so singers could read the music from a distance and were laid out on a four-sided music lectern called facistol that could be rotated to facilitate the changing of the pages or books. The music in the Baclayon cantorales was painstakingly copied by hand with illuminated letters in red, yellow, and black. The folia were made from cowhide parchment and bound by wooden boards covered with black carabao leather. The choir books were produced locally and executed by native escriviente de sol-fa (music scribes).

 

The Kirial de Baclayon has 136 parchment folia measuring 43.3 cm x 66 cm and is 8.4 cm. thick. Considering its size, one cow is needed to produce four folia of parchment. It can be conjectured that 34 cows were slaughtered to make the single cantoral.

The Misa Baclayana is notated in a form that looks like the archaic “mensural” notation of square and diamond note heads from the late medieval period, but it uses the time signature of common practice. The Baclayana mass is in triple meter and its setting is in canto llano figurado (measured plainsong). The notation is in the style of 18th century Spanish church music tutor books. The five movements of the Misa are in F major that makes passing modulations to closely related keys (C major and D minor). Musical texture is generally monophonic while some parts of the mass, such as the Benedictus, employ two-voiced polyphony moving in parallel thirds and sixths. Although there is no organ part indicated in the cantorales found in Baclayon, the mass compositions were most likely accompanied by this instrument as suggested by another manuscript copy of the Misa Baclayana preserved in Dimiao, a neighboring town. Stylistically, the music accompaniment of Misa Baclayana is based on a simple harmonic progression (e.g., I, IV, V and basic secondary chords). This simplicity parallels the easy vocal texture. The charm of the Misa Baclayana lies in its beautifully arched melodies and simple harmonies, creating an atmosphere of devotional sincerity that once filled the walls of the church of Baclayon.  Written by Maria Alexandra Iñigo-Chua

text:
(Balintawak Mass). 1910. Music, Bonifacio Abdon.

A complete Mass composed by Abdon for the Iglesia Filipina Independiente (IFI) in 1910, at the request of the church, this piece is also known as Balintawak: Misang Pilipino (Balintawak: Filipino Mass) or Misang Tagalog sa Balintawak (Tagalog Mass in Balintawak). It is a musical setting of the IFI version of the Mass Ordinary, with text in Tagalog. The Mass is made up of seven movements: 1) “Introito” (Introduction); 2) “Luwalhati” (Glory); 3) “Kaawaan Kami” (Have Mercy on Us); 4) “Pananampalataya” (Faith); 5) “Banal” (Holy); 6) “Panalangin Ukol sa mga Bayaning Nangamatay” (Prayers for Fallen Heroes); and 7) “Katapusan” (End). It is written for tiple and tenor voices, and is accompanied by the organ. The tonality of the Misa Balintawak centers on the key of F.

 

The fourth movement, “Pananampalataya,” is one of the highlights of the Mass because it is a musical setting of the declaration of the fundamental doctrine espoused by the IFI during its foundation—the belief in a unitarian God that possesses three attributes, not persons: “One God, One Essence, One Person” (Mojares 2006, 328). The last movement, “Katapusan,” quotes the melodic and rhythmic motives of the Philippine National Anthem and reflects the nationalistic character of the IFI. The vocal parts also quote the rhythmic motive of the third section of the National Anthem. Abdon employed fragments of the Philippine National Anthem to circumvent the penalties imposed by the Flag Law of the Philippine Commission in 1907, “which prohibited the singing/playing of the national anthem and the display of the Filipino flag from 1907 to 1919” (Ranche 1989, 18).

The Misa Balintawak is one of four complete masses included in Mga Awit sa Pagsamba para sa Diyos at Bayan (Worship Songs for God and Country), the official hymnal of IFI published in 2010. The other three are the Misa Rizalina, Misa Porvenir, and Misa Bantay Kilang. At present, the Misa Balintawak is sung in its entirety during special church ceremonies and celebrations.  Written by Arwin Q. Tan

Sources

 

Manuel, E. Arsenio. 1955-86. Dictionary of Philippine Biography. Quezon City: Filipiniana Publications.

Mojares, Resil B. 2006b. “Isabelo de los Reyes.” In Brains of the Nation: Pedro Paterno, T.H. Pardo de Tavera, Isabelo de los Reyes and the Production of Modern Knowledge, 253-380. Quezon City: Ateneo de Manila University Press.

Ranche, Apolonio. 1989. “The Nationalist Heritage of the Iglesia Filipina Independiente.” Unpublished article.

Yap, Joseph Martin, trans. 2002. “The Religion of the Katipunan or The Old Beliefs of the Filipinos by Isabelo de los Reyes.” In Views on Philippine Revolution, edited by L Arcellana, 197- 299. Quezon City: The Toyota Foundation and the University of the Philippines Press.

text:
(Spanish-Filipino Mass). Possibly 18th century. Anonymous Mass Ordinary music setting from the Manual-Cantoral para el uso de las religiosas de Santa Clara de la ciudad de Manila (Manual-Choir Book for Use by the Religious of Santa Clara in the City of Manila), a five-volume anthology of sacred music printed in Manila from 1871 to 1874.

 

The composition is found in Volume 2 of the Manual-Cantoral de Santa Clara (Manual-Choir Book of Santa Clara), which is devoted to well-known masses (misas classicas) and music for processions (procesiones) and benedictions (bendiciones). The volume is preserved in the archive of the ecclesiastical museum of Baclayon Church, Bohol. Only the “Kyrie” and the “Gloria” of the mass cycle have survived as the other pages have been torn from the volume. Fortunately, a handwritten copy of the whole mass, made by Eulogia Darunday, a cantora or singer of Corella church, has been preserved in the music collection of Corella, Bohol.

The music of the Misa Hispano Filipina represents compositional style and technique from the Spanish colonial period. The music is notated in the archaic-looking “mensural” notation in square and diamond note heads, but it is in common practice triple meter in the F major mode. Musical phrases are generally “regular” or symmetrical, with occasional irregular phrasing. The music alternates between monophonic measured plainsong style (canto llano figurado) and two-voiced polyphonic homorhythmic style (canto de organo) moving in parallel thirds or sixths. This characteristic brings about diversity in unity in the musical texture. The musical form of the “Kyrie” and the “Gloria” is generally through-composed.  Written by Maria Alexandra Iñigo-Chua

article.value: (Spanish-Filipino Mass). Possibly 18th century. Anonymous Mass Ordinary music setting from the Manual-Cantoral para el uso de las religiosas de Santa Clara de la ciudad de Manila (Manual-Choir Book for Use by the Religious of Santa Clara in the City of Manila), a five-volume anthology of sacred music printed in Manila from 1871 to 1874.

The composition is found in Volume 2 of the Manual-Cantoral de Santa Clara (Manual-Choir Book of Santa Clara), which is devoted to well-known masses (misas classicas) and music for processions (procesiones) and benedictions (bendiciones). The volume is preserved in the archive of the ecclesiastical museum of Baclayon Church, Bohol. Only the “Kyrie” and the “Gloria” of the mass cycle have survived as the other pages have been torn from the volume. Fortunately, a handwritten copy of the whole mass, made by Eulogia Darunday, a cantora or singer of Corella church, has been preserved in the music collection of Corella, Bohol.

This characteristic brings about diversity in unity in the musical texture. The musical form of the “Kyrie” and the “Gloria” is generally through-composed.  Written by Maria Alexandra Iñigo-Chua

photos.desc:
Music for Five Pianos performance during Tikladong Hirang, 2015

(UP College of Music Collection)

text:
1993. Music, Jose Maceda.

Music for Five Pianos aka M5P alludes to the composer’s return to his musical roots, having started his career as a concert pianist in the 1930s. In this piece, Maceda divorces the instrument from centuries of solo “pianistic” performance practice by reducing it to what he calls a “sound box” (Maceda 2000). He constructs the piece from the same tool kit used for all his works: layers of repeated motifs that form varying textures and densities of sound masses. In M5P, he completely obliterates melody—a process that plays a significant role in most of his works—except perhaps when melodic fragments are accidentally heard in the interplay of the layers of sound. Rhythm, as in his other compositions, is disjointed through the use of uncommon subdivisions of the beat, such as 7:4 (or 7 notes in 4 beats), 10:3, rendering the meter, although set in four quarter notes to a measure, largely imperceptible.

 

Maceda divides M5P into two main contrasting sections: the first half where the pianos play in “complementarity” with each other, playing similar repeated phrases; and the second half where they “become individual boxes.” In the work, they play distinctive parts, which include passages mimicking techniques of classical piano repertoire. Structurally, it is built on the same framework that underlies all other Maceda pieces. The 30- to 40-minute piece is divided into 20 subsections (marked 1A, 1B, 2A, 2B all the way to 20B), each comprising 15 measures. In most of Maceda’s compositions, these subsections delineate one minute of elapsed time. Since M5P is marked 30-40 MM to a quarter note, each subsection then lasts anywhere from 1.5 to 2 minutes. This internal construction gives hints to the composer’s writing style as being largely influenced by the electroacoustic devices of musique concrete in Paris in the 1940s where sonic events are plotted on to a running timeline. This further explains the idiosyncratic notation that he employs where notes are written on the bar lines, like a node plotted on a grid.

The first main section opens with octave arpeggios on pitch A covering the entire gamut of the keyboard and running in 16th notes. Gradually, other pitches are introduced starting with B-flat, D-flat, E as rhythmic figures transform to include divisions of 5:2, 3:2 and 7:3, until the 5 pianos play the octave arpeggios in varying rhythms and pitches. The arpeggios give way to reiterated open fifth chords in subsection 4A (ms 46) where the pianists play root-fifth-root chords in both hands in varying rhythms and registers. These chords are soon filled in with other pitches, producing tone clusters, rendering this section heavily dense and sonorous. When we get to 8A (ms 106), the tone clusters are replaced by running ascending scales marked by varying lengths and abrupt silences. Gradually, descending patterns are added to the mix, along with grace notes. The first section ends on 10A (ms 136), which is roughly the middle of the piece, with a ‘recapitulation’ of 1A to 1B, finishing in repeated blocks of octaves in 11B.

The second main section begins on 12A (ms 166) as the tail end of the first section gradually diminishes. From this point onwards, the five pianos assume characteristics distinct from each other. Piano 1 reverberates with sustained cluster chords while Piano 2 plays an ostinato of cluster chords alternating with major sixth in octaves. Piano 4 soon enters with repeated open octaves while Piano 3 provides cadenza-like passages. Piano 5 is last to enter with extended trills and brief, rapid scalar phrases in contrary motion which, before long, transform into a swiftly swirling passage. The tension builds up as the overall density and volume increases until all the five pianos return to playing similar passages of open octaves in varying durations in 17A. At 19A, the octaves are replaced by cluster chords, this time in more rapid repetition. Finally, two bars after 20A (ms 288), all pianos reiterate pitch C in octaves spanning the entire piano range in varying rhythms of 10:4, 11:4 and 9:4. The piece ends in measure 300.

Music for Five Pianos is significant because it affords the piano the use of concepts that the composer once articulated through Asian music instruments. The autograph manuscript of the work is preserved in the University of the Philippines Center for Ethnomusicology.  Written by LaVerne David C. de la Peña

photos.desc: Scene from Mutya ng Pasig, 1950 (Cesar Hernando Collection)

text:
(Muse of Pasig). 1926. Music, Nicanor S. Abelardo; lyrics, Deogracias A. Rosario.

“Mutya ng Pasig” was inspired by a carnival along the Pasig in 1926. Moved by the celebration, Abelardo and Rosario allude to a mythical past with its bygone splendor. The song carries a seductive and haunting melody, borne by a definite sweeping rhythm powerfully emoting lost love. In the light of the full moon, the mutya (muse or goddess) speaks, lamenting her lost kingdom and love, an allusion to the freedom lost by the country to its Spanish and American colonizers:

 

Dati akong paraluman

Sa kaharian ng pag-ibig

Ang pag-ibig nang mamatay

Naglaho rin ang kaharian.

(I was a muse before

In the kingdom of love

But when love died

My kingdom vanished with it.)

In the end, she makes a heartrending plea:

Kung nais ninyong ako’y mabuhay,

pag-ibig ko’y inyong ibigay

(If you want me to live,

then give me back my love).

The song requires that the singer take two personas—first, that of an observer of the magical scene that enfolds and the other, that of the Pasig River nymph. Thus, a high musical sensitivity from the singer is demanded to reveal this unique duality (Santos 2005).

The song uses the traditional musical form, the kumintang. This is especially evident in the introductory portion. The rest of the song is cast in the slow triple time of the kundiman. The original composition was written for voice and piano. The work was arranged for full orchestra by Abelardo himself. It was also arranged for chamber orchestra by Elsa O’ Farrell in 1941, and was later rearranged by Redentor L. Romero for the London Philharmonic Orchestra.

A 1950 film of the same title was directed by Richard Abelardo, a cousin of Nicanor S. Abelardo. In 1983, Ryan Cayabyab rearranged this song for Kuh Ledesma’s concert.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

Source

 

Santos, Ramon P. 2005. Tunugan: Four Essays on Filipino Music. Diliman, Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

photos.desc:
Sheet music cover of “Naku... Kenkoy!”

(CCP Collection)

text:
(Gosh … Kenkoy!). 1930. Music, Nicanor S. Abelardo; lyrics, Romualdo C. Ramos.

This comic song is a fox-trot in jaunty duple time. It was created by Nicanor S. Abelardo as a tribute to the komiks character, Kenkoy, created by his friend Antonio Velasquez in 1929. Velasquez illustrated the covers of many of Abelardo’s pieces. Kenkoy is a caricature of young urban Filipinos who flaunt their colonial mentality, and want to impress their fellow Filipinos with their command of the latest American slang and their familiarity with the most modern trends. Kenkoy speaks in a curious mixture of English, Spanish, and Tagalog pretending he cannot speak straight Tagalog:

 

Pati noo’y inahit na

Kilos, lakad ay nag-iba

Habang daa’y kumakanta

Ng ingles na walang letra (May ukelele pa)

Batiin mo “kumusta ka?”

At ang sagot, tingnan mo ba!

“Hey! Tagalog mi no habla!”

Ay naku, naku Kenkoy

Hoy! Kenkoy!

He shaved his forehead

Changed his manners and gait

While strolling he sings

In incomprehensible English (With ukelele at that)

Greet him, “how do you do?”

And look at his reply

“Hey! I don’t speak Tagalog!”

Oh you, you Kenkoy

Hey! Kenkoy!

In 1974, Ruben R. Federizon arranged the song for the then UP (now Philippine) Madrigal Singers. An instant hit, it became a signature piece of the choir.  Written by Antonio C. Hila

text:
2006. Music and lyrics, Kamikazee.

The song is included in the album Maharot (Mischievous), which was released in 2006 by Universal Records. In that year, “Narda” got extensive radio air play and became the signature song of the rock band Kamikazee, which consists of Jay Contreras, vocals; Jomal Linao, lead guitar/back up vocals; Led Tuyay, rhythm/lead guitars; Jason “Puto” Astete, bass guitar; and Allan “Bords” Burdeos, drums.

 

The song is addressed to Narda, the alter ego of Darna, the popular komiks character created by Mars Ravelo. Darna is a superhero who defends a provincial town from evil spirits and demons such as aswang (witch), manananggal (selfsegmenting ghoul), impakta (vampire), and other lowly blood-thirsty mythical creatures. In the song, the male persona reveals his desire to be Narda’s paramour. He wonders if Narda, who is desired by all, would even notice him. He goes as far as contemplating falling into a ravine so that Narda’s double, Darna, might rescue him and he can be in her embrace for a few precious seconds. He embodies the stereotype of the Filipino male as torpe (shy), unable to articulate his feelings for a girl beyond his reach.

The instrumentation of the song is distinctive to Kamikazee. It is in a slow, deliberate tempo punctuated by the steady drum beat and heavy strumming of the lead guitars. Jay Contreras’s pained, raw vocals, which carry the jumpy melodic line, are juxtaposed with the grating baritone drone of members of the band, resulting in vocal and instrumental cacophony. Yet it is this riotous style of singing-yelling and instrumentation that Kamikazee fans adore. Inspired by GMA Network’s Darna, “Narda” was eventually used as the theme song of the aforementioned TV series, which starred Angel Locsin in the lead role in 2009 and Marian Rivera in 2013.  Written by Lara Katrina T. Mendoza

photos.desc:
Album cover of Regine Velasquez’s Nineteen ‘90, 1990,

which includes “Narito Ako” (Viva Records)

text:
(Here I Am). 1978. Music and lyrics, Nonong Pedero. First sung by Maricris Bermont in the First Metro Manila Popular Music Festival in 1978 where the song won third prize.

The text captures the giddiness and excitement of the experience of falling in love. The most well-known version of the song is the soaring rendition of Regine Velasquez, featured in her 1990 album Nineteen 90.

 

This sophisticated contemporary ballad is written in irregular verse form and although the lines are not of the same length, a couplet-type rhyme scheme is displayed:

Narito ako, umiibig

Laging tulala at ligalig

Heto na naman at halos di mapakali

Sa damdamin na pinakamimithi.

(Here I am, in love

Always stunned and bothered.

Here I am again, so restless

In the face of this feeling that I long for.)

The song form is likewise an unusual and irregular ABCABCC’DCC. The combination of irregular verse and song form contribute to create an image of the unstable and freewheeling character of a person in the first throes of romantic love:

Narito ako na lagi nang nakatingin

Sa mga ulap at bituin

Puso’t isip ko ay iisa ang hiwatig

Narito ako, umiibig.

(Here I am, always looking

At the clouds and stars

My heart and mind are one in revealing

That I am here and in love.) Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian, with notes from Elena Rivera Mirano

photos.desc:
Sheet music cover of “Nasaan Ka Irog?,” 1923

(Atang de la Rama Collection)

text:
(Donde estas, mi vida! / Where are You, My Love?). 1923. Music, Nicanor S. Abelardo; Spanish lyrics, Narciso Asistio; Tagalog lyrics, Jose Corazon de Jesus. Arranged for the orchestra by Lucio D. San Pedro, Eliseo M. Pajaro, Hilarion F. Rubio, and Restie Umali, and for mixed choir by Emmanuel Laureola.

 

This art song is cast in the slow triple time of the kundiman, and has a brief introduction and three principal parts. Abelardo developed this kundiman from an early motif he used during his harana (serenade) days in Bulacan and the vicinity of the Tutuban railroad station in Manila.

The song is based on the true-to-life drama of a cruelly thwarted love between the scion of a wealthy family and an impoverished maiden. It expresses acute futility, frustration, helplessness, and lingering sadness through its profuse harmony and the descriptive markings pesante (heavily) and doloroso (achingly). Abelardo dedicated this song to his childhood friend, Dr. Francisco Tecson, from whose personal experience he drew material and inspiration.

Scholars have noted that in this kundiman, the lyrics and music interpenetrate and are one in rhythm and emotion. The opening stanza goes:

Nasaan ka irog?

Nasaan ka irog?

At dagling naparam

Ang iyong paggiliw

Di baga sumpa mong

Ako’y mamahalin?

Iyong itatangi,

Iyong itatangi

Magpahanggang libing

Subalit nasaan

Ang gayong pagtingin?

(Where are you, my love?

Where are you, my love?

Why did your love

Fade away?

Didn’t you promise

That you will love me

That you would cherish me,

And cherish me

Unto the grave?

But where

Is that regard?)

The song inspired the making of the 1936 movie Nasaan Ka Irog, starring Rosario Moreno and Ely Ramos, with Elsa Oria singing the title song. One of the most popular love songs for generations, it has become a standard piece in the repertoire of Filipino singers. It has also been included in the recorded albums of internationally known Filipino artists such as classical pianist Adolovni Acosta in her landmark recording, Malagueña: Piano Music from Cuba and the Philippines, released in 2008; and the Berlin recording of baritone Jonathan Zaens and pianist Abelardo Galang II titled Kundiman: Philippine Art Songs, released in 2007. Two other notable recorded renditions are by the Mabuhay Singers in their 1973 album, Mabuhay Singers Sing Kundiman, and by the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra accompanying tenor Jonathan Badon.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

article.value: (Donde estas, mi vida! / Where are You, My Love?). 1923. Music, Nicanor S. Abelardo; Spanish lyrics, Narciso Asistio; Tagalog lyrics, Jose Corazon de Jesus. Arranged for the orchestra by Lucio D. San Pedro, Eliseo M. Pajaro, Hilarion F. Rubio, and Restie Umali, and for mixed choir by Emmanuel Laureola.

The song inspired the making of the 1936 movie Nasaan Ka Irog, starring Rosario Moreno and Ely Ramos, with Elsa Oria singing the title song. One of the most popular love songs for generations, it has become a standard piece in the repertoire of Filipino singers. It has also been included in the recorded albums of internationally known Filipino artists such as classical pianist Adolovni Acosta in her landmark recording, Malagueña: Piano Music from Cuba and the Philippines, released in 2008; and the Berlin recording of baritone Jonathan Zaens and pianist Abelardo Galang II titled Kundiman: Philippine Art Songs, released in 2007. Two other notable recorded renditions are by the Mabuhay Singers in their 1973 album, Mabuhay Singers Sing Kundiman, and by the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra accompanying tenor Jonathan Badon.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

text:
(Now and Forever). 1977. Music and lyrics, George Canseco. First sung by Basil Valdez.

 

Canseco’s ballad in moderate duple time is an early example of the successful fusion of traditional Pinoy sentiment and the modern urban lifestyle in the movement known as Original Pilipino Music (OPM). One of 1977’s greatest hits, “Ngayon at Kailanman” was recorded separately by Basil Valdez and Celeste Legaspi under the Blackgold label. The song, though, is more popularly associated with Basil Valdez who rose to the top of the charts because of it, with a long-playing album bearing the same title. The album stands as a significant landmark in the Philippine recording industry since it brought the curtain down on the production of albums dominated by covers from the American pop music industry and marked the coming of a new popular music composed in a more modern, post-kundiman style. The song’s opening stanza goes:

Ngayon at kailanman

Sumpa ko’y iibigin ka

Ngayon at kailanman

Hindi ka na mag-iisa

Ngayon at kailanman

Sa hirap o ginhawa pa

Asahang may kasama ka, sinta.

Naroroon ako tuwina

Maaasahan mo tuwina

Ngayon at kailanman.

(Now and forever

I promise to love you

Now and forever

You will never be alone

Now and forever

Be it in misery or in comfort

You will be sure to have someone with you, my love

I will be there always

You can count on me always

Now and forever.)

In 1992, Willy Cruz arranged the song for the movie of the same title which was produced by Viva Films with Sharon Cuneta and Richard Gomez as lead stars. It was also used as the title and theme song of an afternoon soap produced by GMA Network in 2009 starring Heart Evangelista and JC de Vera. True to its title, “Ngayon at Kailanman” is one of OPM’s more enduring songs.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes

photos.desc: Scene from Noli Me Tangere, 1987 (CCP Collection)

text:
(Touch Me Not). Written 1953. Premiered 1957. Music, Felipe Padilla de Leon; libretto, Guillermo Tolentino; orchestration, Felipe Padilla de Leon, Lucio D. San Pedro, and Lucino T. Sacramento. Premiered and produced by the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines on 5 Feb 1957. Restaged in 1987 by the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) with the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra performing under the baton of the composer. Cast (1957): Juanita Javier, Don David, Fides Cuyugan-Asensio, Milo Cristobal, Vicente Antiporda, Dolly Buencamino-Francia, Philip Santos.

 

Based on Jose Rizal’s 1887 novel of the same name, the three-act work is hailed as “the first truly Filipino opera.” It is best remembered for the arias that now grace the repertory of Filipino singers. “Kay Tamis ng Buhay” (Life is Sweet), for lyric soprano, follows the kundiman form and is noted for its haunting lyricism. “Awit ng Gabi” (Music of the Night), for coloratura, the aria of the insane Sisa, is based on the awit and tagulaylay. “Di ba Sila ang Nagpapatay?” (Didn’t They Order the Murders?), for tenor, demands a soaring, dramatic voice.

The opera was revived in 1987 by the CCP to commemorate the centennial of the publication of the novel Noli Me Tangere. This production featured Andion Fernandez/Nanette Moscardon-Maigue (Maria Clara), Nolyn Cabahug/Sal’My Neo Malaki (Crisostomo Ibarra), Fides Cuyugan-Asensio/Luz Morete (Sisa), Elmo Makil (Elias), and Nomer Son (Padre Damaso), with the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra under the baton of the composer himself. In celebration of the birth centennial of Felipe Padilla de Leon, the Dulaang UP on its 37th season, 2012, restaged the work at the Wilfrido Ma. Guerrero Theater of the University of the Philippines. It was directed by Alexander Cortez with musical direction by Camille Lopez Molina. It featured Ivan Nery (Jovita Fuentes Vocal Competition winner) who alternated with Antonio Ferrer as Crisostomo Ibarra, Myramae Meneses/Elainne Vibal (Maria Clara), Aissa Guilatco (Tia Isabel), Elainne Vibal/Jean Judith Javier (Sisa), and Jonathan Velasco/Michael Bulaong/Christopher Ong (Padre Damaso). The opera was restaged at the Newport Performing Arts Theater, Resorts World Manila, Pasay City in 2014. Featured artists were Maria Rachelle R. Gerodias/Myramae T. Meneses (Maria Clara), Sal Malaki/Ivan Niccolo C. Nery (Crisostomo Ibarra), Antoni Mendezona/Jean Judith Z. Javier (Sisa), Noel P. Azcona/Greg A. De Leon (Elias), Andrew Fernando/Jonathan Velasco (Padre Damaso), and Maria Carmila L. Molina (Tia Isabel). It was directed by Freddie Santos, with the Manila Philharmonic Orchestra conducted by Rodel Colmenar.  Written by Antonio C. Hila, updated by Josephine Cecilia L. Baradas

text:
2006. Music and lyrics, Nathan Alarcon. Performed by Bamboo and appeared in the album As the Music Plays, which was released in 2004 by EMI Philippines, Inc.

The band Bamboo—headed by singer-songwriter Bamboo Mañalac—is best known for the songs “Noypi,” “Hallelujah,” and “Masaya” (Happy), all of which rouse the crowds in hard-banging fashion. The song’s mass appeal and popularity may be partly traced to its lyrics, which hew closely to the supernatural myth of the Filipinos’ prowess, which is attributed to an “agimat… (sa) dugo” (talisman in the blood) that renders them resilient and smiling in the face of adversity and hardship.

 

“Noypi” (the word Pinoy in reverse) has been hailed as a pop culture anthem of Pinoy pride and strength by fans and industry observers alike. In a stirring game of basketball, which pitted the national team Gilas against its age-old nemesis South Korea in Aug 2013, “Noypi” blared over loudspeakers at the Mall of Asia Arena along with Francis Magalona’s “Mga Kababayan Ko” (My Countrymen) to shore up not only populist sentiments but also indicate energy and moral support for the national team.

At the 2005 Awit Awards, the song was awarded Best Performance of a New Duo or Group Recording Artists, the Best Rock Recording of the Year, and People’s Choice Favorite Song of the Year. MTV and radio station NU 107 Rock Awards also feted the song with Listener’s Choice and Song of the Year.  Written by Lara Katrina T. Mendoza

Sources

text:
1981. Composed, arranged, produced, and recorded by Ryan Cayabyab.

The long-playing album One, an all-time bestseller and landmark in Philippine music, was completed under the Jem Recording label. A one-man multitrack a capella work featuring 10 songs in 16 voices, One features six Filipino classics: “Dahil sa Iyo” (Because of You), “Minamahal, Sinasamba” (Loved, Adored), “Maalaala Mo Kaya?” (Will You Remember?), “Bakya Mo, Neneng” (Your Wooden Clogs, Neneng), “Hindi Kita Malimot” (I Cannot Forget You), and “Saan Ka Man Naroroon” (Wherever You Are), plus four Cayabyab originals: “Limang-dipang Tao” (Five Armstretches), “Mamang Kutsero” (Mr. Rig-driver), “Tsismis” (Gossip), and the first Metro Manila Popular Music Festival grand-prize winner “Kay Ganda ng Ating Musika” (How Beautiful Is Our Music). The long-playing album is hailed as the first of its kind in Philippine recording and possibly in the world.

 

The album is considered revolutionary and experimental for its highly innovative recording techniques. It highlights Cayabyab’s skills as composer, arranger, and recording artist. By means of masterful musical technology (mixing, bouncing, doubling, and overdubbing), the album focuses on Cayabyab’s voice split into multiple tracks as solo voice, backup, and choral combination. The album is a result of the use of creative and innovative recording techniques, resonant choral harmonies, and idiomatically unique arrangements. Vocal arrangements and all other aspects of album production were handled by Cayabyab.

The album was followed up by another collection using the same format 10 years later titled One Christmas, and 20 years later with still another titled One More. One Christmas was released by Telesis in 1991. It includes songs arranged and performed by Cayabyab: “Heto Na Naman” (Here It Is Again), “Miss Kita Kung Christmas” (I Miss You at Christmastime), “Kumukutikutitap” (Sparkling), “Ang Aking Pamasko” (My Christmas Gift), “Ano’ng Gagawin Mo Ngayong Pasko” (What Are You Doing This Christmas?), “Noche Buena” (Christmas Eve), “Pasko Na, Sinta Ko” (It’s Christmas, My Love), “Maligayang Pasko at Masaganang Bagong Taon” (Merry Christmas and a Prosperous New Year), “Himig Pasko” (Christmas Melody), and “Payapang Daigdig” (Peaceful World). One More was released by Sony BMG in 2001. The tracks included are “Da Coconut Nut,” “Sa May Bintana” (By The Window), “Paraiso” (Paradise), “Nais Ko” (I Desire), “Kahit Ika’y Panaginip Lang” (Even If You’re Only a Dream), “Kailan” (When), “Awit ni Isagani” (Isagani’s Song), “Mama” (Mother), “Paraisong Parisukat” (Square Paradise), and “Hideaway.”  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by Christina Maria P. Cayabyab

photos.desc: Album cover of Jose Maceda: Gongs and Bamboos, 2001, which includes “Pagsamba” (Tzadik Records)

text:
(Worship). 1968. Music, Jose Maceda.

A massive avant-garde composition that is structured at the macro level according to the five parts of the Mass Ordinary (“Kyrie,” “Gloria,” “Credo,” “Sanctus,” and “Agnus Dei”). It is composed for 241 performers and was premiered on 24 Jan 1968 at the University of the Philippines (UP) Chapel of the Holy Sacrifice, by the Ellinwood Chancel Choir, Far Eastern University Glee Club, University of the East Mixed Concert Chorus, students of the UP Conservatory of Music, UP Christian Youth Movement Choir, UP Madrigal Singers, UP Mixed Concert Chorus, and UP Student Catholic Action. Pagsamba was performed in Bonn, West Germany in 1980 and had a repeat in the same UP Chapel, with reduced number of performers, in early 2000s.

 

Described by the composer himself as music for a religious ritual, this piece is however more art than religion, except that the two share the idea of ritual. This is Maceda’s fourth major work after Ugma-ugma, premiered in Los Angeles in 1963; Agungan, 1966; and Kubing, 1966. It is scored for 100 singers symbolizing the “people,” 100 instrumentalists playing five types of indigenous Philippine instruments (whistles, buzzers, sticks, clappers, and scrapers), eight gandingan (gongs with shallow rims), eight agung (gongs with deep rims), and five male choirs, each consisting of five members. In its premiere, the work took advantage of the circular space of the UP Chapel of the Holy Sacrifice. The work was built as a general concept of communal, participative music in which the boundaries separating between artists and audience are breached. The even distribution of musical forces in a circle negates the concept of “political” hierarchy.

Heavily influenced by the avant-garde, post-serial music movement championed by Edgar Varese, Iannis Xenakis, Karlheinz Stockhausen, and by the late 1950s French musique concrete idiom spearheaded by Pierre Schaffer in Paris, Pagsamba puts primary focus on the interplay of the musical element of timbre and on the layering of sound masses. High and low voices of the 100-member choir, intoning “thick” and “thin” sonorities are juxtaposed with the smaller vocal ensembles, whose members chant, half-sing, and mumble disjointed vocables from the liturgical text. These contrasting atmospheric blocks of vocal sounds further contrast with the indeterminate sound strata of instruments, some of which articulate sustained sound events while others produce short sound attacks with no decays. The layering and interaction of these sound colors create “transparent,” “opaque,” “diffused” sound “screens” and “clouds,” a musical organization that is inimical to closed conventional Western musical forms built on tonal harmonic principles. Depending where one is physically positioned in performing and listening to this piece, sound experience is unique or contingent on the position of that performer or listener, an aural specificity that creates what Maceda calls “a stereophony of live sounds.”

The malleability in the individual aural experiencing and the indeterminacy in the sound layering finds a parallel in the setting of the text, which does not strive for intelligibility in the words. This flexibility also means that the Mass can be performed in any language and the acoustic instruments can be substituted with electronic gadgets, whose soundwaves can emit from 241 amplified speakers in a circle. Embodied in this piece is a philosophy of ritual, which emphasizes human capital, joint work or social cooperation, in which individuals can be substituted for each other or by instruments, as long as collective participation is maintained.  Written by Jose S. Buenconsejo

Source

 

Pagsamba 1968.

photos.desc:
Movie poster of Pakiusap, 1940

(Cesar Hernando Collection)

text:
(Plea). 1921. Music, Francisco Santiago; Tagalog lyrics, Jose Corazon de Jesus; Spanish lyrics, Jesus Balmori.

 

Cast in slow triple time, this song is one of the most popular art songs of Santiago. Santiago composed his fourth kundiman, “Pakiusap,” while teaching at the University of the Philippines Conservatory of Music. The song appears in two languages, Tagalog and Spanish, composed by Jose Corazon de Jesus and Jesus Balmori, respectively. In 1929, it was sung by visiting artist Amelita Galli-Curci at the Manila Grand Opera House. It has also been arranged for strings by Restie Umali and for orchestra by Hilarion F. Rubio. The song became even more popular in 1940 when it was used as the title and theme song for an Octavio Silos movie which starred Rosario Moreno and Rudy Concepcion.

“Pakiusap” presents a melodramatic portrait of the Filipino as a pauper in love. The melody is disconsolate and the plaintive text articulates the image of a hapless pauper beseeching the love of a fair maiden in anguished tones. Its famous ending goes:

Pakiusap ko sa ’yo

Kaawaan mo ako

Kahit mamatay

Pag-ibig ko’y minsan lamang

Iniibig kita

Magpakailanman.

(I only ask you

To have mercy on me

Even if I die

I have only one love

I love you

Forever.)

“Pakiusap” has been performed by sopranos Sylvia La Torre in her CD album titled Kundiman and Conching Rosal in her CD album Immortal Kundiman of the Philippines. The song has been recently arranged by Joy Nilo and performed by the Philippine Madrigal Singers in 2013, and the Ateneo Chamber Singers in 2015.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by James C. Diaz

article.value: (Plea). 1921. Music, Francisco Santiago; Tagalog lyrics, Jose Corazon de Jesus; Spanish lyrics, Jesus Balmori.

value.desc:
Movie poster of Pakiusap, 1940

(Cesar Hernando Collection)

article.value: Cast in slow triple time, this song is one of the most popular art songs of Santiago. Santiago composed his fourth kundiman, “Pakiusap,” while teaching at the University of the Philippines Conservatory of Music. The song appears in two languages, Tagalog and Spanish, composed by Jose Corazon de Jesus and Jesus Balmori, respectively. In 1929, it was sung by visiting artist Amelita Galli-Curci at the Manila Grand Opera House. It has also been arranged for strings by Restie Umali and for orchestra by Hilarion F. Rubio. The song became even more popular in 1940 when it was used as the title and theme song for an Octavio Silos movie which starred Rosario Moreno and Rudy Concepcion.

“Pakiusap” presents a melodramatic portrait of the Filipino as a pauper in love. The melody is disconsolate and the plaintive text articulates the image of a hapless pauper beseeching the love of a fair maiden in anguished tones. Its famous ending goes:
Pakiusap ko sa ’yo
Kaawaan mo ako
Kahit mamatay
Pag-ibig ko’y minsan lamang
Iniibig kita
Magpakailanman.
(I only ask you
To have mercy on me
Even if I die
I have only one love
I love you
Forever.)

“Pakiusap” has been performed by sopranos Sylvia La Torre in her CD album titled Kundiman and Conching Rosal in her CD album Immortal Kundiman of the Philippines. The song has been recently arranged by Joy Nilo and performed by the Philippine Madrigal Singers in 2013, and the Ateneo Chamber Singers in 2015.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by James C. Diaz

text:
(When The Time Comes). 2001. Music, Dennis Quila; lyrics, Moy Ortiz and Edith Gallardo. First performed by Aiza Seguerra. The song is included in her album of the same title under Vicor Records.

The ballad’s sentimental melody made the song the biggest OPM hit in 2001, remaining on the charts for the rest of that year. The appeal of the song comes from the inherent sweetness of the voice of Aiza Seguerra, which was enhanced further with resonance in the studio. The sweetness of Seguerra’s vocals matches the simple treatment of the music made up of a singable melody in E major and an easy-to-listen rhythmic accompaniment. The form of the piece is verse-chorus, each section of which has a well-balanced phrasing aabb (verse 12 bars + 12 bars followed by 8 bars + 8 bars of chorus). The second repetition of the chorus leads to a bridge of eight measures. After this, a modulation steps up further to brighten the message of the piece, which is about hope for the reciprocation of an unrequited love:

 

Alam kong hindi mo pansin

Narito lang ako

Naghihintay na mahalin

Umaasa kahit di man ngayon

Mapapansin mo rin

Mapapansin mo rin

Alam kong di mo makita

Narito lang ako

Hinihintay lagi kita

Umaasa kahit di man ngayon

Hahanapin mo rin

Hahanapin din

(I know you don’t notice

I’m just here

Waiting to be loved

Hoping, maybe not today

Someday you’ll notice

Someday you’ll notice

I know you don’t see it

I’m just here

Waiting for you always

Hoping, maybe not today

You’ll be looking for me

You’ll be looking for me)

Viva Films immediately rode on the song’s popularity and used “Pagdating ng Panahon” as the theme song for a reunion movie of Sharon Cuneta and Robin Padilla of the same title in 2001. It won the Best Theme Song award from the Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS).

The song remains a favorite theme song among several television series. Pop singer Bryan Termulo recorded it as one of the songs in the official sound track of the television drama series Dahil sa Pag-ibig and was also sold as Original Motion Picture Soundtrack. Teen idol Kathryn Bernardo’s version of “Pagdating ng Panahon” was also used as one of the songs in the official soundtrack for the 2013 romantic comedy television series Got to Believe.

The song jumpstarted Seguerra’s music career and is his signature song to date. The album Pagdating ng Panahon reached Quintuple Platinum status after its release in 2001. The song bagged Best Pop Recording, Best Produced Record of the Year, Song of the Year, and Best Performance by a Female Recording Artist in the 2002 Awit Awards.  Written by Samantha Louise R. Bigcas, with additional notes from Jose S. Buenconsejo

photos.desc:
Nanette Moscardon-Maigue singing
“Pamaypay ng Maynila” (CCP Collection)

text:
(Fan of Manila). Date of composition unknown. Music and lyrics, Constancio de Guzman.

Written in the balitaw style with a moderate tempo, it is bipartite with the first part in minor key and the second part in the parallel major key. Despite the key change in the second part, the shape and contour of the melody is similar to that of the first. The shift of the harmonic underpinning, however, makes the song bright and cheerful.

The song tells of the language of the fan as used by supposedly demure young ladies. Depending on the gestures used when fanning, a wide gamut of attitudes and emotions are conveyed—from shyness and coyness to outright and flirtatious expressions of love. Some of the lyrics are:

Kung ito’y nakatabing

Sa tapat ng mukha ko

Ang ibig na sabihin

Ay nahihiya ang puso ko.

Ngunit pagmasdan mo

Ang sulyap ko’y sa iyo

Ang ibig kong sabihin

May pag-asa ang puso mo.

Pag ito’y pinamaspas

Ng panay at matulin

Ako ay nagagalit

Huwag mo sanang babatiin.

Subalit pagbanayad

May ngiti pa at lambing

Ako ay umiibig

Lapitan mo, aking giliw.

(If it covers

My face

It means

That my heart is shy.

But if you glance at me

And my eyes are on you

It means

That your heart can hope.

If I fan it

Vigorously

I may be angry

Don’t greet me.

But if I use it gently

With smile and affection

Then I am in love

Come near me, darling.) Written by Corazon C. Dioquino

photos.desc: “Pamugon,” popularized by the Philippine Madrigal Singers, 2008 (Nico Valenzuela)

text:
(Sparrow). 1995. Music, Francisco Feliciano. Text based on Maguindanaon children’s game song. Published by Santa Barbara Music Publishing Company, California, 1995.

 

Like “Pokpok Alimpako,” “Pamugon” is a crowd pleaser and is performed by many choirs in the Philippines, especially in international competitions. It is one of the three works by Feliciano that form the “Mindanao Trilogy.” “Pokpok Alimpako” and “Enduken” are the other pieces. Its text, which is in Maguindanaon, is a children’s game song featuring word play between a hunter and a sparrow:

Pamugun, Pamugun, gkagutem aku.

Gkagutem ka bun, ka di ka bpanegkau.

Manegkau aku, na seleden aku.

Seleden ka bun, ka di ka malagui.

Malagui aku, na timbaken aku.

Timbaken ka bun, ka di ka magenna

Magenna aku, na kayaten aku.

Kayaten ka bun, ka di ka mamusug.

Mamusug aku, na sugkalen aku.

Sugkalen ka bun, ka di ka pedtipu.

Temibpu aku, na malepu aku.

Malepu ka bun, ka di ka mapagud. .

Mapagud aku, na masigken aku.

Masigken ka bun, ka di ka bpeledtu.

Lemedtu aku, na sayaben aku.

Sayaben ka bun, ka di ka demedsuk.

Demedsuk aku, na litagen aku.

Litagen ka bun, u di ka pebpatai.

(Sparrow, sparrow, I am hungry.

You will be hungry if you don’t steal.

If I steal I will be chased.

You will be chased if you don’t run.

If I run I will be shot.

You will be shot if you don’t hide.

If I hide I will be found.

You will be found if you don’t climb.

If I climb I will be poked.

You will be poked if you don’t jump.

If I jump I will be sprained.

You will be sprained if you are not massaged

If I am massaged I might be caught.

You will be caught if you don’t soar.

If I soar I will be swooped upon.

You will be swooped upon if you don’t dive.

If I dive I will be trapped.

You will be trapped if you haven’t died.)

The work was performed several times by the UP Singing Ambassadors in international competitions in Europe, where the group garnered top prizes, namely, Grand Prize in the Festival Choral International de Neuchatel in Switzerland; First Prize, chamber choir category, in Llangolen Musical Eisteddfod in Llangolen, Wales; First Prize, mixed choir category in the Bela Bartok 23rd International Choir Competition in Debrecen, Hungary; Third Prize, open category, in the Concours International de Chant Choral 2008 in Tours, France; and Third Prize, folkloric category, in the Festival Internacional de Musica de Cantonigros in Spain.  Written by Antonio C. Hila

text:
(Stonehearted). Ilocano folk song.

This traditional Ilocano folk song in polka rhythm is a humorous exchange between a passionate suitor and a nonchalant, haughty, and contemptuous maiden:

 

Male:

Pamulinawen, pusok indengam man

Toy umas-asug, agrayo ta sadiam

Panunotem man, dika pagintutulngan

Toy agayat, agrayo ta sadiam.

(Stonehearted one, my heart please hear

I who am pleading, longing for your charm

Kindly consider, be not deaf

To this admirer, longing for your charm.)

Female:

Uray no mano karutap ti pagbatayam

A gumaw-at kaniak

Dikanto kunaen a magaw-atnak

Ta azucenaak a napnuan dayak.

(Though many layers you may stand on

To reach me

You never can claim you can reach me

For I am the azucena flower full of beauty.)

It may be sung and danced simultaneously by the couple. Kitongtong or rice pounding, a vital part of the preparations for an Ilocano wedding feast, is done to the beat of the song.

Arranged by various Filipino composers, Lucio D. San Pedro’s sprightly arrangement, written for the UP Concert Chorus, is among the finer examples of these. It was also used as one of the themes in Eliseo M. Pajaro’s The Life of Lam-ang. A version for male choir was arranged by Emmanuel Laureola, and an alternative melancholic setting for mixed choir was penned by Francisco F. Feliciano. Feliciano’s arrangement is included in the Philippine Madrigal Singers’ collection titled Mga Awiting Bayan (Folk Songs). Antonio Regalario has arranged it for children’s choir, in a version commissioned by the UP Cherubim and Seraphim, and recorded in their album Wings. It has also been arranged for piano by Augusto Espino, and included in his collection of Filipino folk songs transcribed for piano titled Guhit Tugtugin at Seleksiyon (Piano Sketches and Selections). In 2015, Ryan Cayabyab’s orchestral arrangement of the song for the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra was included in the CD Serenata (Serenade) of the Cultural Center of the Philippines.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

photos.desc: Pandanggo sa ilaw by the Ramon Obusan Folkloric Group, Noon Po sa Amin, CCP, Manila, 2005 (CCP Collection)

text:
(Fandango with Oil Lamps). 1946. Attributed to Antonino R. Buenaventura.

The piano instrumental accompaniment for the folk dance “Pandanggo sa Ilaw” from Mindoro Island was composed by Antonino R. Buenaventura. The piece appeared in Francisca Reyes-Tolentino’s publication Philippine National Dances, 1946. It is not certain whether Buenaventura “notated” the melody that he got from a culture bearer of this dance from Mindoro, or if he “composed” this in the style of the folk in collaboration with Reyes-Tolentino. Buenaventura, together with Francisco Santiago, H. Otley Beyer, Cecilio Lopez, Antonio Molina, and Ramon P. Tolentino Jr. They were part of a team commissioned to document Philippine folk dances and songs by then University of the Philippines president Jorge Bocobo from 1934 to 1938 (Salamanca 1985, 214).

 

The dance is in triple time and is in three parts ABC, each of which is sixteen measures in length and is repeated. In sections A and B, the key is in G minor, but this shifts to parallel major in G in the third.  Written by Jose S. Buenconsejo

Source

 

Salamanca, Bonifacio. 1985. “Bocobo Fosters a Vibrant Nationalism (1934-1939).” In University of the Philippines: The First 75 Years (1908-1983) by Oscar M. Alfonso and Leslie E. Bauzon. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

text:
Published 1959. Music arrangement, Levi Celerio, with the possible collaboration of Johnny Benasa; lyrics, Levi Celerio.

A three-part ternary work, it grew in popularity, especially after the new lyrics by Celerio and the spirited rendition of Rufina Esperancilla in the 1961 Tawag ng Tanghalan (Call of the Stage) song competition avidly followed by a large audience on television.

 

In 1969, Restie Umali arranged a choral concert version of this piece for soprano, alto, and bass, which was used in the 1964 Sampaguita film Sa Libis ng Baryo (At the Edge of the Barrio). Its opening lyrics set to balitaw rhythm run:

Manunugtog ay nangagpasimula

At nangagsayawan ang mga mutya

Sa mga padyak parang magigiba

Ang bawat tapakan ng mga bakya.

(The musicians started playing

And the beautiful ladies began to dance

The stamping of their feet almost demolished

All that their wooden clogs stepped on.)

The second part features a slow harana-like section in triple time. The third section, employing the fandango rhythm, is in a driving triple meter that builds excitement by alternating the tonic and dominant chords to an accelerating tempo. The final section returns to the initial pandanggo melody and a rousing finale.

As folk dance music material, earlier arrangements of the pandangguhan are found in Diego C. Perez’s 1886 piano medley Recuerdos de Filipinas (Memories of the Philippines) and Jose A. Estella’s suite Philippine Panoramas, ca 1920s. The song has also been included in records cut by Sylvia La Torre and Pilita Corrales, among others.  Written by Antonio C. Hila

text:
(Country Butterfly). Tagalog folk song.

A balitaw mayor, this traditional Tagalog folk song is bipartite, with both parts in major key and a lively waltz rhythm. It likens a country lass in her wide-sleeved camisa and sayang de cola (long-trained skirt) to a butterfly fluttering about. The vain young woman adorns her hair with two combs. She primps herself up before the mirror, then sashays down the street, her embroidered slip peeking out of her skirt. The second part goes:

 

May peineta pa siya, uy!

May suklay pa man din,

Naguas de ojete

Ang palalabasin

Haharap sa altar

At mananalamin

At saka lalakad

Nang pakendeng-kendeng.

(She wears a large decorative comb, uy!

And a smaller comb too,

Her slip of eyelet

Peeps out from under her skirt

She faces the altar,

Primps herself up before the mirror

And then walks off,

Swaying her hips.

The lilting rhythm mimics the maiden’s walk. In the first part, the fluttering of butterfly wings is suggested by rapidly repeated notes at the beginning of each phrase. In the second part, the opening leaps of intervals of the seventh and sixth of the melodic phrases suggest the flirtatious sway of the hips. Fabian V. Obispo’s arrangement of the song for the UP Madrigal Singers underlines the playfulness of the text by alliterative repetitions of the word paruparo. The song inspired several movies which adopted it as title. The first of these was the Sampaguita film musical starring Elsa Oria. It was directed by Octavio Silos in 1938.  Written by Corazon C. Dioquino

article.value: (Country Butterfly). Tagalog folk song.

A balitaw mayor, this traditional Tagalog folk song is bipartite, with both parts in major key and a lively waltz rhythm. It likens a country lass in her wide-sleeved camisa and sayang de cola (long-trained skirt) to a butterfly fluttering about. The vain young woman adorns her hair with two combs. She primps herself up before the mirror, then sashays down the street, her embroidered slip peeking out of her skirt. The second part goes:

value.desc:
Elsa Oria in Paruparong Bukid, on the cover of

Literary Song Movie Magazine, 1938 (Cesar Hernando Collection)

article.value: May peineta pa siya, uy!
May suklay pa man din,
Naguas de ojete
Ang palalabasin
Haharap sa altar
At mananalamin
At saka lalakad
Nang pakendeng-kendeng.
(She wears a large decorative comb, uy!
And a smaller comb too,
Her slip of eyelet
Peeps out from under her skirt
She faces the altar,
Primps herself up before the mirror
And then walks off,
Swaying her hips.

The lilting rhythm mimics the maiden’s walk. In the first part, the fluttering of butterfly wings is suggested by rapidly repeated notes at the beginning of each phrase. In the second part, the opening leaps of intervals of the seventh and sixth of the melodic phrases suggest the flirtatious sway of the hips. Fabian V. Obispo’s arrangement of the song for the UP Madrigal Singers underlines the playfulness of the text by alliterative repetitions of the word paruparo. The song inspired several movies which adopted it as title. The first of these was the Sampaguita film musical starring Elsa Oria. It was directed by Octavio Silos in 1938.  Written by Corazon C. Dioquino

photos.desc: “Ang Pasko ay Sumapit” lyrics card (CCP Collection)

text:
(Christmas is Here). 1933. Music, Vicente Rubi; Cebuano lyrics, Mariano Vestil; Tagalog lyrics, Levi Celerio.

Cast in lively duple time, the song’s beginnings may be traced to the celebration of the Cebuano feast of the Pili-Kanipaan in December, where the most popular forms of entertainment were light musical plays. Rafael Policarpio, a Cebuano playwright, needed a song for a drama which called for a cluster of people with tansan or softdrink crowns used as accompaniment to the singing of the daygon (Christmas carols) at the gate of a big house in exchange for a pinaskuhan or gift. Lyricist Mariano Vestil wrote the original Cebuano text, “Kasadya Ning Takna-a” (How Happy Is This Time) to Rubi’s lilting melody, and the song became an instant hit after its first performance in Old Opon (now Lapu-Lapu City). Seventeen years later, the song was recorded under the Mareco label, manufacturer of Villar Records.

 

Now immortalized in the annals of Philippine Christmas carols, “Ang Pasko Ay Sumapit” bids us to make merry with festive songs during the season, but with a sobering reminder of the ensuing new year and a fresh, new start to life. Its Tagalog lyrics which are known to most Filipinos run:

Ang pasko ay sumapit

Tayo ay mangagsiawit

Ng magagandang himig

Dahil sa ang Diyos

Ay pag-ibig.

(Christmas is here

Let us sing

Lovely hymns

Because God

Is love.)  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes

photos.desc: Shadow puppet carolers by Anino Shadowplay Collective, 2012 (Anino Shadowplay Collective)

text:
(It’s Christmas Once Again). 1965. Music, Felipe Padilla de Leon; lyrics, Levi Celerio. Arranged for band and for choir and chamber orchestra by Lucio D. San Pedro in 1976.

Commonly heard during Christmas, this popular two-part paso doble carol shifts from minor to major tonality. The choral setting is for a mixedchoir. It is a fitting final song for the misa de aguinaldo or dawn mass. Its lyrics go:

 

Pasko na naman

O kay tulin ng araw

Paskong nagdaan

Tila parang kailan lang

Ngayon ay pasko

Dapat pasalamatan

Ngayon ay pasko

Tayo ay magbigayan.

(It’s Christmas once again

Oh how swiftly the days have passed

Christmas past

Seems just yesterday

It’s Christmas now

We should be thankful

It’s Christmas now

Let us give to one another.)  Written by Antonio C. Hila

photos.desc:
Album cover of Gary V. Merry Christmas, 2006,

which includes “Pasko na Sinta Ko” (Universal Records)

text:
(It’s Christmas, My Love). 1976. Music, Francis M. Dandan; lyrics, Aurelio Estanislao. Arranged by Lucio D. San Pedro. First performed by Traders Royal Bank Chorale in 1976 at the Manila Hotel.

 

This song is a poignant expression of longing for a lost love at Christmas time:

Pasko na sinta ko

Hanap-hanap kita

Bakit nagtatampo

At iniwan ako?

Kung mawawala ka

Sa piling ko sinta

Paano ang paskong

Alay ko sa iyo.

(It’s Christmas, my love

I search for you.

Why have you withdrawn from me

And deserted me?

If you disappear

From my side, beloved

What will happen to the Christmas

That I wish to offer to you.)

Its two parts are repeated with a codetta or extension at the end, which is known for its lovely deceptive cadence, and the sixth chord that closes the piece. Its nostalgic melody highlights the poignancy of the lyrics.

After Gary Valenciano recorded it in 1986, the song became even more popular.  Written by Antonio C. Hila

text:
(Peaceful World). 1946. Music, Felipe Padilla de Leon; lyrics, Eduardo de Leon and Brigido Batungbakal.

 

The song was inspired by the ending of World War II and has since then become a favorite Christmas song. Padilla de Leon wrote the song in four parts (ABCD) and employed the villancico rhythm. The work consists of a solo part for soprano and tenor. Its lyrics have become famous:

Ang gabi’y payapa

Lahat ay tahimik

Pati mga tala

Sa bughaw na langit.

Kay hinhin ng hangin

Waring umiibig

Sa kapayapaan

Ng buong daigdig.

(The night is peaceful

All is silent

Even the stars

In the blue skies.

The wind is gentle

As if full of love

For the peace

In the world.)

The song is also a staple in the repertoire of both professional and amateur choirs. In 1977, Lucio D. San Pedro rearranged the piece for children and mixed choir for the UP Cherubim and Seraphim. The Philippine Madrigal Singers also have their own version of the song.  Written by Antonio C. Hila
