article_title: PequeÃ±a Misa Solemne Sobre Motivos de la Missa Regia del Canto Gregoriano
text:
(Short Solemn Mass Using the Motives of the Missa Regia of Gregorian Chant). 1904. Composer, Marcelo Adonay.

 

This mass is arguably the composer’s most important composition. It is based on motives from the Missa Regia, the third mass in the collection Cinq messes en plein-chant, 1669, by the Flemish composer Henri Du Mont. Composed between 1901 and 1903, the Pequeña Misa was performed for the first time at the San Agustin Church on 28 Aug 1904 by the Rizal Orchestra conducted by the composer. The original scores of this work have been lost but two modern settings, based on two sets of parts copied by students of Adonay—Alejandro Macabasco and Ceferino Pasang—which were found in the Pakil Parish Church archives, have been reconstructed and published in The Life and Works of Marcelo Adonay, 2010. The parts copied by Macabasco are for a smaller orchestra than the version copied by Pasang, suggesting that the composer might have reset the Pequeña Misa to suit the capacities of the different orchestras that performed the work.

The work is a masterful display of compositional technique by a mature artist, displaying the effects of the winds of change sweeping through the musical establishment of the turn-of-the-century Roman Catholic Church. The unifying element of the mass—the use of the opening motive of the Missa Regia in four of the Pequeña Misa movements and scattered references to other motives from the Dumont work in the body of the Gloria—is reminiscent of the compositional technique of the motto cycle/motto mass of the 15th to 17th centuries. This grounding in traditional form is set against the high Romantic idiomatic language found in the work. The passionate and emotional quality of the harmonies and rhythms and the exuberant orchestration of the music, especially in the Gloria and Agnus Dei, firmly establishes the composition as part of a late 19th century development.

The Pequeña Misa has been performed on a number of occasions. Notable among these were performances at the Pasig Church on 8 December 1904, again with the composer conducting the Rizal Orchestra to celebrate the arrival of the Virgin of Antipolo in Manila. Two other performances—at the Malate Church on 23 Nov 1941 as part of the celebration of the Malate town fiesta and at the Quiapo Church on 23 Jun 1946 to celebrate the liberation of Manila—were conducted by Antonio Molina, an admirer of the older composer. These were sponsored by the Amihan Society, which counted as members the composer’s daughter and son-in-law, Marietta Adonay Cadsawan and Paulino Cadsawan, respectively. A performance at the San Miguel Pro Cathedral on 5 Oct 1953 was also conducted by Molina for Centro Escolar College. After a hiatus of 46 years, the work experienced a revival. It was performed on 1 Mar 1999, at the San Agustin Church with Herminigildo Rañera conducting the Coro Tomasino, the Liturgikon Choir, and the Chamber Orchestra of the University of Santo Tomas, with Fr Manuel P. Maramba at the organ. On 18 Nov of the same year, the work was again performed for the First San Agustin International Music Festival with Joel Navarro conducting the Ateneo Glee Club and the Philippine Philharmonic Chamber Orchestra. The most recent performance was the North American premiere of the work, on 29 Jun 2014 at the Glendale City Church in California, conducted by Christopher Yraola as part of a recital in fulfillment of his Master of Music degree in Choral Conducting at the California State University, Los Angeles.  Written by Elena Rivera Mirano

Source

 

Rivera Mirano, Elena, ed. 2010. The Life and Works of Marcelo Adonay. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

text:
1935. Music, Ramon Tapales. This programmatic orchestral suite has three movements: “Mindanao Orchids,” “Tagalog Lullaby,” and “Mindoro Savage Dance.”

“Mindanao Orchids” is an impressionistic interpretation of Mindanao dances in which the dancers take the form of orchids.

 

“Tagalog Lullaby” is based on the folk tune “Hele Na” (Hush) which is traditionally sung by mothers to rock their babies to sleep. The movement evokes images of a rustic farmer’s wife singing to the accompaniment of rustling bamboo trees beside her nipa hut.

“Mindoro Savage Dance” is a fantasy on the “war dance” of the Mangyan. This ethnolinguistic group is not known to be warlike and the idea of a ritual dance for warfare is most probably merely imagined by the composer.  Written by Corazon C. Dioquino

text:
(Seven Gantas). Music, Antonio Maiquez; lyrics, Levi Celerio. Originally sung by Fred Panopio (under Jessica Records) for the movie of the same title (1959).

Sung in the yodelling style of American western genre movies, “Pitong Gatang” is a novelty song from an action movie set in the Tondo district in the 1950’s. Cast in duple time, it sounds like a happy cowboy song but it is a sarcastically funny description of the life situation in a street called “Pitong Gatang,” where the istambay (unemployed toughies) do nothing all day and the tsismoso (rumormongers) feast on the secret lives of others. The violence and intrigue are so prevalent, the song suggests, that if you wish to live peacefully here, you just have to pretend you are dead. In the last stanza of the song, however, the persona claims that he is just having fun and does not mean any harm:

 

Itong aking inaawit

Ang tamaa’y huwag magalit

Iyan naman ay bunga lang

Niyaring isip.

(This song I’m singing

Should not infuriate those concerned

For this is just the fruit

Of my imagination.)

The song has been recorded by a number of singers including Yoyoy Villame and Asin, but is associated with Fred Panopio who was responsible for making it a big hit. Written by Michael M. Coroza

text:
1948. Music, Francisco Buencamino. Arrangement for string orchestra, Lucino T. Sacramento. First performed in the same year by the Manila Little Symphony Orchestra with Federico Elizalde conducting.

 

Pizzicato Caprice evokes a distinctly native flavor, and is performed using the pizzicato (plucked string) technique. The effect is happy, lilting, and fanciful. This work uses the theme of an earlier work by the composer titled “Ang Larawan” (The Portrait), 1943, a piece for solo piano written along the traditional lines of the balitaw and kundiman, which has been played as an encore by Buencamino’s grandniece, Cecile Licad, in many of her concerts both here and abroad.

Buencamino was known for creating genuine Filipino music that preserved native folk melodies. This work was dedicated to his friend and patron of the arts, Victorina Lobregat. Pizzicato Caprice has also been arranged for the marimba and other instruments by Lucino T. Sacramento and popularized by musicians like Ernestina Crisologo.

The Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra performed the work in Hibik ng Diwa (Cry of Spirit), held in honor of the composer in Nov 1988 at the Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). The piece is also a favorite of UP Arco, a student string orchestra of the University of the Philippines College of Music under Edna Marcil Martinez, who played it in CCP in 2010 and in Europe between 2013 and 2015.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes

photos.desc: “Pokpok Alimpako” sung by the UP Concert Chorus (Tiara Aracama)

text:
1981. Music, Francisco Feliciano. It forms part one of three works comprising the choral suite of songs from Mindanao titled The Mindanao Trilogy. “Pamugon” and “Enduken” comprise the other two works. The trilogy serves as Feliciano’s statement on the cultural roots of the problem in Mindanao. Feliciano avers that the failure to understand each other’s culture on the part of both Muslim and Christian Filipinos is what created the conflict. The trilogy pays homage to the traditional musical artistry of Muslims. Through it, the composer exhorts both power-wielding Manilans and Muslims in Mindanao to respect and understand each other’s culture. Below is the text:

 

Pokpok alimpako pok!

Limpakopiko malalago isi daling

Daon si Boroboro

Bukas kasa-isa

Pokpok alimpako!

(Pound your hands!

Dali will run

Boro-boro is not around

Open that hand under the other

Pound your hands!)

The text comes from a children’s game where each child makes a fist, putting this on top of the other fists. The topmost fist makes a pounding motion on the other fists as the song is sung. Then the lowermost fist is released, palms up, and the song is sung again. Fists are opened one at a time. Still together in a circle, the children then bring their hands upward with a jerky movement as they ruffle one another’s hair.

The composition is developed out of a motif from a Maranao melody. This melody exhibits interlocking rhythms, which is a compositional practice found in the music of the kulintang, a traditional Filipino ensemble consisting of several knobbed gongs and drum. The interlocking rhythmic patterns create a layered sound similar to most traditional Southeast Asian music.

The choral work won the best composition in contemporary music when the University of the Philippines (UP) Madrigal Singers sang it in the choral competition in Arezzo, Italy in 1981. Since then, it has been a favorite competition piece among Philippine choirs. In 1996, the Philippine Madrigal Singers sang it again, this time in Tolosa Abesbatz Lehaketa in Spain, where the group garnered First Prize in the folkloric category. The Ateneo de Manila College Glee Club also sang it in Tours, France in 2000 and won the special prize and best performance of a work composed in the second half of the 20th century. In addition, the UP Singing Ambassadors sang it during the international choral competition in Debrecen, Hungary where they won Third Prize in the chamber choir category in 2008. The piece has been recorded by the Anglo-Chinese Junior College Choir of Singapore and was featured at the ABC Classic FM Australia in Dec 1996. Earthsongs in Oregon published the piece in 2001.  Written by Antonio C. Hila

Open that hand under the other
Pound your hands!)

The text comes from a children’s game where each child makes a fist, putting this on top of the other fists. The topmost fist makes a pounding motion on the other fists as the song is sung. Then the lowermost fist is released, palms up, and the song is sung again. Fists are opened one at a time. Still together in a circle, the children then bring their hands upward with a jerky movement as they ruffle one another’s hair.

The composition is developed out of a motif from a Maranao melody. This melody exhibits interlocking rhythms, which is a compositional practice found in the music of the kulintang, a traditional Filipino ensemble consisting of several knobbed gongs and drum. The interlocking rhythmic patterns create a layered sound similar to most traditional Southeast Asian music.

The choral work won the best composition in contemporary music when the University of the Philippines (UP) Madrigal Singers sang it in the choral competition in Arezzo, Italy in 1981. Since then, it has been a favorite competition piece among Philippine choirs. In 1996, the Philippine Madrigal Singers sang it again, this time in Tolosa Abesbatz Lehaketa in Spain, where the group garnered First Prize in the folkloric category. The Ateneo de Manila College Glee Club also sang it in Tours, France in 2000 and won the special prize and best performance of a work composed in the second half of the 20th century. In addition, the UP Singing Ambassadors sang it during the international choral competition in Debrecen, Hungary where they won Third Prize in the chamber choir category in 2008. The piece has been recorded by the Anglo-Chinese Junior College Choir of Singapore and was featured at the ABC Classic FM Australia in Dec 1996. Earthsongs in Oregon published the piece in 2001.  Written by Antonio C. Hila

text:
(Rain is Falling). 1976. Music and lyrics, Danny Javier. First performed and recorded by the APO Hiking Society under Wea (now Universal) Records.

A Pinoy pop classic, this song in moderate duple time is considered one of the best compositions recorded by the trio of Danny Javier, Jim Paredes, and Buboy Garrovillo.

 

“Pumapatak …” can be viewed as a commentary on boredom and evokes the image of an adolescent with no money, desperately seeking temporary escape from ennui via the movies, television, radio, alcohol, food, comics, and trying to “survive” the endless rain that keeps him trapped indoors. In the end, he falls asleep from hunger and the lack of anything better to do. The opening lyrics follow:

Pumapatak na naman ang ulan

Sa bubong ng bahay

Di maiwasang gumawa

Ng di inaasahang bagay

Laklak nang laklak

Hanggang magdamagan

May kahirapan

Di maiwasan

Mabuti pa kaya,

Matulog ka na lang

At baka sumakit ang tiyan.

(Rain is falling again

On the roof of the house

And I can’t avoid

Doing the unexpected

Boozing

All night

It’s hard

And I can’t avoid it

It’s better perhaps,

To get some sleep

I might get stomach cramps.)

Accompanied by guitar and flute, “Pumapatak …” evokes the numbness and apathy of contemporary urban youth using raw and colloquial language.

The song was originally recorded by the APO Hiking Society in 1978 as part of their third album Pagkatapos ng Palabas (After the Show). This song has been revived in the 21st century by the pop-rock group Parokya ni Edgar in their 2002 album, Edgar Edgar Musikahan. Noel Cabangon also included the song in his 2012 album Tuloy ang Byahe (The Journey Continues). In 2011, the song was one of the APO Hiking Society songs performed by actor-singers in the Chris Martinez musical film I Dooby Dooby Doo.  Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

photos.desc: South Border members (Photo courtesy of South Border)

text:
2004. Music, Jay Durias; lyrics, Sharon Inductivo. First performed by South Border for their album Episode III released in 2004 under the independent music label Brown Hand Records.

 

“Rainbow” is a light, optimistic pop rock-R&B (rhythm and blues) song that encourages the listener not to give up hope and maintain a positive outlook in life even when it is replete with challenges. The catchy tune, sung with tender and breathy voices, is set to the common verse-refrain-chorus structure, each part of which is eight bars. In the key of F major, the song is arranged for acoustic instruments (guitar, cello, flute) with a transparent texture befitting the message of hope, of which the rainbow after the rain is a metaphor. In the verses, the undulating cyclical rhythm of life and nature is deliciously depicted by the alternation of the F major and F suspended chords. It segues to the refrain, which starts in A minor but ends up with a break on a foreign region in E-flat, thus underscoring the theme of the ineffable beauty of life. Then, like a rainbow, the chorus spreads its hues, evoking images of butterflies and birds by means of parallel chords. The feel-good inspirational lyrics and the dainty sequence of chords, not to mention the presence of fresh voices, have turned the song into a favorite among OPM fans.

“Rainbow” featured the band’s original lead singer Jay Durias in vocals, as well as the two new vocalists who replaced Luke Mejares when he left to pursue his own career: Duncan Ramos and Vince Alaras. It is one of the two hit singles—the other one being “Ikaw Nga” (It’s You Indeed), theme to the GMA fantasy TV series Mulawin—that introduced the new vocalists into the popular music scene and gave the band a youthful image while retaining their R&B characteristics.

A year before its release, “Rainbow” had already been used as a promotional single for the Metro Manila Film Festival entry Crying Ladies, which starred Sharon Cuneta, Angel Aquino, and Hilda Koronel, and was included in the film’s official soundtrack. The song instantly became a hit and topped the daily charts in the Filipino music channel MYX. In 2012, American Idol Season 7 runner-up David Archuleta made a cover of the track and included it in the expanded edition of his fourth studio album, Forevermore, along with other OPM hits such as “Forevermore” by Side A, “Tell Me” by Joey Albert, and “You Are My Song” by Martin Nievera.

In the 2005 Awit Awards, “Rainbow” won Song of the Year, Best Inspirational/Religious Recording, and Best Performance by a Duo or Group.  Written by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya, with additional notes from Jose S. Buenconsejo

text:
(Memories of Capiz). 1891. Music, Julio Nakpil.

 

This nostalgic piano piece evokes the elegance of the 19th-century upper class. Cast in the well-defined mold of the habanera, this danza filipina or simply danza has a distinct Latin ambiance. After a brief four-measure introduction, the first part in ABBA form is followed by a second section marked trio that provides the CCA portion. As in other rondo forms, the return to the A part is followed by a coda that echoes the introduction. The emphatic danza rhythm spelled out by the left hand and the melodious running melodies in the right hand create the impression of a graceful social dance. The piece became so popular that it had at least six editions after its publication, enhancing the reputation of the already famous Nakpil. The first Exposicion Regional Filipina of 1895 awarded Nakpil a Diploma of Honor for “Recuerdos de Capiz.”  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by Mauricia D. Borromeo

article_title: Recuerdos de Filipinas y Sus Cantares: Gran Potpurri para Piano

photos.desc:
Sheet music cover of “Recuerdos de Filipinas y sus Cantares:

Gran Potpurri para Piano,” 1886 (Jose S. Buenconsejo Collection)

text:
(Memories of the Philippines and its Songs: Grand Medley for Piano). 1886.

Recuerdos… is one of the earliest works of printed music that was most likely published in Manila and the first extant music arrangement utilizing traditional Philippine folk songs and dances. It is a medley arranged by Diego C. Perez, piano teacher of Dolores Paterno at Colegio de Santa Isabel. The medley was a popular genre in the 19th century. Dedicated to Señorita Maxima Alas, the work is a pianistic treatment of 19 traditional Philippine musical and dance genres, including Spanish dances that had been incorporated into Philippine culture of that time: 1) pandangguhan (in the style of fandango); 2) bayuhan (rice pounding rhythm); 3) palimos (beggar’s song); 4) cundiman (acculturated Tagalog folk dance/song); 5) auit (Tagalog song in plosa verse form); 6) cumintang (Tagalog dance-song, variant of auit, also in plosa verse form); 7) virgoire (folk dance); 8) balinta; 9) pasion (chant to the pasyon text); 10) tagulaylay (Tagalog lament); 11) dalit (devotional hymn); 12) zapateado (Spanish dance featuring rhythmic footwork); 13) bantayanun (in the style of music from a fortress or bantayan); 14) jele-jele (lullaby); 15) holona (lullaby); 16) balitaw (Visayan dance song, like cundiman); 17) cabiquingan; 18) paruparuhan (butterfly dance); and 19) talindao (boat-rowing song).

 

The work has survived in two extant copies. The first is preserved at the University of the Philippines Music Library’s Filipiniana Collection and was copied by Antonio J. Molina. This copy bears his note, stating that the work could not have been composed in 1750. The second of the two extant copies is a print in the Biblioteca Nacional de España (BNE) which is dated 1900. Music historian Raymundo Bañas, however, has dated the work to 1886 (Bañas 1970, 39). This is a more probable date as the piece was reportedly exhibited in the 1887 Exposicion General de las Islas Filipinas in Madrid which explains why BNE has a copy of the print.

The printed version has an expensive chromolithographic cover page. Diego C. Perez had to sell his music at the steep price of eight reales (dollars), the equivalent of one night of work for an orchestral musician in the 1880s. This version does not contain publication details and the print probably had a limited circulation.

A copy reached the library of eminent American band composer and conductor John Philip Sousa who reprinted a simpler version of the medley, this time deleting the name of the arranger in his music anthology titled National, Patriotic, Typical Airs of All Lands, published in 1890. The piece was also exhibited in the 1904 St Louis Exposition, where it garnered a prize.

Ramon Gonzales Fernandez in his Anuario Filipino para 1877 (1877, 249-250) listed Diego C. Perez as a compositor de piano (piano repairer). According to writer Alfredo Roa (Roa 1927, Vol. III, 457), Diego Perez was a piano teacher who was a generation older than Pedro Castañeda of Santa Cruz, who tutored the Filipina zarzuela star Praxedes Fernandez de Pastor (La Yeyeng) (ibid, 456).

The piece is remarkable for two reasons. First, Diego Perez included music and dance genres that were no longer heard in the 20th century such as the balinta and the talindao. Second, this piano medley is a valuable reference to traditional Philippine music of the late 19th century. Diego Perez’s treatment of the three Tagalog song genres in a sequence—cundiman, auit, and comintang—displays his familiarity with these types.  Written by Jose S. Buenconsejo

Sources

 

BanÌƒas, Raymundo C. (1969) 1975. Pilipino Music and Theater. Quezon City: Manlapaz Publishing Co.

Buenconsejo, Jose S. 2011. “Adapting to the Western Ideology of Music Composition in the Last Half of 19th Century Manila.” Paper read in the meeting of the Association of Asian Studies in Honolulu, Hawaii, 3 Apr.

Gonzales Fernandez, Ramon. 1877. “Anuario Filipino para 1977.” In Manual del Viajero Filipinas, Vol 2. Manila: Establecimiento Tipografico de Plana y Cia.

Roa, Alfredo. (1927) 1986. “De Nuestra Musica y Nuestros Musicos.” In Dictionary of Philippine Biography, edited by E.A. Manuel, Vol 3. Quezon City: Philippineasian Society, originally published in La Opinion, Suplemento Sabatino.

text:
1989. Music, Lucio D. San Pedro. Lyrics, Fred Tiburcio.

The Redeemer, an oratorio in three parts for solo voices, chorus, and orchestra, was commissioned by the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP). After the biblical text was finished by Fred Tiburcio, San Pedro started this work in Aug 1989 and finished it in Jun 1990. The writing of an oratorio had long been a dream of the composer, who had previously composed religious and sacred works for both church and secular choral groups.

 

The oratorio is written in the romantic style. However, it veers away from the technical treatment used by many classical and romantic Western composers. It is lyrical, totally avoiding virtuosity in solo and choral parts. The composer relies on imaginative tone painting to advance the narrative, avoiding predictable cadence patterns. It is divided into three parts depicting the life and passion of the Lord Jesus Christ from birth to crucifixion.

It is dedicated to then CCP President, Ma. Teresa Escoda, to whom San Pedro expressed his deep appreciation for the commission. The CCP and the National Commission for Culture and the Arts (NCCA) jointly sponsored the premiere performance at the CCP Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo on 26 Oct 1990. The soloists were Josephine Roces (soprano), Janet Sabas-Aracama (alto), Leodigario del Rosario (tenor), and Elmo Makil (baritone). Regalado Jose conducted the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, with a composite choir made up of the Ateneo Glee Club and the UP Singing Ambassadors directed by their respective conductors, Joel Navarro and Edgardo Manguiat.

Its second performance in December of the same year at the Santa Isabel College featured the Santa Isabel College Choir with the composer conducting and Raul Navarro at the piano. Two of its outstanding choruses, “For God so Loved the World” and “Let All the Angels” were sung at the CCP during San Pedro’s proclamation as National Artist for Music in Music on 9 May 1991. On 4 Dec 1991, the choruses of the oratorio’s Christmas portion was presented in the joint concert of the De La Salle University (DLSU) Faculty Staff Chorale and the Pasig Concert Choir conducted by Antonio C. Hila at the DLSU Main Chapel with the composer as the guest of honor.

In honor of the composer’s birth centenary, the combined choirs of Coro Pasigueño and Faith Gospel Singers, conducted by Antonio C. Hila, performed the entire Christmas portion (Part 1) of the work with the following soloists: Marga Roco (soprano), Janet Sabas-Aracama (alto), Eugene de los Santos (tenor), and Jerome Sibulo (baritone). At the piano was Naomi Paz Sison, director of Faith Gospel Singers. The concert was sponsored by the Pasig City Employees Multi-Purpose Cooperative and the NCCA.  Written by Antonio C. Hila

text:
1973. Music, Alfredo S. Buenaventura.

The composition portrays an old man dying peacefully, recalling his happy childhood, adventures, struggles, love, and romance. It is divided into three movements: “Death” (moderato non troppo quasi misterioso), “Childhood” (un poco allegretto), and “Love and Romance” (andante amoroso). The section “Death” returns at the end to complete the work.

 

The instrumental combination is somewhat unorthodox: a mixture of both Western and Asian instruments, such as the flute, viola, contrabass, bandurria, guitar, marimba, xylophone, other percussion instruments, and a mezzo-soprano. The resources of the composition are two modal scales—the Phrygian and the Lydian—a “synthetic scale,” a term given by the composer.  Written by Flerida G. Nolasco

text:
1977. Music, Ruben R. Federizon. First performed by the Philippine Music Ensemble of the Philippine Women’s University on 15 Jun 1977 at the Cultural Center of the Philippines.

The composition was written for a combination of Western and Philippine percussion instruments. The ensemble includes two pianos, two glockenspiels, a xylophone, a triangle, a set of suspended cymbals, a tambourine, a timpani, a whip, a gabbang, two sets of kulintang, a babandil, a bamboo block, a pair of sticks, a dabakan, a woodblock, and a gandingan.

 

The piece consists of two sections with different ostinati. The first section is a fantasia-like treatment of the ostinati with the various instruments playing independent motives. The second section is a more rhythmic treatment of the ostinati. The piece centers around the interplay of the ostinati themes for the different percussion instruments.

Ritmus Tabulare garnered third place in the League of Filipino Composers’ Young Composers Competition in 1977. It has enjoyed many performances both in the country and abroad and is the signature piece of the Philippine Music Ensemble.  Written by Jeanna B. Malabuyoc

The piece consists of two sections with different ostinati. The first section is a fantasia-like treatment of the ostinati with the various instruments playing independent motives. The second section is a more rhythmic treatment of the ostinati. The piece centers around the interplay of the ostinati themes for the different percussion instruments.

Ritmus Tabulare garnered third place in the League of Filipino Composers’ Young Composers Competition in 1977. It has enjoyed many performances both in the country and abroad and is the signature piece of the Philippine Music Ensemble.  Written by Jeanna B. Malabuyoc

photos.desc:
Sheet music cover of “Rosas Pandan”

(UP College of Music Collection)

text:
1938. Music and lyrics, Domingo Lopez; Tagalog lyrics, Levi Celerio. The Tagalog version was popularized by Pilita Corrales in the 1970s.

 

This popular Cebuano song was written by Domingo “Minggoy” Lopez. It is in balitaw style with a fast triple time, spiced up by a syncopated reiterated rhythmic pattern. Its form is binary, with the second part repeated to the same text: ABB.

The song tells of the pretty barrio lass, Rosas Pandan, who brings a song and dance to the fair:

Ani-a si Rosas Pandan

Guikan pa intawon

Sa kabukiran

Ka ninyo makiuban-uban

Sa guisaulog

Nga kalingawan.

(Rosas Pandan is here

She humbly comes

From the country fields

To join you

In the celebration

Of your feast.)

Sounds of the accompanying strumming of a guitar are imitated vocally with nonsense syllables—i.e., tig-a-ding-tig-a-ding-tig-a-ding. This imitative vocalization is highlighted in the arrangement written for a cappella choir by George Hernandez, in which the lower voices mimic the strumming of a guitar. Aside from the numerous Filipino choirs who have performed the song, this arrangement by Hernandez has been rendered by many international vocal groups such as choirs from Canada, Singapore, China, Korea, Russia, Austria, and America. It has also been included in the 2012 recording, The Music of Gyud, emphasizing Cebuano classics from the 20th century.  Written by Corazon C. Dioquino, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

photos.desc:
Sheet music cover of “Sa Kabukiran,” 1939

(Atang de la Rama Collection)

text:
(At the Farm). Circa 1939. New and revised edition copyrighted in 1941 and in 1961. Music, Manuel Velez; lyrics, Juan Yee Benasa (Tagalog), Jose Galicano (Visayan), Jose H. Gavita (Spanish), Jose Climaco (English), F. Zaragosa (Ilonggo), and Leon Pichay (Ilocano). Transcribed by Hilarion Rubio for orchestra with laud and bandurria. Transcribed for orchestra by Redentor L. Romero who conducted and recorded his transcription with the London Philharmonic Orchestra. His other transcription of the same work for violin and piano accompaniment is a significant piece in the Filipino violin repertoire. The transcription by Antonio Maigue and Lester Demetillo consists of flute solo and guitar. They also arranged the same for voice, flute, and guitar.

 

Velez, a prolific prewar composer of popular and movie music, paints a delightful musical picture of life on the farm. The song is written in the key of D and classified as a balitaw in tempo allegretto with a 3/4 beat that undergirds a gay, nimble, and carefree melodic setting for the text:

Sa kabukiran, walang kalungkutan,

Lahat ng araw ay kaligayahan.

Ang halamanan,

Kung aking masdan,

Masiglang lahat ang kanyang kulay,

Ang mga ibong nag-aawitan,

Kawili-wili silang pakinggan.

(On the farm, there is no sadness

All the days are full of happiness

The garden,

As I look at it,

Is alive with color,

The singing birds

Are so delightful.)

Intended for a coloratura soprano, a fermata before the final measure signals the start of a brilliant cadenza displaying the performer’s vocal artistry. It has made many a singing star: Lilian Velez in Filippine Films Production’s Sa Kabukiran, Elsa Oria in Sampaguita Pictures’ Bituing Marikit (Beautiful Star), and Nora Hermosa in Vista Films’ Ang Siloy.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by Mauricia D. Borromeo

text:
(To My Beloved Country). 1950. Music, Lucio D. San Pedro; lyrics, Guillermo Santiago Y. Cuino. First performed by Gloria Vinculado on 8 Oct 1950 at the Far Eastern University Auditorium, accompanied by the Filipino Youth Symphony Orchestra with Luis Valencia conducting.

The song follows the pattern ABCD with a repeat of the second part written in the balitaw tempo. The first five notes of the Philippine National Anthem are used in the coda. Solemn and melodious, it is a classic and all-time favorite of both amateur and professional choral groups. Like other compositions of San Pedro, this song is intensely patriotic:

 

Sa himlayang limot ay aking pinupukaw

Ang gintong alamat ng nagdaang araw

Ngayong malaya ka na sa Dulong Silangan

Lalo pang tumatamis wika mo at kundiman.

(From a forgotten grave, I try to resurrect

The golden legend of bygone days

Now that you are free in the far east

Your language and kundiman are sweeter than ever.)

San Pedro arranged the piece for both female and mixed choir in 1975. The mixed-choir version was popularized by the University of the Philippines (UP) Concert Chorus.  Written by Antonio C. Hila

photos.desc:
Scene from Sakada, 1976, which used “Sa Ugoy ng Duyan” as theme song

(Nicanor G. Tiongson Collection)

text:
(As the Cradle Rocks). Music, 1943, Lucio D. San Pedro; lyrics, 1948, Levi Celerio.

San Pedro had intended to submit the song to a government-sponsored contest during the Japanese Occupation but could not find a lyricist. In 1948, on the ship bringing him home after a year of composition studies at Juilliard School of Music in New York, he met Levi Celerio. San Pedro played the piece for Celerio, explaining that it was a lullaby dedicated to his mother. Celerio quickly wrote the lyrics.

 

Celerio’s lyrics for the song fit the melody so well, that both seem to have been conceived together:

Sana’y di magmaliw ang dati kong araw

Nang munti pang bata sa piling ni nanay

Nais ko’y maulit ang awit ni inang mahal

Awit ng pag-ibig, habang ako’y nasa duyan.

Sa aking pagtulog na labis ang himbing

Ang bantay ko’y tala, ang tanod ko’y bituin

Sa piling ni nanay, langit ang buhay

Puso kong may dusa’y sabik sa ugoy ng duyan.

(I wish that my days had not faded away

When I was still a baby in my mother’s cradle

I want to hear again my loving mother’s song

A song of love that lulled me in the cradle.

In my slumber exceedingly deep

The star guided me and watched over me

With my mother, life was paradise

My anguished heart longs for the rocking cradle.)

In two parts, the song is based on the melody that San Pedro’s mother used to hum to put her children to bed. The song became the core of the five-part Suite Pastorale, 1956, describing the life and romance of his hometown, Angono, Rizal. “Sa Ugoy ng Duyan” forms the third movement of the composition.

It was used as the theme song of the 1976 movie Sakada (Seasonal Cane Worker) which was directed by Behn Cervantes. A choral transcription made in the 1960s was popularized by the University of the Philippines (UP) Madrigal Singers and the UP Concert Chorus. A version for children penned by the composer in 1978 was dedicated to the UP Cherubim and Seraphim and remains a part of their concert repertoire. It was arranged for orchestra and recorded by the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra in Pintig (Beat). It has been sung by academically trained as well as popular singers. When San Pedro was conferred the National Artist award in 1991, “Sa Ugoy ng Duyan” was choreographed by Denisa Reyes for Ballet Philippines.

It was given a fresh arrangement by Tots Tolentino for Chin Chin Gutierrez’s album Uyayi: A Collection of Philippine Lullabies, released in 2003. It was also part of the awardwinning 2004 album of the San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra (SMPO) under the direction of Ryan Cayabyab. The album is titled Great Filipino Love Songs, with the vocal parts interpreted by Basil Valdez.  Written by Antonio C. Hila, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

<v:shape id="_x0000_s1026" o:allowincell="f" style="position:absolute; margin-left:0; margin-top:0; width:8.3pt; height:8.25pt; z-index:251806720" type="#_x0000_t202"> <v:textbox> </v:textbox></v:shape>

text:
(Wherever You Are). 1968. Music, Restie Umali and Levi Celerio; lyrics, Levi Celerio.

Umali’s sentimental melody tugs at the heartstrings while expressing an ardent declaration of eternal love:

 

Saan ka man naroroon sinta

Pag-ibig kong wagas ang ’yong madarama

Kailan pa man sa iyo’y di lilimot

Pusong uhaw sa iyong pag-irog.

Saan ka man naroroon sinta

Pangarap ko’y ikaw pagka’t mahal kita

Asahan mong sa habang panahon

Alaala kita saan ka man naroroon.

(Wherever you are my beloved

You will only feel my pure love

You will never be forgotten

By a heart that longs for your affection.

Wherever you are my beloved

I dream of you because I love you

Rest assured that in the long run

I will remember you wherever you are.)

“Saan Ka Man Naroroon” was used as the theme song of Larry Santiago’s 1968 film of the same title, which starred Lolita Rodriguez, Marlene Dauden, and Eddie Rodriguez. It also became the title and theme song of a 1993 movie directed by Carlos Siguion-Reyna and starring Richard Gomez and Dawn Zulueta, and a television soap opera produced by ABS-CBN in 1999 starring Claudine Barretto and Rico Yan. It was recorded by Pilita Corrales for the long-playing album, Araw-Araw, Gabi-Gabi (Day by Day, Night by Night) produced by Vicor Records, and is also one of the choice cuts in another Corrales album, Theme from Filipino Movies.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes

text:
(Wishing It Would Never End). 1986. Music and lyrics, Willy Cruz. First sung by Sharon Cuneta in the movie of the same title produced by Viva Films in the same year. Best Movie Theme Song, Filipino Academy of Movie Arts and Sciences (FAMAS), Film Academy of the Philippines (FAP), and Star Awards for Movies.

Considered by many as Willy Cruz’s best composition, this song achieved the status of a classic after its release in 1986. Set in moderate duple time, this song shows close unity between music and lyrics.

 

The song’s text concretizes the theme of uncompromising and absolute love, in images that are fresh and riveting:

Kahit na ilang tinik

Ay kaya kong tapakan

Kung ‘yan ang paraan

Upang landas mo’y masundan

Kahit ilang ulit

Ako’y iyong saktan

Hindi kita maaaring iwanan.

(It doesn’t matter how many thorns

I have to step on

If that is the only way

To follow your path

It doesn’t matter

How many times you hurt me

I could never leave you.)

The song was performed countless times by pop singers and choral groups alike. The Philippine Madrigal Singers have included this song in their regular repertoire. An arrangement for piano and orchestra by Cruz was premiered by the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra and Sharon Cuneta during the 1992 concert Willy Cruz and his Music held at the Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo of the Cultural Center of the Philippines. Jun Polistico’s version, also arranged by Cruz, is a notable revival of the song recorded for Viva Records in 1991. “Sana’y Wala Nang Wakas” also became the title and theme song of a primetime soap opera produced by ABS-CBN in 2003 starring Jericho Rosales and Kristine Hermosa.  Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian

photos.desc:
Sangdugong Panaguinip flyer, 1902

(Filipinas Heritage Library)

text:
(Dreamed Alliance). 1902. One-act opera in Tagalog composed by Ladislao S. Bonus.

 

The original Spanish libretto, titled La Alianza Soñada, was written by Pedro A. Paterno and was later translated into Tagalog by Roman G. Reyes with the title, Sangdugong Panaguinip. The opera was first translated into English by Arthur W. Fergusson, then Executive Secretary to Civil Governor William H. Taft. Another translation of the libretto in English by Col Walter H. Loving of the Philippine Constabulary Band was later published by the Imprenta de R. Mercantil de J. Loyzaga (Santiago 2009, 79). It was premiered on 2 Aug 1902 with the Orquesta Molina conducted by Ladislao Bonus assisted by Alejo Carluen at the Teatro Zorrilla to a full-house, with 1,500 seats sold in advance. Among the celebrated local singers who performed the principal roles were Juana Molina, Julian Benito, and Patricio Loyola. The opera ran for at least eight performances at the Teatro Zorrilla.

Sangdugong Panaguinip expresses a strong pro-American sentiment as it was written to legitimize America’s intrusive presence in the country. According to Rivera, the work was “regarded as a propaganda opera advocating American rule in the archipelago” (Rivera 2009, 89). At the inaugural performance, the theater was draped with numerous American flags, and it was attended by a number of high American civil officials, among whom were Taft, Fergusson, and Loving.

A short synopsis written by Raymundo Bañas (1969, 202-3) reads:

A band of Muslims invades Luzon and imposes taxes or tribute on every maiden in the towns of Pasig, Cainta and Antipolo, Rizal. Led by Lapu, the inhabitants of these towns were unified by way of a blood compact so as to repel the invaders. One night while pondering his plan to conquer the Muslims, Lapu fell asleep in a cave known as the cave of Doña Geronima. He dreamt of having seen a rainbow with rays leading to paradise and illuminated by a constellation of American stars. Lapu saw an American-Pilipino alliance, which under Bathala’s guidance could lead to prosperity and happiness of his people.

The play is an allegory using characters as symbols of political and social forces working in the Philippines to cement the relationship between the United States and the Philippines, described in the libretto as follows:

In the first scene, while Lapu is asleep, the orchestra plays the Spanish March while a woman representing Spain appears on the scene, embraces the Filipino woman and points out the road to progress... The “Star-Spangled Banner” is played afterwards as the scene changes and the Statue of Liberty looms in the background. What seemed at first to be a comet grows into a group of stars forming the Filipino flag. The orchestra then plays the Philippine national anthem to conclude the play, the Filipinos embracing the Statue of Liberty representing the United States (Fernandez and Tiongson 1994, 235).

The music of Sangdugong Panaguinip was written for orchestra and various vocal parts. There are nine vocal solo parts: one tiple, one tiple soprano, one primer baritono, two tenores, two tenor partiquino (small parts), one segundo baritono, and a bajo. There is also a chorus that plays an important role in the unfolding of the narrative. Among the orchestral instruments specified in the reduced score for piano were cornetos (horns), cornetinos (small trumpet), fagot (bassoon), bombo platillo (bass drum), trompetas (trumpets), and caja vivo (small drum) (Rivera 2009, 98). The arias and choruses are predominantly set in dance rhythms such as the balitaw, danza, and marcha, and they are mostly through-composed following the poetic flow of the verses (Rivera 2009, 99-100).

The musical score is divided into five scenes, introduced by a sinfonia (orchestral overture) in four distinct sections with differing tempi, key signatures, and character. Remarkable in the first scene is the superimposition of the “Star-Spangled Banner” on the “Marcha Nacional Filipina” in the dream sequence. The presence of the melody of the familiar “La Flor de Manila” (The Flower of Manila) in the fourth scene is also notable. The opera ends with a return of the two superimposed anthems where the American anthem is played by the orchestra while the Philippine anthem serves as an obbligato played by a corneto obligato.

Sangdugong Panaguinip is considered the first Tagalog and Philippine opera and a work that legitimized and strengthened the uneasy political relationship between the Filipino upper class and the conquering American forces.  Written by Arwin Q. Tan

Sources

 

BanÌƒas, Raymundo C. 1924. The Music and Theater of the Filipino People. Manila: Oriental Printing.

———. (1969) 1975. Pilipino Music and Theater. Quezon City: Manlapaz Publishing Co.

Fernandez, Doreen G., and Nicanor G. Tiongson. 1994. “Sangdugong Panaguinip.” In CCP Encyclopedia of Philippine Art, vol. 6. Manila: Cultural Center of the Philippines.

Rivera Mirano, Elena, ed. 2009. “The Case of Marcelo Adonay, Musician.” In The Life and Works of Marcelo Adonay, 5-52. Quezon City: University of the Philippines Press.

Santiago, Fernando A., Jr. 2009. “Remembering Ladislao Bonus (1854-1908): The Father of Filipino Opera.” Selected Papers of the 18th Annual Manila Studies Conference, 23-24 Aug, 64-88.

At the inaugural performance, the theater was draped with numerous American flags, and it was attended by a number of high American civil officials, among whom were Taft, Fergusson, and Loving.
A short synopsis written by Raymundo Bañas (1969, 202-3) reads:

A band of Muslims invades Luzon and imposes taxes or tribute on every maiden in the towns of Pasig, Cainta and Antipolo, Rizal. Led by Lapu, the inhabitants of these towns were unified by way of a blood compact so as to repel the invaders. One night while pondering his plan to conquer the Muslims, Lapu fell asleep in a cave known as the cave of Doña Geronima. He dreamt of having seen a rainbow with rays leading to paradise and illuminated by a constellation of American stars. Lapu saw an American-Pilipino alliance, which under Bathala’s guidance could lead to prosperity and happiness of his people.

The play is an allegory using characters as symbols of political and social forces working in the Philippines to cement the relationship between the United States and the Philippines, described in the libretto as follows:

In the first scene, while Lapu is asleep, the orchestra plays the Spanish March while a woman representing Spain appears on the scene, embraces the Filipino woman and points out the road to progress... The “Star-Spangled Banner” is played afterwards as the scene changes and the Statue of Liberty looms in the background. What seemed at first to be a comet grows into a group of stars forming the Filipino flag. The orchestra then plays the Philippine national anthem to conclude the play, the Filipinos embracing the Statue of Liberty representing the United States (Fernandez and Tiongson 1994, 235).

The music of Sangdugong Panaguinip was written for orchestra and various vocal parts. There are nine vocal solo parts: one tiple, one tiple soprano, one primer baritono, two tenores, two tenor partiquino (small parts), one segundo baritono, and a bajo. There is also a chorus that plays an important role in the unfolding of the narrative. Among the orchestral instruments specified in the reduced score for piano were cornetos (horns), cornetinos (small trumpet), fagot (bassoon), bombo platillo (bass drum), trompetas (trumpets), and caja vivo (small drum) (Rivera 2009, 98). The arias and choruses are predominantly set in dance rhythms such as the balitaw, danza, and marcha, and they are mostly through-composed following the poetic flow of the verses (Rivera 2009, 99-100).

The musical score is divided into five scenes, introduced by a sinfonia (orchestral overture) in four distinct sections with differing tempi, key signatures, and character. Remarkable in the first scene is the superimposition of the “Star-Spangled Banner” on the “Marcha Nacional Filipina” in the dream sequence. The presence of the melody of the familiar “La Flor de Manila” (The Flower of Manila) in the fourth scene is also notable. The opera ends with a return of the two superimposed anthems where the American anthem is played by the orchestra while the Philippine anthem serves as an obbligato played by a corneto obligato.

Sangdugong Panaguinip is considered the first Tagalog and Philippine opera and a work that legitimized and strengthened the uneasy political relationship between the Filipino upper class and the conquering American forces.  Written by Arwin Q. Tan

Movie poster of Sapagkat Kami’y Tao Lamang, 1963

(Photo courtesy of Simon Santos/Video 48)

text:
(For We Are Only Human). 1963. Music, Antonio Maiquez; lyrics, Levi Celerio. First performed by Ric Manrique Jr. Also recorded by Pilita Corrales in Philippine Love Songs, 1972.

 

This two-stanza through-composed song is written in the key of C. It is a danza mayor in tempo moderato. The text rationalizes human foibles and failures. In particular, the song is the confession of a person who cannot resist a forbidden love:

Kahit Diyos na ang siyang may utos

Dahil sa pagsinta,

damdamin din

ang siyang nasusunod

(Although God forbids it

It’s all because of love

That my feelings

Still prevail.)

The composer and lyricist were initially criticized by conservatives who claimed that it is not proper to celebrate illicit relationships with the excuse that “we are only human,” since human beings may choose to fight temptation and uphold morality. The song’s popularity was not affected by these attacks, however, and the work has become a classic. The melody was used in the movie Batas ng Langit (Heaven’s Law), and sung with different lyrics by Ruben Tagalog. Later in 1963, it became the theme song and title of a Virgo Productions movie starring Eddie Rodriguez and Marlene Dauden.

Alfredo S. Buenaventura arranged the song for two voices in 50 Immortal Filipino Duets, 1992, published by the National Philharmonic Society of the Philippines. Various transcriptions for the orchestra have been written in a span of three decades. In 1996, Redentor Romero’s arrangement for the Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra was performed and recorded in Moscow, Russia. The song is included in his CD album Damdaming Pinoy (Filipino Feelings). Ryan Cayabyab also arranged the song for the San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra (SMPO). The song, performed by Basil Valdez accompanied by the SMPO, is included in their CD album The Filipino Classics, 2006. Cayabyab arranged another orchestral transcription for the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO), performed in a concert titled Serenata (Serenade), on 4 Sep 2015, at the CCP Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo. The song performed by the PPO is included in the CD Serenata: Well-Loved Philippine Folk Songs and Melodies.  Written by Michael M. Coroza, updated by James C. Diaz

photos.desc:
Vinyl record cover of Celeste Legaspi’s Ako at Si Celeste, 1977,

which includes “Saranggola ni Pepe” (Blackgold Records)

text:
(Pepe’s Kite). 1978. Music and lyrics, Nonoy Gallardo. First sung by Celeste Legaspi who also recorded the song for Blackgold Records in the same year.

 

The song’s text is replete with images that speak of ordinary Filipinos, as embodied by Pepe, and their elusive dream of a simple, good life, as symbolized by the kite in constant flight. These are also images of people who are continuously swept away and ravaged by the winds of change. A stanza of the song goes:

Matayog ang lipad ng saranggola ni Pepe

Matayog ang pangarap ng matandang bingi

Umihip ang hangin, nawala sa paningin

Sigaw ng kahapon, nilamon na ng alon

Malayo ang tunog ng kampanilya ni Padre

Maingay ang taginting, rosaryo ng babae.

(Pepe’s kite is soaring high

The deaf man’s dreams are also soaring high

The wind blew it out of sight

Yesterday’s cry has been swallowed by the waves

The priest’s bells can be heard from afar

The jingling of the woman’s rosary is noisy.)

Recorded during a time when overt political statement was forbidden and could be expressed only in ambiguous and symbolic language, the lyrics provide an elusive and allegorical quality, and prove that successful ballads need not be associated with mushy romantic love. With only a ukelele as accompaniment and Legaspi’s freewheeling delivery, Gallardo uses the simple melody to make a critical social statement.

Ryan Cayabyab has written two arrangements for the song: one, for two pianos and the other, for the orchestra. Pianists Della Besa and Anna Maria de Guzman performed Cayabyab’s arrangement for two pianos at their duo concert titled Diwa (Consciousness) at the Tanghalang Aurelio Tolentino of the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) on 31 Mar 2009. On 4 Sep 2015, the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra, under the baton of the arranger, performed the song at their concert titled Serenata (Serenade), in celebration of CCP’s 46th anniversary, at the CCP Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo. The song is also included in their CD album Serenata: Well-Loved Philippine Folk Songs and Melodies.  Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian, updated by James C. Diaz

photos.desc:
Scene from Sarung Banggi, 1947

(Photo courtesy of Simon Santos/Video 48)

text:
(One Night). Circa 1900. Music and lyrics, Potenciano V. Gregorio Sr.

An immensely popular song with folk song stature, it is in moderate tempo. It has three distinct sections: A, B, and C. Parts A and B are in the minor key, while part C modulates to the parallel major mode. The text contains four 4-line stanzas. The structure of each part is simple, containing two periods. Each period begins with the same antecedent phrase but with the consequent phrase for the second period ending differently. The original Bikol text runs:

 

Sarung banggi sa higdaan

Nakadangog ako nin huni nin sarung gamgam

Geroba ako katurugan

Bako kundi simong bases iyo palan.

Dagos ako bangon si sakuyang mata iminuklat

Kaidtong kadikluman ako nangalagkalag

Si sikuyang mata panghiling pasiring sa itaas

Simong pandok nahiling ko maliwanag.

(One night while in bed

I heard a bird chirping

I thought it was a dream

I was wrong; it was your voice.

I woke up and promptly got up

I sensed my way in the darkness

I looked up

And saw your face shimmering.)

Tagalog and English lyrics have been created for the song. Numerous composers—notably Constancio de Guzman (Tagalog lyrics), Felipe Padilla de Leon, and Eliseo M. Pajaro—have arranged the song for solo voice with piano accompaniment. Alfredo S. Buenaventura arranged it for rondalla, while Rosendo Santos made a four-hand adaptation for piano. The song has been arranged for chorus by Lucio D. San Pedro and others, and is in the repertoire of many singing groups. Francisco Buencamino used it as a theme for his Mayon Concerto.

Gilopez Kabayao transcribed the song for violin and piano in 1974, and performed it with Corazon Kabayao at the piano, in their concert tours abroad. The song which was originally recorded in 1974 is included in their CD album Gilopez Kabayao Plays Philippine Folk Songs, 2000. Ramon Acoymo and Lisa Florentino performed the song for their CD album Immortal Philippine Songs, 1997. Lucio D. San Pedro has an arrangement of the song for soprano and tenor in 50 Immortal Filipino Duets, published by the National Philharmonic Society of the Philippines in 1992. The song has also been arranged for solo piano by Augusto Espino in Guhit Tugtugin at Seleksyon (Piano Sketches and Selections), 2000, a collection of pedagogical arrangements for piano based on Filipino folk songs. It is also one of the songs in the CD album Guhit Tugtugin at Seleksiyon, 2002 performed by Nita Abrogar Quinto.

In 4 Sep 2015, “Sarung Banggi” was performed by the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO) in a concert titled Serenata (Serenade) at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo. The concert, which was done in celebration of CCP’s 46th anniversary, featured Filipino folk songs with musical arrangements by Ryan Cayabyab. In the same event, Ballet Philippines also performed the song, choreographed by Paul Alexander Morales. The song performed by the PPO is included in the special collector’s CD Serenata: Well-Loved Philippine Folk Songs and Melodies.

The song inspired a 1947 movie of the same title produced by LVN Pictures and starring Mila del Sol and Rogelio de la Rosa. The theme was also used in Pangako ng Kahapon (Promise of Yesterday), 1994, starring Alice Dixson, Agot Isidro, and Donna Cruz, produced by Viva Films. In 2005, an independent film by Emmanuel de la Cruz used the song as title and theme of his Cinemalaya Independent Film Festival entry, Sarong Banggi, starring Jaclyn Jose.  Written by Corazon C. Dioquino, updated by James C. Diaz

article_title: Si Nanay, Si Tatay Di Co Babayaan
text:
(I Will Never Neglect My Mother, My Father). Bikol folk song.

Like most kundiman, this traditional Bicol folk song is cast in a minor key. In slow 3/4 time, it is made up of four phrases comprising two periods. Each phrase begins with identical rhythmic motifs sung on a repeated note.

 

The song deals with parent-child relationships. It praises parents, promising them the child’s eternal gratitude and service:

Si Nanay, si Tatay di co babayaan

Balakid na boot ang sa coyang utang

Si pagdara sa co ning siam na bulan

Gatas na dinodo, di co mabayadan.

(I will never neglect my Mother, my Father

I am greatly indebted to them

For they bore me for nine months

I can never repay the milk that nursed me.)

Lucrecia R. Kasilag used the song in her Five Philippine Folk Songs, 1956, which featured only minor alterations in the melody but ornamentation with pedal points, ostinato, and added seconds. A choral arrangement by Verne de la Peña has been sung by the Philippine Madrigal Singers and is included in their collection, Mga Awiting Bayan (Folk Songs), published in 1994. A version for children’s choir by Fabian Obispo was commissioned by the UP Cherubim and Seraphim and is included in their concert repertoire.  Written by Corazon C. Dioquino, updated by Arwin Q. Tan

text:
(Pilemon, Pilemon). Also known as “Si Felimon.” Traditional Visayan song.

This traditional Visayan fishing song is also sung in Luzon and Mindanao, mostly by children. It was collected by Priscilla V. Magdamo-Abraham and published in her multivolume work Folk Songs of the Visayas, 1957, and arranged by her for the album Philippine Folk Music (Songs of the Visayas), performed by the Silliman University Folk Arts Ensemble.

The text consists of 8 lines, the first 6 of which have an 8-syllable pattern. Lines 1, 3, and 5 are divided in two with a repeated four-syllable phrase; while lines 2, 4, and 6 have a smoother and more uninterrupted single phrase. The seventh line has 14 syllables, divided into two repeating seven-syllable phrases that break the pattern of the first six phrases. The final line is in seven syllables. The fits and starts created by this change in rhythmic pattern contribute to the overall comic effect of this jaunty song in duple time. Its simple images and words make it easy and amusing for children to sing.

 

The comical lyrics tell of the exploits of a fisherman named Pilemon who sets out to sea, catches a small fish called tambasakan (mudskipper), and sells it in a dilapidated market:

Si Pilemon, si Pilemon

Namasol sa karagatan

Nakakuha, nakakuha

Ng isdang tambasakan

Guibaligya, guibaligya

sa mercadong guba.

(Pilemon, Pilemon

Went fishing

He caught, he caught

A fish called tambasakan

He sold it, he sold it

In a dilapidated market.)

The humor is contained in the last three lines, which tells of the sale:

Ang halin puros kura,

ang halin puros kura

Igo ra ipanuba.

(The sale was so small,

the sale was so small

It could only buy coconut wine.)

The song serves as entertainment to fisherfolk and they sing it during their nightly ventures into the sea.

This song became even more popular due to the singing style of the the king of novelty songs Yoyoy Villame, who included it in his album Da Da Da (Tsismis) [Da Da Da (Gossip)], 1982, to an arrangement by Boy Palacio. Arrangements, recordings, and performances include a classical guitar piece by Jeffrey Malazo and Jude Ralph Roldan’s SAB (soprano-alto-bass) arrangement for children’s choir which was commissioned and performed by a Singaporean choir in 2004. It was a part of the work Cebuano Medley arranged by Eudenice Palaruan’s for the Philippine Madrigal Singers and conducted by choirmaster Mark Carpio in Alhambra, California in 2007. The Asian Troubadours also had a rendition for a seven-piece ensemble in 2009. An arrangement of the song by Emmanuel de Leon was performed by the University of the East Chorale and conducted by Anna Abeleda in 2013. Finally, an arrangement for symphony orchestra by Ryan Cayabyab was included in the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra album, Serenata: Well-Loved Philippine Folk Songs and Melodies, 2015.  Written by Rene B. Javellana, updated by Crisancti L. Macazo

Sources

 

Magdamo, Priscilla V. 1956. “Folk and Traditional Music of the Visayas and Mindanao.” Tape recordings with field notes.

———. 1957-1958. Folk Songs of the Visayas, Vols 1-6. Dumaguete City: Silliman Music Foundation Inc.

Roldan, Jude Ralph (pianist and rehearsal conductor of Hail Mary the Queen Children’s Choir). 2015. Correspondence with Crisancti Macazo, 25 Sep.

Serenata: Well-Loved Philippine Folk Songs and Melodies. 2015. CD album. Manila: Cultural Center of the Philippines.

Serenata: Well-Loved Philippine Folk Songs and Melodies. 2015. CD album. Manila: Cultural Center of the Philippines.

photos.desc: Ballet Philippines’ performance of Siklo, 1977 (Salvador Bernal Collection)

text:
(Cycle). 1977. Music, Ramon P. Santos. Commissioned by the CCP Dance Company (now Ballet Philippines) in cooperation with the League of Filipino Composers. First performed by Imelda C. Ongsiako and the Philippine PhilharmonicOrchestra with Ramon P. Santos conducting.

 

The work depicts the simple cycle of life and death of biological forms which, although infinitesimal, can still be seen by the naked eye. Beginning with primary state of non-existence, the cycle progresses through birth, maturation, deterioration, death, and decomposition. To portray this process, Santos used avant-garde techniques: abstract effects achieved by vocal enunciations, sound blocks and sound masses, and concrete structures (and heartbeats) produced by a synthesizer.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes

text:
(Shine on Me). Circa 1930. Music, Mike Velarde Jr; lyrics, Dominador Santiago.

Movie and music director, Mike Velarde Jr, composed the song for the movie Pasang Krus (Bearing the Cross) produced by Sampaguita Pictures in 1939. “Silayan,” in the graceful style of a danza, promises imperishable love for all the days of one’s life. After the solo verse at the beginning, there follows one of Velarde’s loveliest melodies which is intended for a duet. The music is simple, candid, artistically adroit, and expressive:

 

Silayan at bigyan ng pag-asa

Pagmamahal pusong nagdurusa

Iwasan ang pag-aalinlangan

Lahat ng araw kita’y mamahalin.

(Shine on me and give me hope

Give love to this broken heart

Never doubt

I will love you through all the days.)

The song was popularized by Pilita Corrales in her album The Best of Philippine Music Volume 1, 1974. Asin band vocalist Lolita Carbon arranged the song in 1988 and included it in their album Sinta: Himig Kayumanggi 2 (Love: Brown Melodies). A transcription of Jose Valdez was also among the Filipino songs incorporated in the album The Philippine Guitar: A Book of Traditional Songs for Solo Guitar, 1998. In 2007, Kuh Ledesma sang this song in her album K while the reggae group Brownman Revival had a version of the song and recorded it in their album Ayos Din (It’s Still Good).  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by Crisancti L. Macazo

photos.desc:
Vinyl record cover of MAWPHIL Blind Artists’ Combo’s Pasko Natin, 1978, which includes “Simbanggabi”

(MAWPHIL Records)

text:
(Dawn Mass). 1963. Music, Lucio D. San Pedro. Lyrics, anonymous Jesuit priest.

Composed on 31 Oct 1963 in Angono, Rizal, “Simbanggabi” is dedicated to the Ateneo Glee Club, then an all-male group conducted by Vicente Sales in the early 1960s, which first performed it in its original setting of TTBB (Tenor-Tenor-Baritone-Bass). The present and more familiar version for SATB (Soprano-Alto-Tenor-Bass) choir was published by Manlapaz Publishing in 1975. Below is an excerpt from the song:

 

Ikalabing-anim ng Disyembre

May mga parol nang nakasindi

At ang lamig ay lubhang matindi

Simula na nga ng Simbanggabi.

Simbanggabi simula ng pasko

Sa puso ng lahing Pilipino

Siyam na gabi kaming gumigising

Sa tugtog ng kampanang walang tigil.

Luwalhati sa Diyos at ka’taasan

At sa lupa’y kapayapaan sa mga

taong may mabuting kalooban.

(On the 16th of December

There are already lighted lanterns

And the cold is intense

It really is the start of the dawn mass.

Dawn mass, the start of Christmas

In the heart of the Filipino people

For nine days we rise early in the morning

To the sounds of incessant church bells.

Glory to God in the Highest

And peace on earth to

men of goodwill.)

The closing part in the SATB version is a translation to Tagalog of the original Latin text, “Gloria in excelsis Deo et in terra pax hominibus bonae voluntatis” which is found in the TTBB version.

A popular item in the Filipino Christmas repertoire, “Simbanggabi” is a favorite competition piece at local Christmas choral music competitions because, aside from its harmonic and melodic beauty, it is also a challenging piece to sing. The Filipino-American Symphony Orchestra (FASO) performed the piece with adult choirs in 2009 in a concert titled Handog ng FASO sa Pasko (FASO’s Christmas Offering) under conductor Robert Schroeder.  Written by Raul C. Navarro

photos.desc: Vilma Santos, left, in a scene from Sinasamba Kita, 1982 (Photo courtesy of Viva Films)

text:
(I Adore You). 1982. Music, George Canseco; lyrics, Rey Valera. First sung by Rey Valera.

 

Sinasamba Kita was originally a popular Tagalog komiks novel by Gilda Olvidado which was adapted into a movie by Viva Films in 1982, directed by Eddie Garcia, and starring Vilma Santos, Christopher de Leon, Phillip Salvador, and Lorna Tolentino. The song was originally composed for the movie and outshone the movie for which it was made.

Romantic and traditional, the lyrics of the song are the words of a lover who is in perpetual adoration of his/her beloved and is ready to give up his/her own life for him/her:

Sinasamba kita

Higit sa ’yong akalang

Iniibig lang kita.

Paggalang ko sayo’y

Higit sa buhay kong taglay.

Wala na yatang papantay

Ang buhay ma’y ibibigay ko pa.

Sinasamba kita.

(I adore you

More than you think

That I just love you.

My respect for you

Exceeds the life I possess.

Nothing compares to you

I will give my life for you.

I adore you.)

George Canseco’s melody cast in slow duple time is further enhanced by the lyrics of Rey Valera who is himself a noted songwriter and singer. In 2007, GMA Network used the title and theme song for its afternoon soap directed by Joel Lamangan and starring Sheryl Cruz, Wendell Ramos, Valerie Concepcion, and Carlo Aquino. Singer-songwriter Ogie Alcasid interpreted the song.  Written by Elmer L. Gatchalian

text:
1931. Music, Nicanor S. Abelardo. Written while Abelardo was on a study grant at the Chicago Musical College, this orchestral work was in a “more aggressive idiom” than usual, according to the composer. The experience of studying abroad seems to have been a liberating one as Abelardo wrote barely three weeks after arriving in Chicago: “I have been released at last from the classical bond. I have been sent to wander in the new horizon, taking for guides Hindemith, Schoenberg, Stravinsky, Bartok, and the ultramodern style.”

 

The modern trends exhibited in Sinfonietta are reflected in the use of highly chromatic and atonal effects coupled with unusual metres. Musicologist Corazon Dioquino notes though, that despite the use of dissonant harmonies and tinges of polytonality, the overall idiom and form are “comparatively conservative.” Sinfonietta, she wrote, “easily reminds the listener of older models such as Schoenberg’s Verklaerte Nacht.”

The Sinfonietta was performed by the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra at the Cultural Center of the Philippines Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo with Josefino Toledo conducting, at the concert in honor of Abelardo’s centennial on 12-13 Feb 1993.  Written by Flerida G. Nolasco

photos.desc:
Movie poster of Sitsiritsit Alibangbang, 1967

(Photo courtesy of Simon Santos/Video 48)

text:
Tagalog folk song. This traditional Tagalog folk song is cast in quick duple time. It comprises four stanzas set in AABB form. The text is nonsensical with emphasis on rhyming onomatopoeic syllables. In the first stanza, the text teasingly links the sounds of gossip about a flirtatious woman to the hum of butterflies, green and gold beetles. The second and third stanza threaten disobedient children with the prospect of being sold and exchanged in far-off places for material goods like dolls and food.

 

Sitsiritsit alibangbang

Salaginto salagubang

Ang babae sa lansangan

Kung gumiri parang tandang.

Mama, mama namamangka

Pasakayin yaring bata

Pagdating sa Maynila

Ipagpalit ng manyika

Ale, ale namamayong

Pasukubin yaring sanggol

Pagdating sa Malabon

Ipagpalit ng bagoong.

(Gossipy butterfly

Gold beetle, green beetle

The woman on the street

Struts around like a rooster.

Mister, mister on the boat

Kindly take this child aboard

When you reach Manila

Exchange the child for a doll.

Miss, miss with an umbrella

Will you share it with this baby

When you reach Malabon

Exchange the kid for fermented fish paste.)

The song was incorporated by Bayani M. de Leon in his Bahay Bata (Womb), 1975, where it provided one of the seven rhythmic germs based on folk songs which together constitute a rhythmic cycle that runs throughout the composition. Lucrecia R. Kasilag, in her Five Philippine Folk Songs, 1955, scored the song for women’s voices with piano accompaniment. It was the theme song of the movie Sitsiritsit Alibangbang, 1967.  Written by Corazon C. Dioquino

text:
1956. Music, Lucio D. San Pedro. Commissioned by the Music Promotion Foundation of the Philippines under the auspices of the League of Filipino Composers in 1956. First performed by the Manila Symphony Orchestra and Chorus in August 1956 at the Far Eastern University Auditorium with Antonino Buenaventura conducting. Later popularized by the University of the Philippines Concert Chorus beginning 1966.

 

Consisting of several programmatic movements, Suite Pastorale paints in musical forms the composer’s patriotic sentiments and his vividly poignant reminiscences of his beloved hometown. San Pedro’s perpetual fountain of inspiration is his hometown, Angono, its hardy, peaceful folk, and its teeming fields and bay. Critic Antonio C. Hila writes: “ … examined from a wider perspective, his works are the least parochial, the least regional … Angono is the very representation of the country, the very prism where one sees the total image, the entire picture of the national soul.”

The first movement, titled “Horizon” (“Abot-tanaw”), depicts the glory of creation, the unfolding of a new day as the morning sun rises and illumines the horizon. The cool mist clears to expose nature in all its breathtaking splendor.

The second movement is titled “Meditation” (“Dapit-hapon”). The composer wishes that the intoxicating atmosphere may never end. The prevailing mood is a pensive one as he beholds the fading of the daylight. Soon the sun will shine anew and the air will throb with life. But for now he reclines to let the delights of the evening soothe him.

The third movement, “Lullaby” (“Sa Ugoy ng Duyan”), is perhaps San Pedro’s most famous tune. The wistful and hauntingly beautiful strain paints an image of a young mother lulling her child to sleep. The scene is a tender, intimate one, nostalgic and evocative of sheltered childhood days.

The fourth movement is titled “Under the Ratiles Tree by the Church.” A visit to the church after a hearty breakfast brings to focus a spot in the churchyard where an old ratiles (berry) tree once stood. The composer recalls the comforting presence of the sheltering tree whose widespread branches used to cool whoever sat beneath it.

The fifth movement, “Rustic Dance” (“Pistahan sa Nayon”), is a lively, playful picture of a town fiesta—noisy crowds, boisterous laughter, the fluvial parade—in all its spectacle and splendor.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes

photos.desc: Scene from the music video of Imago’s “Sundo,” 2006 (Universal Records)

text:
(To Get You). 2006. Music and lyrics, Imago. First performed by Imago featuring Aia de Leon on vocals, Myrene Academia on bass guitar, Timothy Cacho on lead guitar, and Zach Lucero on rhythm guitar. The song is included as the third track in the group’s third album titled Blush under Universal Records, released in 2006.

 

The simplicity of the song reflects the innocence of the vocal persona who speaks of her journey to find a lover and bring that lover home. The use of the Tagalog word “suyod”—which means a careful and painstaking search—demonstrates the singer’s thorough effort at finding love. The first stanza goes:

Kay tagal kong sinusuyod ang buong mundo

Para hanapin

Para hanapin ka

Nilibot ang distrito ng iyong lumbay

Pupulutin, pupulutin ka

(For a long time, I’m searching the world

to find,

to find you

I’ve wandered down the district of your grief

I’ll get,

I’ll get you)

The song is built on a simple harmonic progression (chord sequence) in the key of A. It follows the common verse-chorus structure (8-bar verse and eight-bar chorus), with a four-bar transition (“refrain”) in between.

The song’s music video, directed by Marie Jamora, depicts the singer-protagonist’s journey amidst a barren landscape, seemingly alluding to a woman’s arduous search for love. This music video stayed on top of the charts on the music channel MYX for several months after its release. It was subsequently nominated in the Song of the Year category and Video of the Year category in the 2007 NU Rock Awards. It was also nominated in the Favorite Music Video category in the 2008 MYX Music Awards. Blush received a Gold Record award after a special edition CD album was released in 2007. In Dec 2016, Aia De Leon collaborated with Balbie Almalbis and Kitchie Nadal to perform another version of the song in their one-night concert titled Secrets produced by Vandals on the Wall and Gabi na Naman Productions.  Written by Samantha Louise R. Bigcas, with additional notes from Jose S. Buenconsejo
