text:
(Destiny). 2012. Music, Up Dharma Down (now known as UDD); lyrics, Armi Millare. First performed by Up Dharma Down featuring Millare on vocals and keyboards, Carlos Tañada on lead guitars and synthesizers, Ean Mayor on drums and samplers, and Paul Yap on bass and synthesizers. The song is included in UDD’s album Capacities, released in 2012 under Terno Productions.

 

In a low, dreamy tune, vivid imagery, and deep poetic lyrics, “Tadhana” is about the aching, one-sided affection that the persona feels towards someone she loves. The aching is depicted musically in the introduction and first verse by an unsettling, sequence of chords which are syncopated and not in root position, i.e., F#/B-C#-C#/D#-F#/C#-F#B-C#-C#/D#. In the verse leading to the chorus, another chord pattern moves in half note duration, with supporting “walking bass” (B-C#-D#-minor-F#) as if to project the itch of the lover crying for attention. In the chorus, the lover’s plea heightens with the insistent pounding of chords to re-iterate the lover’s plight. This emotion then melts into noise, conveyed by the mixed-up, distorted electronica section that serves as a bridge to the second verse. Though the form of the song is highly structured into “square,” eight-bar phrasings, the “groggy” timbre of the voice of the song’s protagonist suits the character of a lover, probably an urbanite (judging from the diction), whose desire he or she cannot suppress.

In the last verse, a favorite among fans, the persona urges anyone who is in love to express his true feelings:

Ba’t di pa sabihin

Ang hindi mo maamin

Ipauubaya na lang ba ’to sa hangin

’Wag mong ikatakot

Ang bulong ng damdamin mo

Naririto ako’t nakikinig sa’yo.

(Why not say

What you cannot confess

Are you going to leave this to the winds

Do not be afraid

To whisper your feelings

I’m here, listening to you.)

An extended version of the song is usually done by the band in their gigs. The additional verse at the end continues the theme of unrequited sentiment:

Ba’t di salubungin

Ang puso ko at kunin

Ang diwang malaya

’Wag na ’wag magpabaya pa

Ikaw ang pag-ibig

Pakinggan ang himig ko

Wala na sanang lalayo

Mundong ito ay hihinto.

(Why not welcome

My heart and

Liberate the spirit

Do not let things slip anymore

You are my love

Listen to my melody

No one should leave

or this world will stop.)

The combination of poetic Filipino words, easy-to-feel emotion, and melody that differs from the usual powerful ballad made this song a contemporary classic among young listeners.

Even before the album Capacities was released in 2012, “Tadhana” had been used as the opening theme song of GMA Network’s fantasy TV series Ilumina, 2010. The song was not an overnight success due to UDD’s independent status. But in 2014, it became a cult favorite after it was included in the soundtrack of the romantic comedy film That Thing Called Tadhana (That Thing Called Destiny), directed by Antoinette Jadaone and starring Angelica Panganiban and JM de Guzman. That same year, “Tadhana” was launched in Spotify where it was noted as the “most streamed OPM track” in 2015.  Written by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya, with additional notes from Jose S. Buenconsejo

article.value: (Destiny). 2012. Music, Up Dharma Down (now known as UDD); lyrics, Armi Millare. First performed by Up Dharma Down featuring Millare on vocals and keyboards, Carlos Tañada on lead guitars and synthesizers, Ean Mayor on drums and samplers, and Paul Yap on bass and synthesizers. The song is included in UDD’s album Capacities, released in 2012 under Terno Productions.

In a low, dreamy tune, vivid imagery, and deep poetic lyrics, “Tadhana” is about the aching, one-sided affection that the persona feels towards someone she loves. The aching is depicted musically in the introduction and first verse by an unsettling, sequence of chords which are syncopated and not in root position, i.e., F#/B-C#-C#/D#-F#/C#-F#B-C#-C#/D#. In the verse leading to the chorus, another chord pattern moves in half note duration, with supporting “walking bass” (B-C#-D#-minor-F#) as if to project the itch of the lover crying for attention. In the chorus, the lover’s plea heightens with the insistent pounding of chords to re-iterate the lover’s plight. This emotion then melts into noise, conveyed by the mixed-up, distorted electronica section that serves as a bridge to the second verse. Though the form of the song is highly structured into “square,” eight-bar phrasings, the “groggy” timbre of the voice of the song’s protagonist suits the character of a lover, probably an urbanite (judging from the diction), whose desire he or she cannot suppress.
In the last verse, a favorite among fans, the persona urges anyone who is in love to express his true feelings:
Ba’t di pa sabihin
Ang hindi mo maamin
Ipauubaya na lang ba ’to sa hangin
’Wag mong ikatakot
Ang bulong ng damdamin mo
Naririto ako’t nakikinig sa’yo.
(Why not say
What you cannot confess
Are you going to leave this to the winds
Do not be afraid
To whisper your feelings
I’m here, listening to you.)
An extended version of the song is usually done by the band in their gigs. The additional verse at the end continues the theme of unrequited sentiment:
Ba’t di salubungin
Ang puso ko at kunin
Ang diwang malaya
’Wag na ’wag magpabaya pa
Ikaw ang pag-ibig
Pakinggan ang himig ko
Wala na sanang lalayo
Mundong ito ay hihinto.
(Why not welcome
My heart and
Liberate the spirit
Do not let things slip anymore
You are my love
Listen to my melody
No one should leave
or this world will stop.)
The combination of poetic Filipino words, easy-to-feel emotion, and melody that differs from the usual powerful ballad made this song a contemporary classic among young listeners.

Even before the album Capacities was released in 2012, “Tadhana” had been used as the opening theme song of GMA Network’s fantasy TV series Ilumina, 2010. The song was not an overnight success due to UDD’s independent status. But in 2014, it became a cult favorite after it was included in the soundtrack of the romantic comedy film That Thing Called Tadhana (That Thing Called Destiny), directed by Antoinette Jadaone and starring Angelica Panganiban and JM de Guzman. That same year, “Tadhana” was launched in Spotify where it was noted as the “most streamed OPM track” in 2015.  Written by Jhoanne Kristine A. Vinuya, with additional notes from Jose S. Buenconsejo

photos.desc:
Scene from Ang Tangi Kong Pag-ibig, 1955

(Photo courtesy of Simon Santos/Video 48)

text:
(My Only Love). Date of composition unknown. Music and lyrics, Constancio de Guzman. A danza menor in binary form (AB), the song is believed to be a prewar hit by Carmen Rosales which she recorded in 1952. After Rosales, other singers recorded the song, namely: Sylvia La Torre, Cely Bautista, RAR Trio, Leopoldo Silos, and Celeste Legaspi. It was recorded by Xavier Cugat for the Columbia Recording Corporation in English. Cugat himself translated the lyrics. The English version was also recorded by Carina Afable in her Forgive and Forget album. In the 1960s, the song became the theme and title of Dely Magpayo’s radio program over ABS-CBN’s AM radio station, DZXL.

 

The song speaks of a true love unappreciated by the beloved:

Ang tangi kong pag-ibig

Ay minsan lamang

Ngunit iyong akala

Ay hindi tunay.

Hindi ka lilimutin

Magpakailan pa man

Habang ako’y naririto

At may buhay.

(My only love

Happens only once

But you think

It is not for real.

I will not forget you

Ever

While I exist

And breathe.)

Redentor Romero arranged the song for two voices in 50 Immortal Filipino Duets, 1992, published by the National Philharmonic Society of the Philippines. In 1996, he transcribed the song for the orchestra and performed it with the Moscow Philharmonic Orchestra as the conductor. The song is included in his CD album Damdaming Pinoy (Filipino Feelings), recorded in Moscow, Russia.

Ryan Cayabyab also has an orchestral arrangement for the San Miguel Philharmonic Orchestra (SMPO). The song, performed by the SMPO, is included in the CD album Great Filipino Love Songs, released in 2004.  Written by Michael M. Coroza and Antonio C. Hila, updated by James C. Diaz

text:
(Triangle). 1989. Lyrics and music, Rom Dongueto. Performed by bands Buklod and Bamboo. Included in Bamboo’s album We Stand Alone Together which was released in 2007 by EMI Philippines, Inc.

 

Written in the late 1980s as a protest song for the band Buklod, the song was revived by the band Bamboo in 2007. The song speaks out against inequalities in Philippine society and is a critique of the hierarchical class structure and oppressive political system of the country:

Habang may tatsulok

At sila ang nasa tuktok,

’di matatapos itong gulo

(As long as the triangle exists

and they are on top,

this chaos will not end.)

Using the pyramid as the metaphor for the existing asymmetrical sociopolitical rule that oppresses the masses, the song rails against the greed and ambition of those that hold power. The lyrics are addressed to a young boy, Totoy, imploring him to view society with a critical mind. Written during the presidency of Corazon Aquino at the time when the government was at the height of its anti-insurgency campaign led by Fidel V. Ramos, the song exhorts the boy to be careful about being caught in the crossfire of a war that has caused much suffering among ordinary citizens.

“Tatsulok” was originally included in the album Karapatang Pantao (Human Rights), an anthology of songs by various artists, produced by Ed Formoso for the human rights group Ecumenical Movement for Justice and Peace (EMJP) and the recording company Dyna Products, Inc. In 1991, “Tatsulok” became the carrier song of Buklod’s second album. In 2007, Bamboo revived “Tatsulok” and included it in their album We Stand Together. Bamboo’s album sold at least 7,500 units and achieved a Gold Record Award. The band received the Awit Award for Best Performance by a Group while “Tatsulok” also won Best Rock Song. In 2013, during a Luneta rally against corruption involving the misuse and abuse of pork barrel funds, the song was sung by Darryl Shy who was one of the contestants in The Voice Philippines.  Written by Ira Cruz and Lara Katrina T. Mendoza

Sources

 

PARI (Philippine Association of the Record Industry). 2015. Accessed 29 Jan. http://www.pari.com.ph/articles.html.

———. 2015. “About Us.” Accessed 15 May. htttp://www.pari. com.ph/aboutus.html.

Remollino, Alexander Martin. 2015. “Rom Dongueto and the Revival of a Protest Song.” Bulatlat. Accessed 29 Jan. http:// www.bulatlat.com/news/7-6/7-6-song.htm.

Salamat, Marya. 2015. “Peoples’ Initiative vs Pork Draws Thousands to Luneta.” Bulatlat. Accessed 29 Jan. http:// bulatlat.com/main/2014/08/26/peoples-initiative-vs-pork- draws-thousands-to-luneta/.

Wikipedia. 2015. “Ira Cruz.” Accessed 29 Jan. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ira_Cruz

photos.desc:
Heber Bartolome in performance, 1989
(CCP Collection)

text:
(We Are Filipinos). Music and lyrics, HeberBartolome. First performed by Heber Bartolome and his group Banyuhay in the First Metro Manila Popular Music Festival in 1978 at the Folk Arts Theater.

 

Considered a classic of the Pinoy folk rock genre, the song provokes nationalistic sentiments with patriotic fury and irony. It lashes out against the colonial mentality of Filipinos, referring sardonically to “imported” aesthetic standards:

Tayo’y mga Pinoy

Tayo’y hindi Kano

Huwag kang mahihiya

Kung ang ilong mo ay pango.

(We are Filipinos

We are not Americans

Don’t be ashamed

If you are pug-nosed.)

This theme, developed in subsequent verses, culminates in a wry appeal for authentic nationalism and derides the persistent use of flawed English by Filipinos:

Katulad ng iba

Pa-ingles-ingles pa

Na kung pakikinggan

Mali-mali naman

Huwag na lang.

(There are some

Who try to speak in English

But listen to them closely

Their English is all wrong

Just forget it.)

The composition is in verse-chorus form with phrases and periods of varying lengths. Instrumental bridges, transitions, and a long 11-bar instrumental improvisation create a richly textured frame for the basic melodic line. The melody of the A section is reminiscent of the kundiman, although its 4/4 beat distinguishes it from the traditional form, which is always in 3/4 time signature. Also, unlike the kundiman, the song remains in the minor mode from beginning to end. The original instrumentation, with its use of the electric guitar, bass, and drums, provides the work with a driving, aggressive rock color.

A deconstructed version of the song using the last two lines of the refrain has also been recorded by Francis Magalona in his album, Rap is FrancisM, 1992.  Written by Raj Mansukhani

article_title: Ti Ayat ti Maysa nga Ubing
text:
(The Love of a Young Maiden). Ilocano folk song.

This popular Ilocano folk song has a danza rhythm. It is made up of four similar periods, with the last two periods transposed to another major key a minor third higher.

 

The text compares the sweet love of a young maiden and the bitter love of an old and foolish man:

Ti ayat ti maysa nga ubing

Nasamsam-it ngem jasmin

Casla sabong nga apagucrad

Iti bulan ti Abril

Ti ayat ti maysa nga lacay

Aglalo no agkabao

Napait, napait,

Napait nga macasubkar.

Ala ngarud o lelong

Sumapulca iti balo

Nga capadpad a ta uban mo

Ken dayta toppol mo.

Ta bay-am a panunotenen

Ti ayat ti maysa nga ubing

Aglalo, aglalo

No addan makinaywanen.

(The love of a young maiden

Is sweeter than the jasmine

Like a flower that has just bloomed

In the month of April.

The love of an old man

Especially if he is senile

More so when foolish

Is bitter, it’s loathsome.

So, oh! Grandpa

Look for a widow

That would watch your white hair

And your toothlessness.

Think no more

Of the love of a young maiden

Especially, especially

If someone is already looking after her.)

The folk song was used by Eliseo M. Pajaro in his symphonic poem, Life of Lam-ang, 1951, where the melody appeared as the heroine Ines’s answer of love. The song also has been arranged for piano, choir, and orchestra. Raul Sunico’s arrangement for solo piano is included in his CD album Sungdo ni Ayat (The Pain of Love), a collection of Ilocano love songs, in 2003.

Various arrangements for choral singing have been written and performed by different groups in recent years. Fabian Obispo’s choral arrangement continues to engage the audience and has since been performed by the Philippine Madrigal Singers on their many forays abroad; by the UP Singing Ambassadors on their concert tour in 2008; and by the Madrigal Alumni Ensemble, in celebration of the 50th anniversary of the Madrigal Singers at the Ford Amphitheatre, California, in 2013. Still another arrangement for SATB (soprano-alto-tenor-bass) choir was used by the UST Singers during their concert tour in 2011. Other arrangements include those for children’s choir, including one for the UP Cherubim and Seraphim by Antonio Regalario used in their first tour in the United States (US) in 1975 and recorded in their album Wings that same year, and another used by the Loboc Children’s Choir of Bohol during their US tour in 2008.

In 4 Sep 2015, an orchestral version of the song was performed by the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra (PPO), in a concert titled Serenata (Serenade) at the Cultural Center of the Philippines (CCP) Nicanor S. Abelardo. The concert, which was part of the celebration of the CCP’s 46th anniversary, featured Filipino folk songs arranged by Ryan Cayabyab, performed by the PPO and included in the special collector’s CD Serenata: Well-Loved Philippine Folk Songs and Melodies, released in the same year.  Written by Corazon C. Dioquino, updated by James C. Diaz

photos.desc:
Album cover of Ella May Saison’s Language of Soul, 1993,

which includes “Till My Heartaches End” (Viva Records)

text:
1992. Composed by Tito Cayamanda and Vehnee Saturno. Originally sung by Ella May Saison with an arrangement by Gerry Paraiso.

The song is about the pains of romantic love—a theme that is dear to many Filipinos. The lyrics evoke a picture of a woman who lost not only her love but herself, having become disoriented because of loneliness and regret. The persona of the singer, however, does not succumb to despair. Judging from the timbre of the voice, the act of singing evokes strength itself and the protagonist turns to dreams to ease up her agony. The song’s chorus goes:

 

I was afraid this time would come

I wasn’t prepared to face

this kind of hurtin’ from within

I have learned to live my life beside you

Maybe I’ll just dream of you tonight

And if into my dream you’ll

come and touch me once again

I’ll just keep on dreaming till my heartaches end

The song is based on a 48-bar, verse-chorus structure or AAB and is in the key of F. The first verse is sung to eight-bar symmetrical phrases, while the second is comprised of two eight-bars.

“Till My Heartaches End” became the title and theme song of the movie starring Kim Chiu and Gerald Anderson, directed by Jose Javier Reyes, and released by Star Cinema in 2010. Carol Banawa, who covered the song in the movie’s soundtrack, also included it in her album My Music, My Life, which was released in the same year under Star Records/Black Bird Music.  Written by Giesil Carina Merin, with additional notes from Jose S. Buenconsejo

photos.desc:
Ramon Santos conducting a  performance of Tin-ig, 2010

(Ramon P. Santos Collection)

text:
(Voices). 1982. Music, Ramon P. Santos. A piece for orchestra. Commissioned by the Cultural Center of the Philippines and the League of Filipino Composers. Premiered in Manila in 1983.

The standard orchestral instrumentation of woodwinds (3-3-3-3 + piccolo + E-flat and bass clarinets), brass (3-4-3-3-1), and strings (minimum 5-5-5-5-3), is supplemented by a piano and a battery of percussion instruments (minimum seven players) that is characteristic of the wide spectrum of colors unique to Santos’s orchestral output beginning the 1970s.

 

The work is in 13 movements, with a total duration of around 18 minutes. Each of the 13 movements in the work presents the conceptual, procedural, textural, and even the melodic processes that are inspired by various Asian musical practices.

The 13 movements symbolically highlight the variety of the composer’s musical experiences at the time of its writing. Movement II opens with interlocking patterns on col legno battuto strings (strings struck with the wood of the bow) that reminds one of various indigenous instrumental ensembles in Southeast Asia. This movement flows from the previous movement where the col legno battuto sounds are mere punctuations of bowed muted strings. In Movement III, however, this battuto interlock is conceptually developed, as each individual string player “fits-in” either 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, or 6 equal beats within the frame of a 4/4 meter, and with each individual entry, creates a more complex resultant texture. In opposition to Movement I, the battuto interlock in Movement III is drowned by bowed strings as it comes to a close, leading directly to Movement IV, where percussive gestures from the strings progress into percussion instruments. Further on, Movement IX presents an interesting procedural scoring. Divided into groups, musicians from the string and percussion sections of the orchestra are cued by the conductor to play written-out musical patterns in an extended canon. This is followed by Movement X with its relative brevity, where a single melodic fragment is extended into a variety of sound colors. The most impressive piece in the collection, however, is Movement V, where orchestral colors are combined to form a single, collective sound envelope that appears to simulate the spectral transformations of a single strike of a very large gong or tam-tam. This unique movement stands above all the other movements as among the most creative of Santos’s orchestral output.

The work ranks high in Filipino contemporary art instrumental music. It is both a notable artistic output and a pedagogical material for composition students.  Written by Jonas U. Baes

Ramon Santos conducting a  performance of Tin-ig, 2010

(Ramon P. Santos Collection)

article.value: The work is in 13 movements, with a total duration of around 18 minutes. Each of the 13 movements in the work presents the conceptual, procedural, textural, and even the melodic processes that are inspired by various Asian musical practices.

The 13 movements symbolically highlight the variety of the composer’s musical experiences at the time of its writing. Movement II opens with interlocking patterns on col legno battuto strings (strings struck with the wood of the bow) that reminds one of various indigenous instrumental ensembles in Southeast Asia. This movement flows from the previous movement where the col legno battuto sounds are mere punctuations of bowed muted strings. In Movement III, however, this battuto interlock is conceptually developed, as each individual string player “fits-in” either 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, or 6 equal beats within the frame of a 4/4 meter, and with each individual entry, creates a more complex resultant texture. In opposition to Movement I, the battuto interlock in Movement III is drowned by bowed strings as it comes to a close, leading directly to Movement IV, where percussive gestures from the strings progress into percussion instruments. Further on, Movement IX presents an interesting procedural scoring. Divided into groups, musicians from the string and percussion sections of the orchestra are cued by the conductor to play written-out musical patterns in an extended canon. This is followed by Movement X with its relative brevity, where a single melodic fragment is extended into a variety of sound colors. The most impressive piece in the collection, however, is Movement V, where orchestral colors are combined to form a single, collective sound envelope that appears to simulate the spectral transformations of a single strike of a very large gong or tam-tam. This unique movement stands above all the other movements as among the most creative of Santos’s orchestral output.
The work ranks high in Filipino contemporary art instrumental music. It is both a notable artistic output and a pedagogical material for composition students.  Written by Jonas U. Baes

text:
(Voice of the Earth). 1980. Music, Ruben Federizon. Originally scored for solo soprano and woodwinds, and later revised for choir. This version was premiered in 1980 by the UP Concert Chorus under conductor Reynaldo T. Paguio, and with soprano Imelda Ongsiako.

Ruben Federizon composed Tinig ng Lupa in 1980 after watching the news on TV about a landslide caused by the cutting of trees by a logging company in the Visayas that resulted in the loss of many lives. The composition is not a realistic description of the incident but an exhortation to respect nature. This environmental theme remains very relevant today.

 

It opens with an “attention catcher,” a rhythm in changing meters played by two pairs of kalatong sticks punctuated by the choir that intones vocal sounds: /ay/, /oy/, /rrrr/, /hu/, /hm/, /a-i/, /ug/, and /wo/. This section ends with a hushed tone cluster on the basses that settles to a one-note drone which ushers in the next section. In the succeeding second section, the pulse slows down but it remains in pianissimo. This grows bigger, agitated, and is interrupted by a solo soprano that brings in the third section. This structure is reminiscent of the opening of Gabaq-an by the same composer, but with a significant variation. Here, the female soloists enter one at a time until all of the singers have joined in to thicken the density of the sound. The fourth section is characterized by dissonant ostinato chords from the male sections punctuated by the kalatong alongside rhythmic interjections from the female sections. The last section reiterates the opening section with same changing meters played by the kalatong, this time punctuated by the whole choir. The piece ends in crescendo on the highest note possible sung by a solo soprano.

Tinig ng Lupa became part of UP Concert Chorus’s repertoire during their international tour in 1980. The piece was also performed by the Philippine Madrigal Singers.  Written by Antonio C. Hila

text:
1958. Music, Lucrecia R. Kasilag. First performed and recorded by the Filipino Youth Symphony Orchestra at the 1959 Philippine Music Festival with Luis C. Valencia conducting. Recipient of the Republic Cultural Heritage Award, 1960. First performed abroad on 21 May 1963 at the Festival of Music and Arts of this Century, sponsored by the University of Hawaii Music Department and the East-West Center’s Institute of Advanced Projects.

 

Scored for Western, Maranao, and Tausug instruments, it is written in rondo form and utilizes themes from Muslim folk music. It opens with the drum’s statement of the theme in fugal exposition, and progresses in canon as the metal percussion instruments restate the melodic and rhythmic patterns. The wind group enters with the haunting theme followed by the piano picking up the main theme. The third theme is played by five Tiruray gongs. In the final section, the first and second themes reappear, leading to the coda.

The Maranao and Tausug instruments used are two kulintangan (eight gongs in a row), five Tiruray gongs, metal xylophone, gabbang (bamboo xylophone), babandil (small gong), gandingan (set of four hanging gongs), agong (big gong), and dabakan (drum). The Western instruments used are the piano, B-flat clarinet, cymbal, trumpet in C, triangle, horn in F, trombone in C, tympani, snare drum, and bass drum.  Written by Jeanna B. Malabuyoc

article_title: Transfiguration, Work for Orchestra, Chorus, and Narrator
text:
1983. Music, Francisco F. Feliciano. First performed by the Philippine Philharmonic Orchestra and Philippine Madrigal Singers on 25 Nov 1983 at the Main Theater (now Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo), Cultural Center of the Philippines, with Feliciano conducting and Rolando S. Tinio narrating.

 

Based on a Biblical text, Feliciano’s Transfiguration, written in contemporary idiom and free form, uses passages of the Old Testament, specifically, Exodus, Daniel, and the Book of Psalms which all relate to the New Testament account of Luke (9:28-36) on the Transfiguration. The series of quotations leads to a climax in the “Sanctus” and ends with passages from 2 Peter 1:16-21.

The orchestra and chorus complement each other as the orchestra creates an ever-evolving sequence of sound masses against the monophonic Gregorian chanting of the chorus. Both orchestra and chorus complement each other again at the end. Two musical quotations, the “Kyrie Eleison” and the “Hosanna in Excelsis” from the Gregorian Dominicalis, and the “Hosanna in Excelsis” from Palestrina’s Pope Marcellus Mass were used in the composition. The staging is done with the orchestra and the chorus distributed in the hall and on the stage.  Written by Antonio C. Hila

text:
(Teasing). 1967. Music, Ramon P. Santos. Composed for the UP Madrigal Singers, this choral work uses three Filipino children’s songs as thematic material: “Sampung mga Daliri” (Ten Little Fingers), “Isa, Dalawa, Tatlo” (One, Two, Three), and “Yelo Malamig” (Cold Ice). It is scored for soprano, alto, tenor, and bass, sung without accompaniment or a capella.

The imitative and playful interplay of melodic motifs is reminiscent of the light English canzonets and madrigals. However, the use of unexpected dissonances and altered chords give it a fresh, contemporary flavour. The main melodic themes, deftly interwoven with each other, are easily recognizable though clothed in a new harmonic idiom.

 

Tuksuhan was followed by Tula-tula (Poetica), 1967, written in the same style and based on three nonsense songs: “Penpen di Sarapen,” “Jack en Poy” (Jack and Poy), and “Leron-Leron Sinta” (Leron-Leron Beloved). The success of these songs, both in the local as well as international scene, prompted other composers to make similar arrangements of popular folk and game songs.  Written by Corazon C. Dioquino

photos.desc:
Jose Maceda conducting a performance of Udlot-udlot, Quezon Hall,

University of the Philippines Diliman, 1975 (UP Center for Ethnomusicology)

text:
(Fluctuation). 1975. Music, Jose Maceda. First performed by 800 students on 16 Oct 1975 at the Folk Arts Theater grounds, Manila, during the Third Asian Festival Conference.

 

Udlot-udlot’s technology may be described as primeval: only four types of native bamboo instruments are used, but these may also be multiplied limitlessly. These are the kalutang (percussion sticks), tongatong (stamping tube), balingbing (bamboo buzzer), and ungiyong (whistle flute). Three varying ostinato patterns are heard. The kalutang plays the first pattern which persists throughout the 40-minute work. The two other patterns, heard at intervals, are perceived against this, creating an immense cloud of sound. This nontraditional realm of sound may be incomprehensible to the urbanized but it is familiar to the villager for whom music is a highly integral part of everyday life.

The piece was performed beside, rather than in, concert venues, illustrating Maceda’s preference for open-air spaces, thereby manifesting the Southeast Asian village traditions in his musical philosophy. In a night performance in 1978 at the Chulalongkorn University in Bangkok, the performers moved about under the glow of torches evoking an extraordinary ritualistic atmosphere. The work was performed at Gamelan Aid project at the Tenjin-Bashi Art-Cento on 22 May 2010 and at the Senri Expo Park on 22 Oct of the same year in Japan. Maceda’s composition is in itself a valuable link between the Filipino’s ancient past and the modern spirit.  Written by Ma. Patricia Brillantes, updated by Josephine Cecilia L. Baradas

text:
(Movement). 1986. Music, Josefino Toledo. First performed at the Cleveland Institute of Music, Ohio, USA in Apr 1986.

 

Ug-og is a southern Philippine word for forced motion or movement. The composition examines Southeast Asian musical tradition with its use of drones, liquefied and motoristic rhythms, mass sounds, and processed musical elements. It also explores the striking sonorities that can be derived from an undertone series, in particular the eighth to twelfth partials of A-flat3.

The work is scored for alto flute, English horn, clarinet, bass clarinet, bassoon, contrabassoon, two horns, trombone, bass trombone, tuba, and several percussions for three players.  Written by Flerida G. Nolasco

text:
(Coordination). 1973. Music, Jose Maceda. Premiered by 20 Manila-based radio stations on January 1, 1974.

 

Ugnayan is 50-minute work for 20 radio stations composed by Jose Maceda in 1973. The pretaped music of each station consists of sounds taken from Philippine native instruments organized according to a musical plan made up of different shapes and textures. Each of the radio stations serve as a musical instrument and together they comprise an orchestra where more of the same instruments are replicated many times over, by dozens and even thousands of receivers, each playing his/her own ostinato in homes, buildings, parks, and open spaces.

At its premiere, thousands of people within a radius of 100 kilometers from Manila played their transistor radios in parks and listened to a meditative music from their own transistors. At Rizal Park in Luneta, ambulant participants carrying their transistor radios had the opportunity to listen not only to their own radio but also to enjoy the combined sounds of music emanating from other radio stations carried by other participants. Ugnayan was also performed in Amsterdam in 1975 and in Bonn in 1980.

An earlier work by Maceda, Cassettes 100, composed in 1971, served as a study for Ugnayan. Cassettes 100 was limited to 100 participants with cassette recorders playing pretaped music and moving to simple choreography. Its initial performance was at the lobby of the Main Theater (now Tanghalang Nicanor S. Abelardo) of the Cultural Center of the Philippines. The 1974 recording, which was supervised by the composer himself directing teachers and students of the University of the Philippines College of Music, was released as a CD with the same title by John Zorn’s label Tzadik in Nov 2009.  Written by Corazon C. Dioquino, updated by Josephine Cecilia L. Baradas

text:
1953. Music, Juan Silos Jr; lyrics, Levi Celerio. Recorded by Sylvia La Torre for Villar Records, 1953, and by American actress, singer, and activist Eartha Kit in an album titled Live from the Cafe Carlyle, 2006.

 

One of Silos’s most popular novelty works, it was supposedly composed while Silos was bathing. The song praises Waray women from the eastern Visayas provinces of Leyte and Samar for being tougher than the rest:

Waray-waray, hindi tatakas

Waray-waray, bahala bukas

Waray-waray, handang matodas

Waray-waray, manigas.

Waray-waray, tawag sa akon

Sa bakbakan, dili mag-urong

Sa sinuman na humahamon

Kahit ikaw ay maton.

(Waray-waray, will not run away

Waray-waray, come what may

Waray-waray, ready to die

Waray-waray, ‘til death.

Waray-waray, that’s what they call me

In fistfights, I don’t back out

From whoever challenges me

Even if you are a toughie.)

The song’s structure is AABAA: A is in the major key, while B is in the minor. La Torre’s version is polka-like, while Kitt’s is jazzy in style. The song is gay and funny in either tempo. While the lyrics are mainly in Tagalog, Waray words such as “akon” and “dili” are interjected, creating the impression that the persona is a native Waray speaking Tagalog.

The song was the theme of the LVN movie of the same title, which starred Nida Blanca and Nestor de Villa in 1954. “Waray-waray” has been arranged for chorus by Fidel Calalang Jr in a version performed by the UST Singers and the UP Singing Ambassadors.  Written by Michael M. Coroza, updated by James C. Diaz
